bio: Apple icon riding high on iPod —Apple shares are up 70% in the past year—and his animation hit factory Pixar, which he agreed to sell to Disney for $7.4 billion. Music execs who grumble that Apple sells lots of iPods but not much music may have to change their tune: company&#39s iTunes site now selling 3 million songs a day, accounting for 83% of the downloadable music sold opn the Internet. Now mobile phone carriers take aim at Apple, planning their own MP3 services, but Jobs trumps them with new iTunes-branded Motorola phone. Business equally rosy in Hollywood. Movies by animation powerhouse Pixar (Toy Story, Finding Nemo, The Incredibles) grossed $3.2 billion at worldwide box office. Underwent surgery for pancreatic cancer August 2004; back at work after a month.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took over family’s oil business in 1969, expanded into banking, real estate, alternative energy. Latest push: liquefied natural gas. His “energy bridges” unload liquefied gas from tankers and ship it ashore via submerged pipelines. Supports disadvantaged children through his family foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Formerly Bogotá&#39s top builder, Sarmiento, 73, now concentrates on Grupo Aval, his profitable network of regional banks. Grooming son Luis Carlos Jr. to take over family empire, which also includes investments in telecom and construction. Net worth up significantly, thanks largely to Colombia&#39s blistering stock market, the world&#39s second best performing in 2005. Kicks back at Cotton Bay Club, his private island in the Bahamas. Member of the Order of Boyaca, one of Colombia&#39s highest civilian honors..

name: Billionaires
bio: Fourth generation of Swiss-German industrial fortune heads Holcim, the world's second-largest supplier of cement, aggregates and concrete. Holds an engineering degree from the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology and a PhD in business administration from Tufts University. Honorary Consul-General of the Republic of Cyprus in Switzerland. His personal wine holdings include the Cuvaison and Chapel Hill labels and the revamped Weingut Schmidheiny, a vineyard in Balgach, Switzerland, where he was born.

name: Billionaires
bio: Plush-toy salesman’s son dropped out of Kalamazoo College, started own line of toy animals 1986. Beanie Babies ruled the lunchbox set for years with understuffed, affordable toys. Created buying mania by limiting production runs, assigning names and birth dates. Sales (est. $500 million) down sharply as Beanie Babies’ popularity wanes, but investments in real estate appreciating nicely. Owns Four Seasons Hotel in New York, Montecito Country Club in Santa Barbara, Calif. Also less glamorous office parks in Chicago. Recently completed construction on the Ty Warner Sea Center, also in Santa Barbara.

name: Billionaires
bio: Texas rancher turned computer ace waltzed through Princeton, hedge funds on Wall Street before 30th birthday. Left New York with wife to sell books on the Internet from Seattle garage. Named company Amazon because of river’s never-ending tributaries. Books remain big business, but world’s biggest virtual mall sells toys, T shirts, blenders and boom boxes. Sales: $8.5 billion. Still fond of the frontier: ranch in Texas serves as headquarters for pet project Blue Origin, commercial space-travel venture.

name: Billionaires
bio: Made his fortune in the mundane business of putting together PCs, MP3 players and cell phones for others. Founded Hon Hai Precision, now the world's largest contract manufacturer after leapfrogging Flextronics. Shares in its majority-owned international division Foxconn, have tripled in value since they were listed last year in Hong Kong.  Gou's annual salary: 3 cents (NT$1). Last year, he announced he would live off Hon Hai's dividends, even though he is still keeps workaholic hours as chairman and president of the company he founded. Also put a chunk of his shares in a trust to pay employee bonuses. After his wife's sad death from cancer last year, Gou has been receiving flowers and attention from hopeful women.

name: Billionaires
bio: Computer Associates' biggest individual shareholder. Haefner's 21.4% stake can be traced back to 1968 when he sold his data processing business to University Computing, which was later acquired by Computer Associates. His AMAG is the biggest importer of Volkswagen, Seat, Skoda, Audi and Porsche in Switzerland. His Moyglare Stud Farm in Ireland has bred winners including Simple Exchange and Media Puzzle.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Rupert (see), runs Franklin Resources, mutual fund company started by Rupert Sr. in 1947. Yale grad, former Army lieutenant, serves as chairman. Son Gregory sits as president and CEO. Today more than $465 billion assets under management with offices in 29 countries and more than 100 investment products.

name: Billionaires
bio: Harvard Business School grad and former oil-trader, his holdings include Maxis Communications, Malaysia's largest cell-phone service provider, with more than six million subscribers; now entering the Indian cell-phone market.  His Measat satellites help telecoms and broadcasters reach customers and audiences across Southeast Asia, China, South Asia and Australia. Also controls racetrack betting and lottery systems in Malaysia via Tanjong Public.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former IBM salesman founded Electronic Data Systems 1962, sold to General Motors for $2.5 billion in 1984. Founded rival information services firm Perot Systems in 1988. Stepped down for politics in 1992, making 2 unsuccessful bids for presidency; warned of job losses from free trade agreements. Since then Perot Systems set up subsidiaries in India. Chairman emeritus spends time supporting military veterans. Son Ross Perot Jr. heads Dallas real estate firm Hillwood Development.

name: Billionaires
bio: Raised in Russia, immigrated to U.S. with family at age 21. Worked way through graduate school, founded industrial holding company Access Industries in 1986. Later worked with Russian school chum Viktor Vekselberg (see), then Russian billionaire Mikhail Fridman (see). Trio made fortune setting up TNK-BP, joint partnership between their Tyumen Oil Company and British Petroleum; became Russia's second-largest oil company. Recently bought plastics manufacturer Basell from Shell and BASF for $5.7 billion. Also owns stakes in Siberian-Urals Aluminum (SUAL), power company in Kazakhstan, Russian telecom Svazinvest, real estate in Argentina and the U.K. Board member of Warner Music. Access affiliate recently acquired the Academy of Science building in New York City for an estimated $30 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs nine golf courses; value of his properties dipped in the past year. Also the largest individual shareholder in Japan Airlines Corp., the nation's flagship carrier, and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Japan's biggest aerospace company and defense contractor. Itoyoma of late has become a shareholder activist: he is seeking the ouster of JAL's president Toshiyuki Shinamachi, after safety violations at Asia's largest airline hurt the company's share price. Shinamachi agreed to step down.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief of Fast Retailing, which owns Uniqlo, the Japanese version of the Gap. Big plans: sales were $3 billion for the fiscal year ending in August 2005; wants to hit $10 billion by 2010. Recognizes the need to expand outside of Japan, where population is limited. Has recently opened stores in Hong Kong, South Korea and the U.S. Also bought stakes in international brands: Comptoir des Cotonniers from France, Aspesi from Italy and Theory from the U.S. Has learned from mistakes; started Uniqlo in the U.K. in 2001 with 20 locations, but grew too quickly and closed 16 of them soon after. The recent moves are paying off; in the past year stock is up nearly 40% to a recent $86.

name: Billionaires
bio: Famed 71-year-old clothing designer not close to retirement. Too busy making deals around the globe. Recently lent Armani moniker to perfume, baby clothes, home decor, $10,000 Prive Borgo watches and hotels going up in the Middle East. Plans to open 20 new AX Armani Exchange stores in China by 2008 through a joint venture. Also on tap: stores in Japan and Central and South America. Former life: spent two years in medical school at the University of Bologna before dropping out in 1957 to take a job as a department store buyer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Often referred to as the Siberian hermit, rarely leaving his remote town of Surgut. Avoids public attention and the trappings of wealth. A professional driller, Bogdanov was appointed CEO of Surgutneftegas (means “Surgut oil and gas”), when he was 33 years old. In early 1990s Bogdanov and his fellow managers privatized the company. Now Russia&#39s fourth-largest oil company, Surgutneftegas invests heavily in exploration, oil field development and education. Group now sits on whopping $13 billion in cash, yet Bogdanov hasn&#39t acquired other oil outfits or moved into new industries like many of his rivals.

name: Billionaires
bio: Financier father, Henry Crown (d. 1990), created Material Service with 2 brothers in 1919 after being fired from $4-per-week job. Built into multimillion-dollar business; merged with General Dynamics 1959. Today Lester retains big stake of General Dynamics; stock in Hilton Hotels, Alltel. Also big stake in Maytag, appliance outfit purchased by Whirlpool for $1.7 billion in August. Activist spends free time solving global problems: chairs Chicago Foreign Relations Council, sits on board of Aspen Institute. Competitive edge kept sharp with stakes in baseball’s New York Yankees, basketball’s Chicago Bulls.

name: Billionaires
bio: Met partner John Sall at North Carolina State; cofounded software giant SAS Institute after graduating. Developed business intelligence programs and platforms. Clients include U.S. Department of Defense, Air France, pharmaceutical and financial services companies. SAS is world’s largest privately held software manufacturer. Estimated sales: $1.5 billion. Despite persistent rumors, no plans to go public.

name: Billionaires
bio: Eldest son of slain Lebanese prime minister Rafik. Carved out successful career in investment management outside the family fold from Geneva, his home base. More recently, led successful $6.5 billion bid for Turk Telekom, the largest privatization in Turkey to date. Also heavily involved in family's Al-Abdali real estate development project in Jordan that is working to rebuild the city center of Amman. Chairs two soccer clubs in Lebanon. His mother Nazek, brothers Saad, Fahd and Ayman, and sister Hind are all billionaires (see all).

name: Billionaires
bio: Second son of Rafik Hariri, slain prime minister of Lebanon who also founded Saudi Oger, a now $3.3 billion (sales) construction firm. Georgetown University graduate and Saudi business maven has focused on politics since his father's death. The Cuban-cigar-loving leader of Lebanon's Future Bloc won seats in parliament last spring and is considered a likely candidate for prime minister. But the nation's president is blocking him from taking that post. Because of the frictions and safety concerns, spent most of the year away from Beirut in Riyadh.  Mother Nazek, his three brothers Bahaa, Fahd and Ayman, and his sister, Hind, are all individual billionaires (see all).

name: Billionaires
bio: In 1982 succeeded her father as head of A. Johnson & Co., a diversified trading company founded by her great-grandfather in 1873. The privately held $5.6 billion (sales) company has interests in everything from energy and telecom to real estate and food retailing; its Axfood AB is one of the largest food operations in Scandinavia. Attended Radcliffe College in Cambridge, Mass. as an exchange student in the early 1960s. She is an avid horsewoman and a member of numerous Swedish charities, including the World Childhood Foundation, which was founded by the nation’s queen.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of August Kühne, one of the founders of transport and logistics group Kühne & Nagel. Still holds 56% of the publicly traded group, which he has run for four decades. Must love cruising: although he lives in land-locked Switzerland, he has built an extravagant house said to look like the main command deck of an ocean liner.

name: Billionaires
bio: Through timber giant Empresas CMPC, Matte controls 1.5 million acres of pine and eucalyptus in Chile and Argentina. Maintains holdings in ports, telecommunications and financial services. University of Chicago-educated, Matte also reportedly owns a 50% stake in Las Parvas, one of South America's top ski resorts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Electronics salesman for Dad’s distribution company, skipped college to open car stereo shop 1966. Later lured older customers with VCRs, small appliances. Early proponent of big-box-store concept: piled inventory on sales floor, let customers fondle merchandise. Took public as Best Buy in 1985. Today $29 billion in sales, more than 800 locations. Stepped down as CEO in 2002. Quiet philanthropist gives to  children, families and education.

name: Billionaires
bio: A former military man who turned out to be a financial whiz. In the 1990s helped privatize Lukoil, which was formed out of the best Russian oil properties; now the right hand of Lukoil chief Vagit Alekperov. As vice president, responsible for strategic development and external relations. “My wealth is a virtual thing; 99% of my money consists of Lukoil shares,” Fedun has said. But oil is real, and due to its high prices and effective company management, Lukoil&#39s market cap nearly doubled last year. An avid soccer fan: when his club, Spartak of Moscow, came in second in the Russian championship, Fedun awarded his players generously; his goalkeeper got a Hummer H2.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ninth-grade dropout pumped gas until drafted by Army in 1943. Moved to Detroit after World War II, borrowed $1,800 to buy diner, sold for modest profit. Turned to building homes in Arizona; lost out in real estate crash of 1964. To southern California, bought more property. Then leveraged buyouts: Castle & Cooke (Hawaiian real estate), Dole Food (bananas). GOP fundraiser also holds stake in Pacific Holdings, conglomerate owns largest chassismaker in the U.S. New interests: health and nutrition; plans to redevelop 5.8-million-square-foot factory complex in Kannapolis, N.C. into biotech research center. Orchid breeder lined the gardens of his estate with over 300 boulders mined from Thailand’s River Kwai.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded and runs $3 billion (sales) infotech group HCL, with operations in 15 countries. Claims to be the largest foreign employer in Northern Ireland where it has an offshore center with 2000 people. Customers include Boeing, IBM and Deutsche Bank. Also has a new venture with Japan's NEC. Is a movie buff and passionate about cricket.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stanford grad started eponymous discount stock brokerage in 1971. Accounts skyrocketed during the Internet boom only to nosedive in tech crash. Relinquished CEO position in 2003; took back a year later amid sagging profits. Plans to remain chairman through January 2007. Dyslexic, started the Charles & Helen Schwab Foundation for children with learning disabilities and AD/HD.

name: Billionaires
bio: In the last two years has profitably disposed of assets he accumulated in the 1990s during privatization. Sold Stoilensky GOK (ore mining and processing plant) to billionaire Vladimir Lisin, and Mikhailovsky GOK and a stake in the metallurgical business Tulachermet to billionaires Alisher Usmanov and Vasily Anisimov. In January 2006 Raiffeisen Bank of Austria acquired his Moscow Impexbank; he has invested the proceeds in the booming Russian stock market. Now lives in the Georgian village of Chorvila, where he was born.

name: Billionaires
bio: Significant shareholder of Al Rajhi Bank along with his three brothers (see also: Sulaiman Bin Abdul Al Rajhi, Saleh Bin Abdul Aziz Al Rajhi, Mohammed Abdul Aziz Al Rajhi). Has benefited from bank's rising share price. Also owns Al Rajhi Factories which manufactures everything from PVC pipes to foam mattresses as well as bottles potable water.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bought his father's one-route Ontario bus company for a dollar in 1951; eventually built into Power Corp., a $21 billion (sales) financial services and communications giant. Power Corp. consortium bought an indirect 25% stake in media giant Bertelsmann in early 2001. Also owns Investors Group, Canada's largest mutual fund group, and has holdings in specialty mineral companies and waste services. The stock, which split in 2004, is up slightly in the past year. While sons Andre and Paul Jr. run the company, Paul Sr. collects Canadian art and hunts birds at his private estate in Quebec.

name: Billionaires
bio:
This savvy banker sold his Banco Real to Dutch bank ABN Amro in 1998 for
$2.1 billion. Minority shareholders sued, hoping to snare a piece of Faria's
stake, but reportedly lost their case before Brazil's supreme court in
October 2005. Faria kept some of Banco Real's assets and transformed them
into Banco Alfa, now Brazil's 18th largest bank with nearly $4 billion in
assets. He also owns some 12,000 acres of farmland and a company reported to
be Latin America's largest palm oil producer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Scion of a distinguished family of Iraqi Jews who settled and made their fortunes in Asia. With brother-in-law, owns major stakes in the listed Hong Kong and Shanghai Hotels, which operates the famous Peninsula Hotel in Hong Kong, as well as CLP Holdings, one of the leading power supply companies in Hong Kong. Was knighted last year in honor of his extensive charitable and philanthropic activities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Deli-owner-turned-shopping-mall-Midas oversees a $33 billion (assets under management) portfolio of 130 malls in Australia, New Zealand, the U.K. and  U.S. Three sons are involved in the business: David is Westfield deputy chairman and overseas family investments; Peter, who heads up U.S.  operations, and Steven are group managing directors. As chairman of the  Football Federation of Australia, turned around Australia's languishing  soccer league. Also established the Lowy Institute for International Policy think tank.

name: Billionaires
bio: Studied chemistry at UC, Berkeley, Ph.D. from Caltech. One of the “Gang of Eight” that cofounded Fairchild Semiconductor in 1957. With partner Robert Noyce founded chipmaker Intel 1968. Introduced first microprocessor 1971. First year sales: $3,000. Today the world’s largest producer of computer chips, more than $30 billion in revenue. CEO from 1975 to 1998; coined Moore’s Law, predicting chip power would double every 12 (later revised to 24) months. Intel chairman emeritus donated half his stake to Moore Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Generic drug maverick relentlessly battled big pharma over exclusivity patents, gradually building Apotex into Canada&#39s second-largest drugmaker with $840 million in revenue. Once reportedly stormed into the offices of a rival, sheriff and private investigators in tow, to recover documents used later in a corporate espionage case. Once president and largest shareholder of Barr Laboratories, Sherman is now slowly selling off shares as the company continues to press the U.S. Food & Drug Administration for over-the-counter approval of its controversial “morning-after” pill.

name: Billionaires
bio: Honorary chairman of Ito-Yokado, one of Japan's biggest retailers, founded by his family in a seedy area of bombed-out Tokyo after World War II. Last September the superstore chain combined its three different retail chains into one new group, Seven & I Holdings, in part to help defend against takeovers. The $57 billion (combined market cap) group, which now ranks as Asia's largest retail chain, includes 11,103 Seven-Eleven Japans, 582 Denny's Japan and 181 Ito-Yokado supermarkets. The company, which is expanding its convenience store chain into China, also owns 7-Eleven in the U.S.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Charles (see), runs Franklin Resources, mutual fund company started by Rupert Sr. in 1947. Washington & Lee grad, former marine, vice chairman. Today more than $465 billion assets under management with offices in 29 countries and more than 100 investment products.

name: Billionaires
bio: Real estate developer and hotelier in Asia. His Millennium & Copthorne runs a chain of 90 hotels in 21 countries including the Millennium Resort Scottsdale McCormick in Arizona and the JW Marriott Hong Kong. His City Developments is one of the largest commercial landlords in Singapore. Announced in December 2005 that he would partner with the Las Vegas Sands Corporation to bid for the first casino in Singapore; pulled out a month later and said the decision was due to “some requirements associated with the bid.” His cousin Quek Leng Chan is also a billionaire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Russian immigrant parents found refuge in the Bronx; young Ralph worked day jobs at department stores. Left business school to design ties for Beau Brummel. Launched Polo in 1967 with $50,000 loan. Built reputation on classic preppy styles. Today Polo designs everything from socks to sofas. Recent moves: bought back licensing rights from Reebok to sell luxury footwear; became exclusive apparel sponsor for the U.S. Open through 2008. Owns ranch in Colorado, island retreat in Jamaica. Car and motorcycle enthusiast; collection of European cars was on display at Museum of Fine Arts in Boston: Bugatti, Bentley, Alfa Romeo, Ferrari, Porsche, Jaguar.

name: Billionaires
bio: Low-profile construction magnate is also the biggest shareholder in Tata Sons, the holding company that owns Tata Consultancy Services, India&#39s largest software company. Also owns direct-selling venture Eureka Forbes and textile firm Forbes Gokak. His top brands include: Kingfisher beer, Bagpiper whiskey and McDowell‚s No.1 Brandy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Began career at Magnitogorsk Iron& Steel mill in 1967, becoming general director in 1998. Next year, defended his plant from a takeover attempt. Rashnikov kept his mill, but since then Magnitogorsk has been on the defensive. Unlike directors of other steel mills Rashnikov hasn't bought coal fields or plants abroad, but instead used financial resources to gain total control of the group: bought a 17.8% stake in the company from the Russian Government in December  2004 and purchased the remaining  15.3% from  the shareholders of Mechel steel group. Ironically Rashnikov stepped down as chief executive in February 2004, relinquishing day-to-day duties, and became chairman of the Board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Bombay and raised in the U.K., the two brothers started separate careers - Simon in carpets and real estate, David in metals trading - before joining together in Transworld, a metals trader that invested heavily in Russia and Kazakhstan. They say they and their various partners initially raked in upwards of $500 million in annual profits in the early 1990s from these trading activities. After the partnerships unraveled, the brothers got out, deciding to focus on more genteel investments of property and private equity. Simon resides in Monaco; David remains in London. The brothers were named Entrepreneurs of the Year at the fourteenth Variety Club Props Awards in May 2005.

name: Billionaires
bio: Left his medical practice in South Africa to join identical twin brother Thomas in founding generic drug maker Hexal AG in 1986. They eventually built it into Germany’s second-largest generic drug producer. Last February they sold that business as well as their 68% stake of U.S. Eon Labs to Novartis for $7.5 billion. At age 56 he isn’t quite ready to retire and accepted an executive position at Sandoz, a generics division of Novartis. Rumored to love golf, skiing and sailing.

name: Billionaires
bio: With identical twin brother Andreas, founded generic drug maker Hexal AG in 1986. Together they built it into Germany’s second-largest generic drug producer, with $1.6 billion sales in 2004. Last February they sold Hexal and their 68% of U.S. Eon Labs to Novartis for $7.5 billion. No plans yet to retire: like his twin, he accepted an executive post with Sandoz, a generics division of Novartis. Is said to be the more extroverted of the two brothers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Got start in storage business in 1972 after stopping at warehouse on road trip and learning it was full. Lost potential customers with confusing signs: people thought “Private Storage” meant closed to the general public. New name brought them in droves. Today Public Storage the nation’s largest self-storage company, with over 1,400 storage facilities in 37 states. Also real estate: 10 million square feet of commercial space through affiliate PS Business Parks. Supports cancer causes, particularly children’s leukemia. Last year donated $200 million to Parker Hughes Cancer Center in St. Paul, Minn., named for his late son.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hard-nosed chairman of ESL Investments merged Kmart with Sears, Roebuck in November, capping one of the greatest corporate comebacks in history. Lawyer’s son inspired by grandmother, devoted viewer of Wall Street Week; spent spare time in high school reading corporate reports, financial textbooks. Skull & Bones member at Yale; landed job at Goldman Sachs, mentored by Robert Rubin. Founded own firm in 1988. Snagged early investment from Richard Rainwater: “Eddie is the single best investing mind in the world today.” Other Forbes 400 clients: Michael Dell, David Geffen, Tisch family, Ziff brothers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Moscow; graduated from prestigious Moscow State Institute of International Relations with a major in international economic relations. In 1983 worked briefly at a Soviet institute while studying at the Foreign Intelligence Academy, a KGB training ground. Went to the European department of the Foreign Ministry's central office, although some say he was in foreign intelligence. Spent five years at the Russian Soviet Embassy in London. In 1995 acquired  Nationalny Reservny Bank and became its president. Most of his fortune now tied up in Gazprom and Unified Energy Systems shares. A Duma, or parliament, member, he is known for his criticism of corruption in Moscow and his struggle to rein in Russia's massive gambling industry.

name: Billionaires
bio: Star Wars avatar completed his intergalactic double trilogy last summer with Revenge of the Sith; summer blockbuster grossed $841 million at the box office. First movie came as student with futuristic police-state flick, THX-1138. Later: American Graffiti, Indiana Jones series. Fled Hollywood to set up special-effects shop Industrial Light & Magic (Harry Potter movies, War of the Worlds). But with his sci-fi franchise wrapped, what’s in the stars for this curiously rich George? Possible Indiana Jones sequel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vancouver magnate parlayed car dealerships, started shortly after college, into advertising, fishing and supermarket empire. Lately focusing on eclectic tourist attractions. Pushed into Thailand and Hong Kong with Ripley's Believe It or Not, exhibitor of oddities such as Ecuadorian shrunken heads and a stuffed white buffalo. Building 100,000 square foot water park in Niagara Falls next to largest aquarium in Canada. Retreats to massive Palm Springs lair once belonging to Frank Sinatra.

name: Billionaires
bio: Third son of Texas oilman Perry Bass (see) broke out on his own in 1983 to become formidable and secretive investor. His Oak Hill Capital Partners manages $12 billion, much of it in private equity. On the payroll: Myron Scholes, winner of the Nobel Prize in economics and onetime partner at Long-Term Capital Management. Led $700 million leveraged buyout of Duane Reade drugstore chain 2003. Followed that up with $250 million investment in Indian outsourcing company GE Capital International Services. Private equity fund has attracted cash from Bill Gates, Nike founder Phil Knight.

name: Billionaires
bio: Still owns some 19% of the world’s fifth-largest retailer Metro Cash & Carry, the group he founded in 1964. Retired but hardly idle, he has built a 172,000-square-foot luxury development complete with hotels, apartments, office space, restaurants and shops near the Potsdamer Platz in central Berlin. Also manages an Internet and technology company, Beisheim Holding Schweiz AG. A widower with no children, he divides his time between his homes in Switzerland, Paris, and Rottach-Eggern in Germany.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder, along with high school friend Jay Van Andel (d. 2004), of Amway, giant direct-seller of cosmetics, nutritional supplements. Pair started pushing all-purpose cleaner to friends in 1959; now more than 3 million salespeople generating $6 billion a year under Alticor name. Biggest market is Asia: China sales doubled in 2004. DeVos now retired, serves on board; second generation of both families in charge. Family also owns NBA’s Orlando Magic.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief executive of Formula One racing still knows how to cut a deal. He sold off the remaining 25% portion he still owned of the racing empire, yet managed to hold on to it at the same time. After selling his shares to CVC Capital Partners, a leading European private equity firm, he turned around and reinvested in a new joint venture with CVC called Alpha Prema. It is this new corporation that now controls 86% of Formula One Group. Bernie will still direct the empire. But the threat of car manufacturers starting their own rival series has not waned.

name: Billionaires
bio: Esther and her younger sister Alicia inherited Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas from their late father who founded the construction company. The two ran the company jointly from 1989 to 1997, when Esther bought out her sister for $800 million. Now owns 38% of the $7.6 billion (sales) construction giant and sits on the supervisory board. A member of Spanish nobility, she holds the title of Marquesa de Casa Peñalver y de Cárdenas de Monte Hermoso. She is married to Fernando Falcó, Marqués de Cubas, scion of an old Spanish family. Apparently loves ballet and classical music

name: Billionaires
bio:
His billions from beer keep growing. While at Banco Garantia, the Brazilian
investment bank that Lemann founded in 1971, he and his partners bought
control of a Brazilian brewery that eventually became AmBev. It merged with
Interbrew of the Netherlands in 2004. The stock of the combined firm, InBev,
soared 40% over the past year. A onetime tennis champion (he played at
Wimbledon), he still actively invests in Brazil with former Garantia
partners-and fellow billionaires-Marcel Telles and Carlos Alberto Sicupira
(see both).

name: Billionaires
bio: The perennial question surrounding Korea&#39s biggest family-owned companies: Is there a father-to-son succession in the works? Speculation about this at Hyundai was heightened in December, when Hyundai Motor group chairman Chung Mong-koo, 68, listed Glovis, the group&#39s logistics business, on the public markets. The public offering reportedly gave Chung&#39s only son, Eui-sun, 35, a 32% interest in Glovis worth $700 million--and enough cash to perhaps later increase his own stake in the world&#39s fifth-largest automobile manufacturer. Might not be a bad investment: Hyundai Motor&#39s share price climbed 50% last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Affable head of Swiss-based luxury group Richemont whose brands include Cartier, Chloe and Dunhill. Strong performance particularly in U.S. and Asia (excluding Japan) helped boost stock more than 50% in past 12-months. In 2005 Rupert yanked all Richemont ads from Wallpaper magazine because an article insulted Afrikaans, his native language. Busy year in South Africa as well. Vodafone announced plans to buy VenFin, one of Rupert's two main holding groups in that country. VenFin plans to keep its Vodacom assets and sell rest back to Rupert family's Rembrandt Trust and other shareholders. Oversees two of South Africa's best-known vineyards, Rupert & Rothschild and L'Ormarins (took over management after his brother died a few years ago); also owns one of country's most exclusive golf clubs. Father Anton Rupert, a respected South African industrialist who built family's early fortune in tobacco and other businesses, died in January.

name: Billionaires
bio: These secretive brothers own 18.5% of retailer Metro. Also control the 11-hotel Travel Charm chain of luxury hotels and spas located along Germany’s Baltic coast and in Austria.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Fubon Financial Holdings may weigh in on big decisions but his two U.S.-educated sons Daniel and Richard now otherwise run the show. Fubon has been aggressive among Taiwan financial institutions looking to expand overseas. It hopes this year to invest in a Chinese bank through its Hong Kong-listed subsidiary, Fubon Bank (Hong Kong).

name: Billionaires
bio: Trained physicist Tschira helped establish German software company SAP with four former IBM colleagues. Now retired, although still on SAP’s board, he concentrates on running his Klaus Tschira Foundation dedicated to pursuing whatever scientific research and cultural projects capture his imagination; for instance, sponsored a Brubeck Family Christmas Concert last December. His foundation is located in Heidelberg in the Villa Bosch, former home of German Nobel Prize-winning chemist Carl Bosch.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Austrian retail chain Billa, sold out to the German REWE group in 1996. He invested the proceeds in prime Austrian real estate and is now one of the largest, possibly the largest, private real estate owners in Austria. His assets include the five-star Hotel Radisson in Salzburg, the historic building that houses the Vienna Stock Exchange and four palaces in Vienna. The former jazz pianist, whose stage name was Charlie Walker, likes to hang out at the Cafe Central, an old coffee house he renovated in Vienna.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman and chief executive of Bouygues, a diversified industrial group that now has interests in telecom, media and construction. Founded by his father in 1952, the group's sales are still growing, up 15% in 2005. Sales at construction division Bouygues Immobilier were up 20%, thanks to strong demand for corporate and commercial property in Spain and Portugal. Bouygues Telecom, a hot target in the consolidating European telecom sector, hit $5 billion in sales last year. The company donates to education and the Toulouse Midi-Pyrenees Association of guide dogs for the blind. Bouygues is godfather to the son of interior minister and French presidential hopeful Nicolas Sarkozy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Medical device tinkerer created new cardiovascular catheter with $1,500 blowtorch, soldering iron and plastic tubing. Cook Inc. later branched out with pacemakers, syringes, stents. Rival Guidant proposed $3 billion buyout in 2003; deal fell through. Onetime Chicago cabbie still arrives at 5 a.m. for work. Recently caught the gambling bug: plans to renovate 2 hotels and build $250 million, 80,000-square-foot nautical-theme casino in French Lick, Ind. Charitable giving through Cook Group Orange County Holdings.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Chairs family-owned conglomerate $6.9 billion (2004 sales) Grupo Votorantim,
one of Brazil's largest, operating in aluminum, pulp and paper, cement and
orange juice. The group expanded into the U.S. last year by acquiring cement
plants in the Great Lakes region. His three siblings and their heirs also have stakes in the company. He writes a weekly column in a Sao Paulo newspaper.

name: Billionaires
bio: Since 2002 his Aiful has ranked as Japan's largest consumer finance company. The $4.5 billion (sales) company, known for its TV commercials featuring a chihuahua and its hapless owner, posted robust sales and profits for the year ending March 2005, thanks largely to its corporate loan business. According to a national tax report published last year, Fukuda was the biggest taxpayer in his hometown of Kyoto in 2004, paying $8 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Known as the Whiskey King of Thailand, Charoen's unlisted Thai Beverage has long been the market leader in Thailand for hard liquor, including its famous Mekong whiskey. Planning to take his company public this year in Singapore after protests derailed a listing in Thailand in 2005. Owns and lives in a ten-story Bangkok building located on the site of a former Thai prime minister's onetime home.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Salinas, who made his fortune in television, retail, and cellular services,
is one of Mexico&#39s more colorful billionaires. In 2005, the SEC said that he
bought the discounted debt of one of his outside holdings, Unefon, and then
sold it back to the company at face value. In doing so, he allegedly pocketed close to $109 million in the process for himself and a partner. (There has yet to be a ruling.) Salinas de-listed his companies from the NYSE last July, citing the time and resources necessary to comply with “excessive regulation.” Months earlier, the Mexican Finance Ministry reportedly asked federal prosecutors to bring the nation&#39s first insider-trading case against him. At press time, the Mexican attorney general&#39s office had yet to bring charges and Salinas was unavailable for comment.

name: Billionaires
bio: Upon his father's death in 1984, inherited Eternit, a manufacturer of construction materials. Sold the company after discovering that asbestos, a main ingredient in Eternit's products, was linked to cancer. Reinvested proceeds: early investor in Swatch. Professional managers now oversee his diversified portfolio of stocks, bonds and private equity investments. In 2003 donated $1 billion to support sustainable development programs like community organizations, educational programs, corporate social responsibility and the effective management of natural resources.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and chief executive of Softbank, Japan's leading Internet and telecom service company. Best known for its Yahoo Japan unit. Thanks in part to several years of aggressive promotion, which has included handing out free modems from hard-to-miss red stalls on busy street corners, his revolutionary IP phone/ADSL service has garnered almost 5 million subscribers. The company, however, still operates in the red, posting a $520 million loss (half the previous loss) for the year ending March 2005. Looking ahead Softbank is venturing into Japan's competitive cell phone market, a longtime ambition of Son's. The Japanese government last year greenlighted Softbank and two other companies to enter the mobile market.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grew up in Moscow and attended a well-regarded high school for Moscow's elite. After graduating from Moscow State University worked at the Institute for Systems Studies at the Soviet Academy of Sciences. In 1989 went to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and two years later was tapped to be minister of foreign economic relations. In 1994 met Alfa Group's head Mikhail Fridman and soon became a shareholder of Alfa-Bank, a business within the Alfa Group conglomerate; he is now its president. Owns Russia's largest private collection of Russian Art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Sam, left Russia 1899, founded Distillers Corp. in Montreal 1924. Acquired Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, made millions in whiskey along the U.S.-Canadian border during Prohibition. Sam died 1971, left Edgar with the American side of the business (other son, Charles, got the Canadian business). Added marquee brands (Chivas Regal, Absolut), entertainment (80% stake in MCA). Sold all to Vivendi for $34 billion in 2000. Son Edgar Jr. oversees big stake in Warner Music. Edgar Sr. active in Jewish causes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Built family&#39s scrap metal business into a cascade of assets in media, utilities and oil. Investments include a 25% stake in German media behemoth Bertelsmann, which will likely go public in May. Should push Frere&#39s worth into the stratosphere. Known as a workaholic who claims he&#39ll never retire, Baron Frere is a connoisseur of fine wine and co-owner, with French billionaire Bernard Arnault, of the Château Cheval Blanc vineyard.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Randstad Holding in 1960, now one the world’s largest temporary employment agencies. Owns 44% of the $7 billion (sales) company, which has branches in a dozen European and North American countries. Although retired, he remains vice chairman of the supervisory board. Enjoys sailing.

name: Billionaires
bio: A modern-day fairy tale: Heidi Jelinek, so the story is told, met Helmut Horten, founder of the eponymous German department store chain, in a hotel bar in 1959 when she was about 19 years old. Despite a 30-year age difference, they wed seven years later. She inherited an estimated $1 billion fortune from him, when he died in 1987. Now Austria’s merry widow divides her time between a home in Lyford Cay, a penthouse in Vienna and houses in the Tessin and by the Wörthersee in Austria. Owns one of the world’s largest yachts, the 315-foot Carinthia VII.

name: Billionaires
bio: First Czech billionaire to debut on Forbes billionaires list. Like most Central and Eastern European billionaires, he got his start when the government began privatizing nationalized companies in 1992. The economics school gratuate leveraged a $1 million loan he got through his small office supplies business into a controlling stake in Ceska pojistovna, the largest Czech insurer. That company is now worth $2.7 billion. In 2002, he invested $160 million in the hugely popular Czech Nova TV. Last year he sold his stake to American billionaire Ronald Lauder (see) for a $580 million net profit. Kellner, who has a "designer" house outside of Prague, collects photographs and started a boarding school for "genius" kids.

name: Billionaires
bio: The low-profile Lee family originally made its fortune in agriculture, but these days most of its fortune is in Oversea-Chinese Bank, one of the three biggest local banks in Singapore. The family also runs a major foundation, the Lee Foundation, which supports an opera troupe, among other things.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Internet shopping mall Rakuten, Mikitani has become Japan's leading Internet entrepreneur after high-profile rival Takafumi Horie disappeared from public view following his arrest for allegedly covering up losses at Livedoor. The two online businessmen had clashed over the right to buy Japan's first new baseball franchise in decades. Late to the contest, Mikitani won, naming his team the Rakuten Eagles. But his effort to take over major TV broadcaster TBS failed, like Horie's attempt on Fuji TV. Despite setbacks for Mikitani, his business keeps expanding with company revenue almost tripling to $1 billion in 2005 because of strong e-commerce sales.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Future Electronics in 1968 and built it into the world's third-largest electronics distributor (products include semiconductors and electromechanical components); now expanding rapidly in China. Supports several nonprofits including the Alcor Life Extension Foundation, which promotes cryonics, the science of freezing bodies with the intent to restore life when technology becomes available.

name: Billionaires
bio: From his home base in Monaco, this ultraprivate Romanian-born Israeli controls a vast international business empire that includes industrial conglomerate Israel Corp.; Zim, Israel&#39s largest container shipping company; and a $1 billion stake in Royal Caribbean. As part of estate planning, this octogenarian and his brother Yuli divided the family business last year-except for a retained shared interest in Mizrahi Bank-to pave the way for smooth succession. Yuli and his side get an Israeli and Eastern European real estate portfolio. Renowned philanthropist, Sammy set up an $8 million fund last year to buy lifesaving drugs. Said to possess one of the world&#39s largest collections of Marc Chagalls. Last year art insiders speculated he was the anonymous buyer who shelled out $13.1 million for Willem de Kooning&#39s Sail Cloth and $8.4 million for a bronze cast by Alberto Giacometti. Made headlines in February when he withdrew a $20 million donation to the Tel Aviv Museum of Art after other donors complained about the museum&#39s plan to change its name in his honor. “Excuse me for wanting to donate,” read the ad Sammy and wife Aviva placed in an Israeli newspaper announcing the withdrawal.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former butcher’s apprentice owns and runs $8 billion (sales) Anton Schlecker drugstore chain with help from his wife, Christa, and children Lars and Meike. There are 13,750 locations in Germany, accounting for 74% of the nation’s drugstores. In recent years the company has expanded into Austria, Holland, Spain, France and Italy. A football fan, Schlecker also enjoys sport cars, supposedly owning a Ferrari, an Aston Martin, a Porsche and an E-type Jaguar.

name: Billionaires
bio: President of $1.2 billion (sales) Keyence, a maker of laser sensors, code readers and other devices designed to help manufacturers automate production. Media-shy Takizaki's hobby is collecting fossils. Has a 350-million-year-old ammonite at the entrance of his headquarters, other fossils of long-dead creatures displayed in corridors and meeting rooms of this ultramodern high-rise. Relics are supposed to convey a tacit message to employees: keep aiming high or you'll become a fossil.

name: Billionaires
bio: Great-grandfather hawked baking soda, soap; threw in bonus stick of gum with purchase. Premium became more popular; introduced spearmint gum 1893. Fourth-generation gum maker chewing up competition; purchased Kraft Food candy business (Life Savers, Altoids) for $1.5 billion last November; floated $1 billion in bonds to finance deal. Eyeing China market, though per capita gum consumption just 10 sticks a year (in the U.S.: 160 sticks). U.S.’ largest gum producer sells 16 types of gum in 67 flavors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Battle of the search engines continues. After dropping Google last year, Yahoo revamped its own engine; now claims to scour more than 20 billion Web pages, images. Met partner Jerry Yang at Stanford. As grad students turned Internet search engine project into popular Web portal. Went public 1996. Strong revenue growth pushing stock to pre-Internet-bubble prices. Yang: Taiwanese immigrant, arrived California at age 10. Filo: directs technical end of operations. Pair remain company’s public faces; business run by former Warner Bros. boss Terry Semel.

name: Billionaires
bio: With mother Ingeburg, his four siblings Daniela, Günter, Joachim and Wolfgang (see all), inherited fortune from his late father, coffee baron Max Herz. Helped push out two of his siblings in a drawn-out family feud. Now controls a 34% stake in $4.5 billion (sales) Tchibo Holding, makers of a coffee brand that is as well known in Germany as Maxwell House is in the U.S. The group also has a 50% stake in Beiersdorf AG, makers of Nivea skin care products. Family troubles continue to percolate. Another brother, Joachim, is threatening to sue over alleged improprieties in the estimated $5 billion buyout of two other siblings.

name: Billionaires
bio: With younger brother Ronald (see), sons of beauty queen Estée Lauder, who started selling face creams in 1946 with help of chemist uncle and kitchen sink. Now Estée cosmetics empire: hair and skin care products, fragrances, makeup sold in more than 130 countries. Latest product line: costly creams using ocean ingredients. Chairman since 1995; son William chief executive. Trustee of U. of Pennsylvania, Whitney Museum, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital.

name: Billionaires
bio: His New Regency's latest blockbuster, Mr. and Mrs. Smith, generated nearly $500 million in worldwide box office receipts and, of course, spawned Hollywood's It-couple du jour, Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie. (Pitt bunked at Milchan's Malibu home following the split from Jennifer Aniston.) Milchan's own background is the stuff of movies. A former biochemistry student and soccer player, Milchan successfully transformed his family's fledgling fertilizer company into a $125 million chemicals business. Parlayed that into a role procuring arms for Israel, which he coyly discussed in a 60 Minutes interview in 2000. (Milchan denies he was an arms dealer but admits to acting as an intermediary between the country and defense contractors like Raytheon.) Later began bankrolling films for directors Sergio Leone and Martin Scorsese in the early 1980s, before going on to produce such movies as The War of the Roses, JFK and Fight Club. Massive art collections decorate his seven homes, including works by Basquiat, Picasso and Monet, but the most coveted space goes to paintings by his daughter, artist Elinor Milchan.

name: Billionaires
bio: The onetime talent agent for MCA runs Univision, country’s largest Spanish TV network. Also big player in Spanish radio, following $3.5 billion purchase of Hispanic Broadcasting in 2003. With partners bought Univision in 1992 for $550 million. Press-shy Perenchio made headlines in February over reports that he&#39s contemplating a sale of Univision.

name: Billionaires
bio: Built his London-listed Vedanta Resources by acquiring state-owned mining and metal assets in India where main operations are located. Also owns copper mines in Zambia and Australia. Has a $3 billion expansion underway. Promised to donate $1 billion to a new university , modeled after Harvard, over two years.

name: Billionaires
bio: Boosted by higher metals prices and overseas sales, Bailleres' Industrias Penoles continues to be a dominant player in the Mexican mining sector. Grupo BAL, his family's holding company, includes a diverse group of private and public companies ranging from a bank (Grupo Nacional Provincial) to a high-end department store (Palacio de Hierro).

name: Billionaires
bio: Identical twin brothers have had a busy year consolidating their vast retail, publishing and real estate empire. First sold off Littlewoods stores and merged the remaining mail order business with their Gus group. Then unloaded storied Scotsman Publications to Johnston Press Plc. to focus on Conrad Black's Telegraph Group, which they bought for $1.2 billion. The ever sensitive brothers brought a criminal libel action in France against the Times of London for a November 2004 article they say maligned them; the trial is expected to start this year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Irrepressible Branson boldly announced several new ventures this year: he&#39s starting a mobile phone venture in China, moving into bioethanol refining and publishing comic books. That&#39s on top of ongoing initiatives to launch space flights and a U.S. airline. To fund the new activities Branson has been trying to generate cash: he is in the middle of selling part of Virgin Mobile UK to cable operator NTL and taking equity in a combined entity; he did a similar deal with short-haul carrier Virgin Express. His Australian endeavor, the airline Virgin Blue, is locked in a takeover battle. Last October Branson launched the “Branson School of Entrepreneurship at CIDA City Campus” in South Africa.

name: Billionaires
bio: His upscale U.K. properties continue to attract high-end tenants like Hugo Boss, Cartier and Richard Ward, the fashionable hair salon where a doorman hails taxis and feeds parking meters. The Saatchi Gallery has also leased space. A further boon to Cadogan's estate assets: a tribunal ruled in his favor in September, allowing him to revalue his leases in Cadogan and Chelsea Squares to reflect the rise in the discount rate.

name: Billionaires
bio: With mother Ingeburg, his four siblings Daniela, Günter, Joachim and Michael (see all), inherited fortune from his late father, coffee baron Max Herz. Sided with his brother Michael in the latter&#39s successful campaign to remove brother Günter and sister Daniela from the management of Tchibo Holding in 2003. Now holds 34% stake in $4.5 billion (sales) Tchibo Holding.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of the founder of privately held Danish toymaker Lego. Ran the company for 25 years before stepping down in 2004 after several years of losses; remains the sole owner. The world’s fourth largest toymaker is trying to turn itself around. Last July it sold its four Legoland amusement parks to the Blackstone Group for $456 million and for a 30% stake in the newly formed Merlin Entertainment group, which will take over the assets.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers&#39 $5 billion (assets) Essar group with interests in steel, shipping, telecom, construction, power and oil and gas is benefiting from India&#39s economic boom. Biggest asset: one-third stake in cellular operator Hutchison Essar worth $2 billion. Shashi’s sons Prashant & Anshuman work in the group; Ravi’s daughter Smiti publishes Time Out in Mumbai.

name: Billionaires
bio: Self-described “cartoon schlepper” made first fortune with popular kids show Mighty Morphin Power Rangers. Scored again with Fox Family Network, joint venture with Rupert Murdoch’s Fox television: netted $1.7 billion after sale to Disney in 2001. Latest bet: buying big stake in German broadcaster from bankrupt Kirch Media; stood to triple investment, but regulators shot down proposed $5.2 billion sale to German publisher Axel Springer. Now making a run at Bezeq, Israeli telecom.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hollywood director found Midas touch again last year with War of the Worlds, which grossed $583 million at the box office, but latest effort, Munich, received cooly by critics. Public offering of animation division of DreamWorks, the boutique studio he owns with fellow billionaires Jeffrey Katzenberg and David Geffen (see both), added more than $100 million to his portfolio. Movie buff rejected by top film schools, got start as TV director for Universal. First movie, Duel, aired on TV, third movie, Jaws, launched a litany of blockbusters: Raiders of the Lost Ark, E.T., Jurassic Park, Saving Private Ryan. Latest

name: Billionaires
bio: The younger Bronfman brother is no longer showing the sharp elbows he used in 2002 to push Jean-Marie Messier out of Vivendi (in which his family had acquired a stake after selling family's crown jewel Seagram's in 2002). Now holds only minor position in the French media conglomerate. Owns big stake in Koor Industries, an Israeli holding company with investments in chemicals, telecom and defense electronics. Lately Charles is focusing on Jewish charities. Helped found Birthright Israel, which sends Jewish youths from North America on educational tours of Israel. Through his foundation underwrites New York Jewish Music and Heritage Festival. Last year Bronfman became the first non-Israeli to light the torch at Mount Herzl during the opening of Israeli Independence Day. In January his wife, Andrea, was tragically killed; a taxi hit her while she was walking the Bronfman's dog near their New York City apartment.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former supermarket manager developed shopping centers in Iowa with late brother Martin beginning in 1954. Took General Growth Properties public in 1993. Relocated to Chicago. Still on the move: paid $12.6 billion for storied Baltimore developer Rouse in 2004. Remains chairman, but son John oversees company’s 200 million square feet of mall space.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns more than 50% of Caltagirone SpA, an industrial holding company with cement, real estate and media interests. Subsidiary Caltagirone Editore controls Italy&#39s leading free daily newspaper, Leggo, as well as the Internet portal Caltanet. Dubbed “Franco the Taciturn” by media trying to figure out what he&#39s going to do next; keeps his cards close to his chest. Son Francesco Jr. is chairman of Caltagirone&#39s cement subsidiary Cementir. Also personally holds a stake in Acea SpA, Italy&#39s water-and-energy provider.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turned his father’s dust removal business into thermal engineering firm GEA. In 1999 sold his stake to MG Technologies in exchange for $1 billion in cash and a 21% stake in the combined group. Settled in Switzerland where he runs Luserve AG, a financial consulting firm. Married, with six children, he has a foundation that supports projects in Third World countries and reportedly owns a luxury resort, Fregate Island, in the Seychelles.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of five children of slain Lebanese prime minister Rafik (see Bahaa, Saad, Fahd and Hind) to qualify for the billionaire ranks. Fills role of family's tech geek. Cut his teeth within the engineering ranks of the recently privatized satellite consortium, Intelsat, as well as at a Hariri-controlled South African wireless carrier.  Then started closely held identity management software firm Epok; signed Dubai International Airport as a customer in 2004.

name: Billionaires
bio: Youngest son of Rafik Hariri; four brothers, Bahaa, Saad, and Ayman, sister Hind and mother Nazek, are all also billionaires (see all). Sits on board of Beirut's  Future Television Network, a terrestrial and satellite TV network covering the Middle East region, founded by his father in 1992. Lives close to his mother, Nazek, in Paris and runs a design studio for furnishings and other wares.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heir to steel-and-coke fortune steered family firm into real estate, venture capital. Early backer of Kleiner Perkins, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, co-owner of downtown Pittsburgh’s PPG Place. Now developing golf-based luxury resort and residential properties. Stepped down as chairman of the Hillman Company in 2004. Recently donated $20 million to cancer research, $10 million to Children’s Hospital of Pittsburgh.

name: Billionaires
bio: Husband, Bronson Ingram, inherited father’s oil-and-barge empire in 1963 with brother. Expanded with distribution business: books, computers, videotapes. Started computer wholesale distributor Ingram Micro. Martha became director of public affairs in 1979, chairman of holding company after Bronson’s death in 1995. Parceled out divisions to children: Ingram Entertainment (nation’s largest distributor of DVD hardware and software) to son David; Ingram Book Group (distributor of books, audiotapes to retailers and libraries) to son John; Orrin runs Ingram Marine boat division (4,000 barges, hundreds of towboats along major rivers, intercoastal waterways). Martha also board member of Weyerhaeuser and AmSouth Bancorp; pillar of Nashville society.

name: Billionaires
bio: A carpenter by trade, Jove opened his own business in 1980 and developed it into one of Spain's leading property companies, $830 (sales) Fadesa Inmobiliaria which he took public in April 2004. Fadesa continues to expand in Morocco with a residential, tourism and commercial center in Tangier; Jove has received numerous awards from the King of Morocco for his contribution to the growth of the country's tourism industry.  Also has interests in real estate companies in France and Poland. Hobbies: collects art from the Spanish province of Galicia and enjoys woodworking.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads Kazakhmys, the world's tenth-largest copper producer. Has 16 copper mines across Kazakhstan. Group had a wildly successful London offering in October 2005. In less than two months Kazakhmys joined the FTSE 100 index of Britain's biggest companies. A descendent of Koreans forced by Stalin to move to Kazakhstan, Kim joined Kazakhmys during Khazakstan's early 1990s privatization and eventually raised his stake to about 45% today.

name: Billionaires
bio: With older brother Leonard (see), sons of beauty queen Estée Lauder, who started selling face creams in 1946 with help of chemist uncle and kitchen sink. Now Estée cosmetics empire: hair and skin care products, fragrances, makeup sold in more than 130 countries. Latest product line: costly creams using ocean ingredients. International investor, owns big stake in Central European Media, Israeli TV. Served as ambassador to Austria under Reagan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a respected Soviet physicist, Melnichenko studied physics at prestigious Moscow State University. Dropped out in 1991 and with some schoolmates, sold computers and established a chain of currency-exchange booths; in 1993 founded MDM Bank, which would later handle the accounts of oil tycoon Roman Abramovich and other businessmen. In 2000, teamed up with metals trader Sergei Popov and began accumulating an industrial empire that now includes chemicals, coal mines, steel mills and a 6% stake in Russia's electric monopoly. Melnichenko is no longer an eligible  bachelor; in September 2005 he married Serbian model Alexandra Kokotovich in a lavish ceremony featuring performances by Whitney Houston and Christina Aguilera.

name: Billionaires
bio: Met partner Henry Samueli at TRW. Started designing high-speed telecom chips from Nicholas’ spare bedroom. Took public as Broadcom 1998. Nicholas: brawny CEO quit unexpectedly in 2003 to spend time with family. Supports education, performing arts, humanities, science through the Nicholas Foundation. Samueli: Broadcom chairman, chief of technology. UCLA grad funded school’s new Henry Samueli School of Engineering & Applied Sciences.

name: Billionaires
bio: Studied to be an electrical engineer but left to go into business. Through the 1990s made his way through the murky world of metals and oil trading in the Urals and Siberia. As a client of MDM Bank, got to know the bank's owner, Andrei Melnichenko. After the collapse of the ruble in 1998, convinced Melnichenko to buy Russian steel mills, chemical companies and coal mines on the cheap. Eventually became co-owner of MDM and chairman. MDM was recentlyCK dissolved into several holdings; Popov sits on the boards of the coal company SUEK, fertilizer producer EuroChem and MDM-Bank.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of German bird salesman looking to restore family’s reputation after son Edward, head of Canary Capital hedge fund, set off 2003 mutual fund scandal with improper market-timing trading scheme. Ed cooperated with authorities, paid $40 million fine. Leonard got start running father’s Hartz pet supply business, made industry leader. Sold 85% of company for $208 million in 2000. Son Emanuel manages family’s vast real estate empire: 35 million square feet of commercial space in New Jersey, New York City’s posh Soho Grand and Tribeca Grand hotels.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ohio shopkeeper’s son dropped out of law school, started women’s sportswear store in 1963 with loan from aunt. Expanded, took “Leslie’s” public 1969. Today Limited Brands: Victoria’s Secret, Express, Limited Too, upscale Henri Bendel. Also Bath & Body Works, C.O. Bigelow. Major art collector. Supports Jewish studies causes via Wexner Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Hired as Esprit's primary sourcing agent in 1971. Later bought rights to the
clothing brand in Europe and Asia; listed Esprit Far East on Hong Kong stock
exchange in 1993. Ying stepped down as chief executive in 2003; remains
chairman. Has proclaimed firm needs to buy up competitors or expand
aggressively in big cities to maintain massive growth. Tycoon has been
steadily selling off stake over the past few years, pocketing almost $1
billion along the way; still holds 16% of Esprit.

name: Billionaires
bio: Secretive Chen delisted his flagship company, Nan Fung Textiles, in 1989; invested in real estate. Bought up massive portfolio of luxury properties, residential buildings, plus a stake in Singapore billionaire Ng Teng Fong's Sino Land. Booming Hong Kong market making a roaring recovery after the late 1990s downturn and 2003 SARS scare;  portfolio up 30% in value in past 12 months. Committed Buddhist.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs eponymous Godrej Group, a $1.3 billion (sales)consumer products conglomerate that makes soaps, home appliances, hair dyes and office furniture. Family's biggest asset is its large landholdings in Mumbai. With rising real estate prices, the value is up by a third since last year.

name: Billionaires
bio:
No fairy godmother for this former chambermaid. Created own Cinderella story marrying her boss, Johnson & Johnson heir John Seward Johnson (d. 1983). Polish immigrant inherited private golf club, 36 million J&J shares. Art collector recently sold world’s most expensive piece of furniture: Badminton Cabinet. “Basia” purchased piece for $15.1 million in 1990; sold to Prince 
Hans-Adam II of Liechtenstein for $36.7 million in December.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, James, joined Wall Street specialist firm in 1945; became Spear, Leeds & Kellogg 1954, nation’s largest specialist on the New York Stock Exchange. Peter joined as director 1973; made money on the side investing in Alex. Brown, National Discount Brokers. Sold Spear, Leeds & Kellogg to Goldman Sachs in 2000 for $5.5 billion. Other stakes in laser imaging (Presstek), paper (Mercer International), MFC Bancorp.

name: Billionaires
bio: With husband Stan, Ann inherited big Wal-Mart stake from father, James (Bud) Walton (d. 1995), who cofounded retail chain with brother Sam. Stan made money as a real estate developer, including shopping centers anchored by Wal-Mart stores. Also owns more than 1 million acres of ranch land. Sports fanatic owns stakes in pro football’s St. Louis Rams, basketball’s Denver Nuggets, hockey’s Colorado Avalanche.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cuts and polishes more diamonds than anyone else in the world. Last year opened one of the largest diamond-polishing plants in Africa, in Angola, second only to his plant in Namibia. Partnered with retailer H. Stern to open 50 jewelry stores in Russia and the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS). In negotiations to buy Israeli soccer team Hapoel Tel Aviv. His empire also includes a majority holding in the $1.6 billion (market cap) Africa Israel Investments, which owns swimsuit maker Gottex, 1,700 Fina gas stations in the southwestern United States and a stake in Israel's first toll road. Has become the largest private Israeli investor in Las Vegas, where he plans to open a hotel and mall. Born in Uzbekistan, his Lubavitcher-Jewish family fled to Israel in 1971. Made his name undercutting De Beers diamond cartel, striking his own deals with diamond-producing countries like Russia and Angola. A devout Jew, donates at least $30 million each year to the Chabad movement, which seeks to return lost Jews to the flock.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Onsi Sawiris (see), made first foray into Europe telecom sector with his group’s $12 billion purchase last year of a controlling stake in Italian mobile and fixed-line phone operator Wind Telecommunicazioni. Facing pressure from Iraqi public for poor service record of Iraqna, his mobile phone subsidiary in war-torn Iraq. Argued that security problems there should prompt government to extend current licenses by 3 to 5 years. Bought stake in Hutchison Whampoa for $1.3 billion, causing concerns among some Israelis who didn’t like the idea of Arabs holding a stake in Hutchison’s Israeli cellular carrier, Partner Communications.

name: Billionaires
bio: Schoolteacher’s son and erstwhile bank examiner made big bucks betting on drugstore in 1961; built into 100-store chain before selling to Eckerd for $50 million 12 years later. Through publicly traded Valhi, invests in metals, titanium, waste management. Won big with oil and gas investments via Boone Pickens’ (see) investment fund. Friend of Oprah, supports cancer care, research at the U. of Texas Southwestern Medical Center.

name: Billionaires
bio: Degree from MIT; taught at Harvard. Worked as code breaker for Department of Defense during Vietnam. Founded Renaissance Technologies hedge fund firm 1982. Flagship Medallion fund averaging 34% annual returns since 1988. Most expensive fees in the business: 44% of profits, 5% of assets. Hires Ph.D.s instead of M.B.A.s; employees use computer modeling to find market inefficiencies. Launching fund for institutional investors that could handle $100 billion. Chairs Math for America; group donated $25 million last year to train 180 New York City math teachers.

name: Billionaires
bio: What, me worry? That seems to be the attitude coming from The Donald. Despite talk about real estate bubble bursting, Trump has his fingers in new projects going up in just about every major market across the country: Developing residential towers with Phil Ruffin (see) in Las Vegas; erecting 92-story skyscraper in Chicago; building a community of $10 million mansions in Palos Verdes, Calif. Owns various stakes in nearly 18 million square feet of residential, commercial, gambling space. With partners, recently sold big chunk vacant land, three rental properties for $1.8 billion; now suing partners over terms. Better relations with his Atlantic City partners after reorganizing flagging casino properties. Avid golfer owns top-rated tracts in New Jersey, Florida, California.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owner of Oskol Steel Mill, the Ural Steel industrial complex, and the Lebedinsky Iron Ore Mining and Processing Facility has said his first love was his stock, or shares, in his metals plants. In the beginning of 2005 Usmanov and his partner Vasiliy Anisimov acquired Mikhailovsky GOK (an ore mining and processing plant). In Spring 2005 their attempt to annex Russia's largest ferrous metals producer, Magnitogorsky metallurgical complex, failed, even after Usmanov and Anisimov blocked raw-materials delivery to Magnitogorsky. Now the partners say they will acquire enterprises in Kazakhstan and Ukraine.

name: Billionaires
bio: With father Stephen, third- and fourth-generation heads of worldwide engineering giant that built Hoover Dam and Channel Tunnel. Now active from Iceland to Australia: prominent projects include Iraqi infrastructure, China’s largest petrochemical plant, Boston’s Big Dig, Washington State’s Tacoma Narrows Bridge. Stephen president 1960–90. Riley now chairman, CEO.

name: Billionaires
bio: With son Riley, third- and fourth-generation heads of worldwide engineering giant that built Hoover Dam and Channel Tunnel. Now active from Iceland to Australia: prominent projects include Iraqi infrastructure, China’s largest petrochemical plant, Boston’s Big Dig, Washington State’s Tacoma Narrows Bridge. Stephen president 1960–90. Riley now chairman, CEO.

name: Billionaires
bio: Together with siblings Luciano, Giuliana and Gilberto (see all), formed Benetton Group in 1965. Now deputy chairman of the $2 billion (sales) clothing company, which sells its United Colors of Benetton and Sisley brands at 5,000 stores in 120 countries. Also vice president of family's Edizione Holding, which holds stakes as varied as land in Argentina and Autogrill SpA restaurants along highways and at airports.

name: Billionaires
bio: This sports enthusiast and member of Italian Benetton clan promotes Benetton's sponsorships of rugby, basketball and volleyball. Through Fondazione Benetton, he created La Ghirada, an indoor-and-outdoor sports complex in Treviso, Italy, complete with beach volleyball, golf and swimming. Chairs Edizione, the Benetton family holding company, which owns United Colors of Benetton clothing line, big stake in Autogrill (caterer and retail operator along highways and at airports). Deputy chairman of another Edizione holding, Olimpia, which has big stake in Telecom Italia. Shares the fortune with siblings Carlo, Giuliana and Luciano (see all).

name: Billionaires
bio: Board member of Benetton Group, apparel company she cofounded with her three brothers, Carlo, Gilberto and Luciano, in 1965 (see all). Its brands include United Colors of Benetton and Sisley. Also a director of the family's Edizione Holding, which has interests in Telecom Italia and Autogrill SpA, a chain of roadside and airport restaurants in Italy and abroad. Autogrill first brought Burger King to Italy in 1999 through a franchise agreement; the United States now accounts for one-half of the company's $4.3 billion in revenue. Operates in 60 U.S. airports, including 19 of the largest in terms of passenger traffic.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ran Benetton Group, which he founded with siblings Carlo, Gilberto and Giuliana (see all), for 40 years. Remains chairman. Most famous for clothing; Benetton produces 110 million garments a year through the United Colors of Benetton, Sisley, Playlife and Killer Loop brands. With his siblings also owns Autostrade, the most extensive toll-highway network in Europe, and Autogrill restaurants, which serve 720 million customers each year on highways and in airports in 15 countries. Also owns extensive land in Argentina. Son Alessandro is now Deputy Chairman at Benetton.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wharton grad started trading options at Gruntal & Co. 1978; made $8,000 profit on first day. Founded hedge fund SAC Capital with $20 million 1992. Today manages more than $6 billion in assets; average annual return of 40%. Firm’s 40-odd portfolios believed to account for as much as 3% of NYSE’s daily volume. Highly secretive investor commands one of the highest performance fees in the business: 50% of the profits if certain benchmarks met. Avid art enthusiast has spent more than $300 million since 2000 building collection: Warhol, Pollock, Degas. On boards of Robin Hood Foundation, Michael J. Fox Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heir to the Campbell Soup fortune once tried unsuccessfully to pressure Wyoming legislators to legalize game ranching for native and exotic life. Not much has been heard from him since he fled to Ireland in 1994 to avoid U.S. taxes. Sold his Campbell stake in 1996.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of archetypal Texas oilman H.L. Hunt (d. 1974), whose oil empire started from poker winnings. Inherited most of Hunt Oil: older branch of the family took a big hit in silver market, but Ray stuck with oil, scored big with deal in Yemen. Moving into natural gas in Peru. Well connected in Beltway thanks to fundraising for Bush, seat on Halliburton board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dropped out of Harvard Ph.D. program after fit of writer’s block. Used $3,000 MasterCard line to trade soybeans at age 31. Made $40,000, didn’t hedge; lost $23,000 hours later. Founded hedge fund group Caxton Associates 1983. Juilliard chairman, opera enthusiast owns Steinway grand piano, plays every night at midnight: “A great piece of music can take you to a place that is pretty powerful and positive.” Devout Republican chairs American Enterprise Institute think tank, funds Manhattan Institute, New York Sun newspaper.

name: Billionaires
bio: With first cousin George Roberts (see), partnered with fellow Bear Stearns mentor Jerome Kohlberg (see) to form leveraged buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts 1976. Used junk bonds to buy underperforming companies, reworked balance sheets, sold for profit. Kohlberg exited in 1987. “Barbarians at the gate” best known for $25 billion RJR Nabisco buyout 1989. Other high-profile deals: Safeway, Primedia, Duracell. Last July bought Toys “R” Us for $6.6 billion with Bain Capital and Steven Roth’s (see) Vornado Realty; acquired SunGard Data Systems for $10.6 billion with Blackstone Group. Gregarious New York socialite, big donor to Metropolitan Museum; wife, Marie-Josée, former head of poverty-fighting Robin Hood Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mikhelson's father headed the largest pipeline construction trust in the U.S.S.R. From that, Mikhelson has managed to build gas company OAO Novatek working on large deposits in Yamal-Nenets Region (northwestern Siberia). The state-owned monopolist Gazprom generally suppresses the rivalry but tolerates Novatek's presence on the market. Mikhelson has proved to be convenient for Gazprom, since he supplies Russian regions with gas at local prices, allowing the gas giant to keep more reserves on hand for lucrative export markets. Novatek listed its Global Depositary Receipts on the London Stock Exchange in July 2005.

name: Billionaires
bio: Granddaughter of company founder Mario Prada runs the luxury-clothing company with husband Patrizio Bertelli. She is lead designer; he is chief executive. Their fiery relationship fuels interesting designs, most recently a Prada menswear show featuring urban-warrior-inspired fashion. Recently hired over-40 actress Kim Basinger as new face of sister brand Miu Miu (Miuccia's nickname). While her designer counterparts Karl Lagerfeld (Chanel, Fendi) and Stella McCartney (her own brand) designed affordable collections for H&M, Prada contends she will not follow suit. In February Prada agreed to sell lagging Jil Sander brand to U.K. private equity firm Change Capital Partners for reported $65 million.
title: Owner, Fashion Designer

name: Billionaires
bio: With first cousin Henry Kravis (see), partnered with fellow Bear Stearns mentor Jerome Kohlberg (see) to form leveraged buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts 1976. Used junk bonds to buy underperforming companies, reworked balance sheets, sold for profit. Kohlberg exited in 1987. “Barbarians at the gate” best known for $25 billion RJR Nabisco buyout 1989. Other high-profile deals: Safeway, Primedia, Duracell. Last July bought Toys “R” Us for $6.6 billion with Bain Capital and Steven Roth’s (see) Vornado Realty; acquired SunGard Data Systems for $10.6 billion with Blackstone Group. Soft-spoken, spends after-work hours on the driving range at Stanford.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of visionary businessman John D. Rockefeller who turned $4,000 in oil refining into Standard Oil, oil-and-gas behemoth that fueled the American industrial revolution. Company broken up in landmark antitrust case 1911. Father invested in real estate. David became banker, diplomat, pillar of New York society. Last year celebrated 90th birthday with sumptuous gala at Manhattan’s Museum of Modern Art. Marked the occasion by giving $100 million to both MoMA and Rockefeller University. “With opportunity, comes responsibility.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Fourth-generation banker Schroder continues as a director of his family's financial services company, Schroders Plc., which celebrated its 200th anniversary in 2004. Schroders manages $186 billion on behalf of clients in 26 countries. Family has 47% stake. Profits (before tax) in 2004 were up 190% under the continued turnaround of chief Michael Dobson.  Schroder himself flies planes and breeds "middle white" pigs at his estate in Islay, Scotland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of dry-goods-store owner studied at Yale with President George W. Bush; founded ballet society to meet girls. Harvard M.B.A., then managing director at Lehman 1978 at age 31. Cofounded buyout firm Blackstone Group 1985 with $400,000, with partner Peter G. Peterson. Led bankruptcy restructurings of Enron and Global Crossing. Appointed chair of Kennedy Center in Washington, D.C., immediately donated $10 million in 2004. Splits time between $30 million Manhattan duplex, estates in the Hamptons, Palm Beach.

name: Billionaires
bio: High school graduate and self-made industrialist made fortune in construction (Washington Group International), mining (copper in Butte, Mont.) and transportation (1,000-mile-long Montana Rail Link). Owns largest tug and barge company in Canada; investor in Seaspan Corporation, line of 23 container ships profiting from China trade.

name: Billionaires
