bio: Met up with Austrian Dietrich Mateschitz two decades ago and decided to start an energy drink company with him. He provided the beverage formula and his partner contributed the marketing flair. The result: $2.5 billion (sales) Red Bull, in which they each own 49%. Yoovidhya also owns 60% of a private Thai hospital chain and $133 million (sales) TC Pharmaceuticals, a producer of energy drinks in Thailand. Son Chalerm, who holds the remaining 2% stake in Red Bull, owns one of Asia’s leading wine producers, Siam Winery, whose labels include Monsoon Valley and Sabai, a herb and wine drink.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ex-record-label tycoon sold his Zomba Recordings , onetime label for Britney Spears, Backstreet Boys and 'N Sync, to BMG for $2.7 billion in 2002. He now lives quietly in the Cayman Islands. He has reportedly granted one interview in his life. Raised in a middle-class neighborhood in Johannesburg, Calder started out playing bass guitar in local bands and is supposed to have kept tax manuals as bedside reading.

name: Billionaires
bio: Youngest of four brothers, Dhanin was just 25 when he took over the family's small seed shop. Transformed it into one of the world's largest suppliers of animal feed.   Then successfully branched into retail and telecom and other businesses. The group uses a lotus flower as its Buddhist symbol of commitment, effort and accomplishment. In spare time, enjoys breeding Thai chickens; allows cockfights but only with chickens wearing small gloves to prevent serious injuries.

name: Billionaires
bio: With his father, opened a discount supermarket WHERETK in the late 1970s. Later partnered with Swedish retailer ICA Group and supermarket giant Ahold. In 2004 exercised option to sell his remaining 20% stake in the venture, forcing Ahold to pony up $1 billion. Has been boosting his stake in consumer-goods company Orkla, on whose board he sits. Also invests in real estate and local companies through his Canica group. Reportedly owns an island in the Caribbean and one of the biggest sailboats in Europe.

name: Billionaires
bio: Matriarch chairs privately-owned Bennett, Coleman & Co, India's biggest media house. Family acquired the company from a British group. Now Sons Samir and Vineet run the show. Their flagship publication, the Times of India, is the world's largest selling English daily newspaper, selling more than 3 million copies. Group recently listed Entertainment Network India, a radio broadcasting arm and launched Times Now, a television news channel, in a joint venture with Reuters. Jain herself has introduced columns on spirituality in the group's newspapers; also oversees the Times Foundation, the group's philanthropic arm.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Enron president wisely left firm in 1996, uncomfortable with “asset-light” strategy. Bought Enron pipeline operations with pal William Morgan. Today controls 38,000-mile pipe network. Last year bought Canadian pipeline company Terasen for $5.6 billion. Gave Kinder Morgan access to fast-growing oil sands developments where production expected to double over next decade. Pays himself $1 a year, but dividends from limited partnership more than enough to support fly-fishing hobby.

name: Billionaires
bio: His $3 billion (sales) tour outfit Globus & Cosmos was founded in 1928 by father, Antonio, with a single boat that ferried tourists around Lake Lugano. President Sergio has been with the company for 50 years. Loves expensive toys: has a helicopter, a yacht (Lady Marina) and a $600,000 Mercedes Maybach. Son Fabio is chief executive of Monarch Travel, the family's no-frills airline. Son Paolo, who was CEO of Globus' American arm, Group Voyagers, committed suicide two years ago at age 34.

name: Billionaires
bio: With a Thai business partner, created Red Bull energy drink and marketed it to young people using cheeky advertising and extreme sports sponsorships. A Taurus (the zodiac sign of the bull), Mateschitz owns 49% of the $2.5 billion (sales) company. While he is spending less time these days on the company’s daily operations, he is still involved in building its new Austrian headquarters with its two volcano-shaped roofs. Also keeps busy with his many other interests including a new construction company; a Formula 1 team; a football club; and Hangar-7, the event center located on the grounds of Salzburg airport that houses his historic aircraft collection, the Flying Bulls. He’s also developing a luxury resort on Laucala, an island in Fiji that he owns.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Greek immigrants studied petroleum engineering at Texas A&M, captain of tennis team. Founded Mitchell Energy & Development in 1946, struck big in north Texas gas fields. Sold to Devon Energy in 2001 for $3.5 billion. Nature enthusiast built Woodlands residential community 1974, sold 1997. Owns Bald Head Island in North Carolina, hotels in Galveston. Funded $10 million National Academies study on sustainable development. Donates to University of Texas Medical Center for Alzheimer’s research; Texas A&M telescope project.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father Klaus died last April making Axel the sole owner of candy company Storck GmbH, which makes Werther's Original, Merci, Riesen, Toffifee and nimm2. He is the fourth generation of Oberwellands to run the now estimated $1.5 billion (sales) group. The company established the Stork Foundation in 1992 to preserve the endangered stork population in Germany.

name: Billionaires
bio: Met partner Henry Nicholas at TRW. Started designing high-speed telecom chips from Nicholas’ spare bedroom. Took public as Broadcom 1998. Nicholas: brawny CEO quit unexpectedly in 2003 to spend time with family. Supports education, performing arts, humanities, science through the Nicholas Foundation. Samueli: Broadcom chairman, chief of technology. UCLA grad funded school’s new Henry Samueli School of Engineering & Applied Sciences.

name: Billionaires
bio: Canada's cheese mogul started Saputo in Montreal in 1954 with parents Giuseppe and Maria. Delivered mozzarella by bicycle in the early days. Snapped up U.S. and Canadian dairies in the 1980s as pizza's growing popularity boosted demand. In 2003 expanded into Argentina with $51 million purchase of Molfino Hermanos dairy processor. Also controls the 47-story Place Victoria, home of the Montreal Stock Exchange.

name: Billionaires
bio: A commerce graduate, he built Sun Pharmaceutical Industries into India's fifth-largest drugmaker partly by making timely acquisitions. Recently paid $23 million for the manufacturing operations of Able Labs, a generics company in New Jersey. Shanghvi is spinning off and listing part of Sun's drug discovery research division.

name: Billionaires
bio: Budapest-born immigrant escaped Soviet occupation with family to Sweden, then to New York 1958. Moved to LA, studied economics at UCLA. Plane enthusiast ran own aircraft brokering, consulting business in college. With $150,000 savings, $1.7 million bank loan, started International Lease Finance with fellow Hungarians Louis and Leslie Gonda (see both). Business took off as airlines lined up for cheap, low-risk leases; became one of world’s largest aircraft lessors. Sold to AIG in 1990. Recently gave $66 million to the Steven Udvar-Hazy Center of the National Air & Space Museum at the Smithsonian Institute.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wee is chairman of United Overseas Bank (UOB), one of the three big local banks in Singapore. In the last few years, has had to divest non-bank holdings as part of new Singapore government regulations on banks. Heads the Singapore Federation of Chinese Clan Associations, which looks to promote the better use of Chinese language by local Singaporeans. Son Wee Ee Cheong is bank's deputy chairman and president, and heir apparent.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Iscar, one of the world&#39s largest (by sales) manufacturers of carbide industrial-cutting tools, which are used by carmakers like GM and Ford. Son Eitan, who along with his wife owns Israel&#39s largest horse-breeding stud farm, is Iscar&#39s president. Stef Wertheimer also seeds high-tech Israeli startups through four industrial parks. Recently built a windmill at the flagship Tefen industrial park. After fleeing Nazi Germany the grade school dropout joined the Palmach, the elite strike force of the Haganah (the pre-state defense organization). A former Israeli parliament member, he is today an ardent supporter of joint Israeli-Palestinian businesses. In 2002 he testified before Congress about his idea for a “new Marshall Plan” that advocates U.S. funding to revitalize the Middle East, a plan he still champions in speeches across the world.

name: Billionaires
bio: Battle of the search engines continues. After dropping Google last year, Yahoo revamped its own engine; now claims to scour more than 20 billion Web pages, images. Met partner David Filo at Stanford. As grad students turned Internet search engine project into popular Web portal. Went public 1996. Strong revenue growth pushing stock to pre-Internet-bubble prices. Yang: Taiwanese immigrant, arrived California at age 10. Filo: directs technical end of operations. Pair remain company’s public faces; business run by former Warner Bros. boss Terry Semel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Parents escaped Poland weeks before Nazi invasion. Sam born in Chicago 4 months after family’s arrival in America. With fraternity brother Robert Lurie (d. 1990) bought up cheap real estate throughout U.S. from distressed owners, kept buying when values recovered and boomed. Lately a seller, but jeans-wearing businessman still controls 123 million square feet of office space, 198,000 apartments. “I’ve always said that I am worth $29.53.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Along with Saudi Arabia's richest man, Prince Alwaleed, is one of the two largest private shareholders in the country's food conglomerate, Savola Group. Its shares are up more than 40% over the past year. Also majority owner of Saudi Construction Company founded in the early 1970s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Powerful wife of Moscow Mayor Yuri Luzhkov, started out as a factory worker, then studied at the Moscow Institute of Management. Met Luzhkov in 1987 when they were both serving on the Mosgorispolcom, a Soviet-era municipal commission. Founded Inteko in 1991. After Luzhkov became mayor, Inteko company became the largest construction firm in the city, mostly building prefab housing. But Luzhkov's term is ending in 2007; Baturina isn't likely to get construction contracts so easily then, so she's cashing out from mass construction business. Last year Inteko sold its cement works and DSK-3, a producer of prefab buildings, for $1.1 billion. Baturina wisely invested some of that cash in Gazprom and Sberbank. Plans invest the rest in development of more expensive homes, hotels and office centers; has already obtained the sites.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs $2.4 billion (sales) Hubert Burda Media Holding, publisher of such well-known German magazines as Focus, Bunte and Freundin. A well-known philanthropist, he supports the Bambi prize (Germany’s academy awards) and the Hermann-Lenz Prize for German literature. He is married to well-known German actress Maria Furtwängler.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former bag boy founded investment company Yucaipa 1986; made fortune with leveraged buyouts of supermarket chains Fred Meyer, Jurgensen’s, Ralph’s. Dealmaking ever since. Recent transactions: invested $100 million in Sean (P. Diddy) Combs’ Sean John clothing line; sold majority stake in food supplier Golden State Foods to Wetterau Associates, of St. Louis, for $110 million. Also big stake in Pathmark grocery stores. Longtime Democratic fundraiser a close friend of Bill Clinton; former President calls Burkle’s 757 private jet “Ron Air.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Became known to the public only in June 2005, when steel giant Evraz Group's GDRs were sold on London Stock Exchange; Frolov, who is responsible for all of Evraz' operations, turned out to have the second-largest stake in EvrazHolding. Graduated from the Moscow Institute of Physics & Technology in 1987. Prior to joining Evraz, worked as a research fellow at the I.V. Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Forced out of McCain Foods' day-to-day operations in the 1990s after a family feud; remains vice chairman and still has a one-third stake. Took over meat processor Maple Leaf Foods in 1995, where son Michael is chief. Lackluster 2005: Maple Leaf sales and profits flat for the year; stock off 12%. Donates to philanthropic causes like National Ballet School of Canada and the National Gallery of Canada.

name: Billionaires
bio: Affable investor got start managing Bass family’s $50 million portfolio in 1970; lost money first 2 years, better tidings buying large Disney stake in 1984. Left 2 years later, cofounded Columbia Hospital 1987; bought Thomas Frist’s (see) Hospital Corp. of America 1994. Recently shedding certain assets: “Natural resources and oil have been good to me, but the big money to be made in those sectors is all over.” Owns 7.5% of beleaguered telecom Global Crossing, chairs Crescent Real Estate Equities; REIT owns 75 office buildings in Houston, Dallas. Wife, Darla Moore, dealmaker in her own right, managing sizable assets since 1994; donated more than $70 million to U. of South Carolina’s business school.

name: Billionaires
bio: North Carolina native studied at UNC undergrad, then Harvard M.B.A. Saved failing Bank of North Carolina, started by father, before it merged with NCNB in 1982 (now Bank of America). Still owns 32 million BofA shares worth $1.4 billion. Other investments: drywall maker National Gypsum, C.D. Spangler Construction. Loves keeping business private: “People don’t read about your mistakes.” Unwinds by repairing grandfather clocks.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fifth wife and widow of Axel Springer, founder of $3 billion (sales) Axel Springer Verlag, one of Germany's leading publishing groups. She now owns 52% of the  company, which publishes over 150 papers, among them the leading German conservative daily Die Welt and Germany's largest daily tabloid, Bild Zeitung. Axel Springer publishes foreign language editions of Forbes in Poland and Russia. Germany's competition authorities recently dealt Springer Verlag a blow when they refused to approve its planned acquisition of ProSiebenSat.1, Germany's leading commercial TV broadcaster, from fellow billionaire Haim Saban. Active in various philanthropic organizations, Friede has received numerous awards for her efforts to rebuild German-Jewish relations.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Inherited real estate and shipping outfit Wheelock & Co. from father-in-law,
Sir Y.K. Pao. Left helm to launch failed bid to become Hong Kong's first
chief executive in 1997. Headed Hong Kong Trade Development Council until
2002, then returned to Wheelock. This year company bought Lane Crawford, one
of Asia's oldest luxury department stores; added 4 Hong Kong stores, another
in Shanghai. Once again heading the HKTDC; recently dispelled rumors he
would run for chief executive again in 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: Third-generation grocer giving gourmands reason to salivate. H.E. Butt supermarket chain offering free meals all year long as part of centennial anniversary celebration. Originally founded in 1905 by grandmother to support sick husband, 3 children in Kerrville, Tex. Today more than $10 billion in sales, 320 stores, including 19 Mexico locations. Large-scale Central Market stores cater to gourmet tastes. Shuns Coca-Cola, stocks wine, cheese, kosher cuisine instead. Wharton grad started bagging for family business at age 8. Became HEB president 1971; childless: family legacy ends with him.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a carpenter founded Sonae GSPS in 1959 as a producer of decorative laminates. Later diversified into supermarkets. The $8 billion (sales) company is now Portugal’s leading retailer and owner of Modelo Continente superstores and supermarkets. De Azevedo holds a 53% stake in the group, which also has interests in tourism, car parks, real estate, shopping centers, a radio station, a newspaper and a maker of wood panels. His children, sons Nuno and Paulo and daughter Claudia, all work in the organization.

name: Billionaires
bio: Two years after selling TV production giant Endemol, the brain behind global hit Big Brother returned in full creative force. Launched a new television channel, Talpa TV, to stunning success. Only months old, Talpa already claims 10% of the coveted youth market and has secured rights to screen the Dutch premier soccer league. Reality TV pioneer is now forging a new media revolution, with content that audiences can tap into from a variety of platforms, including television, the Internet, mobile phones and radio. The Media Midas has had some setbacks, though; shares of debt-ridden Sanctuary Group, the music management company behind Elton John and Iron Maiden, have tanked as the company struggles to stay in business. De Mol's 20% stake has plummeted with it.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief executive of Mediolanum SpA, life insurance and fund management company he founded in partnership with Silvio Berlusconi's Fininvest Group in 1982. Mediolanum companies provide investment advice, online banking, life insurance and real estate loans. Stock is up 50% since last April. Longtime business ally of Prime Minister Berlusconi, who is a Mediolanum shareholder. Serves on board of luxury-eyewear maker Safilo Group. Enjoys bicycling, owns a farm.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of oil baron J. Paul Getty Sr. (d. 1976) sold family’s Getty Oil to Texaco for $10 billion in 1986. Now committed composer: claims music helped him “dodge the curse” that inherited money often brings. Business mostly a diversion. More fun dabbling in Napa Valley, where he owns Squaw Valley resort and cult winery PlumpJack. Packages $170-a-bottle wine in screw caps, citing scientific evidence they’re better than cork. High-profile patron of the arts in California. Passionate baseball fan often seen at San Francisco Giants games.

name: Billionaires
bio: With fraternity brother founded Continental Cablevision 1963. Partner left 1981; Amos sold to US West in 1996 for $11 billion, kept large stake. Renamed MediaOne, sold to AT&T for $58 billion 3 years later. On board of private equity firm Quadrangle.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, James (Bud) Walton, and his brother, Sam Walton, ran a handful of small five-and-dime stores in Arkansas and Missouri; with Sam, Bud built the first Wal-Mart in Rogers, Ark. in 1962. Nancy inherited large Wal-Mart stake after Bud’s death in 1995. Established and serves as president of New York City’s Cedar Lake Ensemble, also Missouri’s Columbia Performing Arts Center: dance instruction school enrolls nearly 600 students per year. With husband, Bill, owns pro hockey’s St. Louis Blues. Big givers to Missouri-area hospitals, young women’s causes. Donated $25 million to U. of Missouri for new basketball arena named after daughter, Paige.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dropped out of school age 14, worked as a milk delivery boy for family dairy during Depression. Opened ice cream shop with 2 brothers and $1,200 in 1940, grew into United Dairy Farmers chain. Now run by brother Robert, today operates more than 200 stores. Acquired S&Ls 1959; diversified into insurance 1971. With sons owns 42% of American Financial Group. Co-owner of pro baseball’s Cincinnati Reds donates tickets to students, civic workers. Still no plans to retire. “My main hobby is working. I love what I do.”

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner Arthur Blank founded home improvement chain Home Depot 1978 after getting fired from Handy Dan Improvement Center. Revolutionized hardware stores by catering to do-it-yourselfers, professional contractors; stacked inventory to the ceilings. GOP backer donated $200 million to build public aquarium in hometown Atlanta.

name: Billionaires
bio: Helped then-husband Amancio Ortega make gowns and lingerie in their home. That business eventually became $6.7 billion (sales) Inditex, an apparel manufacturer that also owns Zara retail stores. Though the two divorced years ago, Mera still holds a 7% stake in the group. She also got $600 million in cash at the time of Inditex’s public offering, which she has invested in a variety of holdings such as a Spanish film production outfit, a marine fish farming group, a company that is looking for cancer treatment in compounds found in the sea and a maker of a fingerprinting identification system for newborns. Mera is also president of the Paideia Foundation, which helps people with physical and mental disabilities.
title: Investor, Philanthropist

name: Billionaires
bio: Repulsed by smelly feet, Moretti Polegato came up with an idea in 1994 to put tiny holes in shoe soles to release sweat. The concept turned into a fortune as his Geox grew to a $415 million (sales) company with 250 stores in 80 countries. Flagship Geox shop opened in December on New York's Madison Avenue; Geox sits across from Nike, the company that passed on Moretti Polegato's special shoes when he pitched it to management in the mid-1990s. Also designs his own eyeglasses. Owns two Lamborghinis and a Ferrari 360 Modena Spider, as well as five Arabian horses (one named Geox). Ran his family's prestigious Villa Sandi winery long before he got into the shoe business.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Steven (see), passed up father’s real estate business to start Equity Group Holdings 1979; bought small manufacturing companies (Chicago Pneumatic Tool, Western Pacific Industries, Ammco Tools). Acquired 25% stake in near-bankrupt real estate investment trust, combined with manufacturing units to create Danaher 1982 (named after favorite Montana trout stream).

name: Billionaires
bio: Along with his brothers (see also: Sulaiman Bin Abdul Al Raiji, Saleh Bin Abdul Aziz Al Rajhi, Abdullah Abdul Aziz Al Rajhi), owns significant stake in family's Al Rajhi Bank, whose share price has soared in the past year. His family holding company, Mohammed Abdulaziz Al Rajhi & Sons, has various steel and real estate interests.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gave up his orthopedic practice in 1956 to take over the family’s shoe business. Today he still owns and runs the $2.7 billion (sales) Deichmann-Schuhe GmbH, now Europe’s largest shoe retailer. The private company is also owner of U.S. retail chains Rack Room Shoes and Off Broadway. A committed philanthropist, he regularly donates large sums to missionary and humanitarian organizations including a program to help leprosy victims in India, which he visits annually.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bought used garbage truck in 1962 after dropping out of college, transformed small trash hauling operation into waste management behemoth WMX. Bought 19-store video rental chain Blockbuster 1987; expanded, sold to Viacom for $8.4 billion 7 years later. Owns big stake Auto-Nation, pro football’s Miami Dolphins.

name: Billionaires
bio: Booming housing market keeps Kohler’s coffers overflowing. Grandfather started company in 1873 as maker of hitching posts, cemetery ornaments for midwestern farmers. Kohler today a leading manufacturer of kitchen and bath fixtures, furniture, electricity generators. With sister Ruth, controls $3 billion (sales) firm after buying out 300 shareholders in 1998. Yale graduate owns Whistling Straits course on Lake Michigan, site of last year’s PGA championship, possible home to 2020 Ryder Cup. Also owns Scotland’s Old Course Hotel, Golf Resort & Spa.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father Lars founded L.E. Lundberforetagen AB in 1944 as a construction company. Fredrik took over in 1981.Today the $2.5 billion (sales) diversified holding company concentrates on property management and investments, and owns 157 properties and projects in Sweden. Lundberg enjoys hunting and curling; in fact, he was once a junior world champion of curling.

name: Billionaires
bio: Biotech entrepreneur has had a hand in the world’s greatest medical advances: pacemakers (Pacesetter), insulin pumps (Minimed), cochlear implants, neurostimulators (Advanced Bionics), prosthetic retinas (Second Sight). Latest vehicle, Mannkind, developing inhaled insulin that mimics the body’s. “It will be one of the most valuable products of all time.” Works 90-hour weeks hatching medical startups from industrial park outside L.A. Says he’ll donate his entire fortune to charity, medical research.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, John Elroy McCaw, started in cable business. Craig took over at 19 after father’s death, built into early cell phone giant McCaw Cellular, sold to AT&T in 1993 for $11.5 billion. Much of proceeds reinvested in Nextel and satellite network, wiped out in telecom crash. Craig remains big communications investor. Hopes to score in large-area wireless broadband via nascent Clearwire.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Mitchell (see), passed up father’s real estate business to start Equity Group Holdings 1979; bought small manufacturing companies (Chicago Pneumatic Tool, Western Pacific Industries, Ammco Tools). Acquired 25% stake in near-bankrupt real estate investment trust, combined with manufacturing units to create Danaher 1982 (named after favorite Montana trout stream).

name: Billionaires
bio:
Shareholder in Millhouse Capital, which this fall was paid $13.1 billion by
the Russian state-owned gas monopoly Gazprom to buy Millhouse&#39s majority
stake in oil-giant Sibneft. Has worked with fellow billionaire and Millhouse
investor Roman Abramovich since the early 1990s, when they established
Runicom, an oil trading outfit; then the two along with fellow tycoon Boris
Berezovsky took control of Sibneft in 1995 (Berezovsky later sold his stake
after the failed Sibneft-Yukos merger in 2003). Acted as president of
Sibneft since 1998 and then resigned in October following the sale. Keeps a
low profile, despite his recent purchases of a $37 million mansion in
London&#39s ritzy Belgravia district and a 125,000-bottle-a-year vineyard in
southern France called Chateau Thénac.



OLD BIO (from rich list):
Trained as oil engineer in Moscow, earned M.B.A. from Fordham U. Worked for Deloitte & Touche; became U.S. citizen. Teamed up with Roman Abramovich to start oil trading outfit Runicom S.A. In 1995 the duo partnered with Boris Berezovsky to gain control of oil giant Sibneft; became president in 1998. Deal to merge Sibneft and Yukos fell apart last year after top Yukos shareholder, Mikhail Khodorkovsky, landed in jail. Owns Château Thénac vineyard in France, paid $37 million for new home in London.

name: Billionaires
bio: Yale undergrad wrote senior thesis outlining overnight delivery service. After stint in Vietnam worked as crop-dusting pilot, bought small stake in Arkansas aviation firm. With venture capital, small inheritance, launched Federal Express in 1973. FedEx now the world’s biggest overnight freight service, delivering more than 6 million shipments a day. New cargo hub in Guangzhou, China under way. History buff, minority owner of pro football’s Washington Redskins.

name: Billionaires
bio: Minnesota farm boy worked way through college at print shop. Persuaded retiring owner to sell for $2 million over 10 years. Paid off early, built Taylor Corp. into $1.8 billion (sales) printing giant: invitations, stationery, magazines. Retired as CEO, still chairman. Former Republican state senator, owner pro basketball’s Minnesota Timberwolves. Also agribusiness: chickens, liquefied eggs; owns 9,000 acres of “good farmland” in Iowa, Minnesota.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former bank clerk used profits from a real estate deal to open up a small bank in 1966. Today, Public Bank is the third largest banking group in Malaysia with 12,600 employees and more than 250 branches. Public Bank's Islamic banking products and services (which, among other things, are interest-free because Islam prohibits taking or giving interest) are gaining popularity among Malaysia's Muslims. Loves photography; is an avid reader.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs Johnson Electric, which pioneered the manufacture of micro motors in Hong Kong in 1959. The rapid expansion of Hong Kong's motorized toy industry during the early 1960s boosted Johnson Electric's fortunes. Today makes more than 1,700 types of motors for a wide variety of products, including office equipment and lawn mowers. His mother is honorary chairwoman and several other relatives work at the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of Taiwan billionaire Y.C. Wang, Cher turned her love of gadgets into a sizable fortune. Shares of High Tech Computer, the smart phone maker she controls with husband Wenchi Chen, quintupled in the past year amid bulging sales and profits. Another company run by the two, Via Technologies, designs semiconductors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Last April the casino visionary opened Wynn Las Vegas resort to great fanfare: $2.7 billion complex boasts 2,700 rooms, Ferrari dealership, permanent space for Wynn’s vaunted art collection. Golf course commands $500 per round green fee. Son of bingo parlor operator became keno manager at Frontier Hotel in Las Vegas. Bought Golden Nugget casino before building the Mirage, Treasure Island and Bellagio theme resorts. Sold Mirage to Kirk Kerkorian for $6.4 billion in 2000. Took Wynn Resorts public 2002. Emphasis on entertainment: enticed Siegfried & Roy to Mirage, brought Cirque du Soleil to Sin City. Lured Broadway to the Strip with Avenue Q last year; closing adult puppet show in May to make room for Monte Python-themed Spamalot. Set to open Wynn Macau this fall; $700 million casino in Far East gambling mecca will allow Wynn to compete with arch-nemisis Sheldon Adelson on two continents.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lives life in the fast lane, thanks to a $40 million racecar franchise in Lebanon for the new A1 Racing League. Iraqi-born Londoner got criticized for hosting a lavish1,000-person wedding for son Tameem and his wealthy Palestinian bride-on the same day that the antipoverty Live 8 concert kicked off in adjacent Hyde Park. Recently added a $131 million (purchase price) property in Chicago's South Loop to his $1.2 billion estimated real estate holdings.

name: Billionaires
bio: Benjamin Graham disciple founded investment firm in 1974. After careful analysis invested in high-intrinsic-value companies at low stock price; waited for market to adjust. Today Brandes Investment Partners manages $95 billion. Author of Value Investing Today. Serves on boards of Salk Institute for Biological Studies, Whittier Institute for Diabetic Research.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners and longtime friends Alijan Ibragimov and Alexander Machkevich (see both) built a metals and mining empire in Kazakhstan. The trio has spent the last four years consolidating assets in the now-named Eurasian Natural Resources Corporation. Hopes to ride the crest of successful Kazakh offerings in London next year. A native of Uzbekistan, Chodiev studied international law and Japanese and lived in Japan before teaming up with his pals to take advantage of the freewheeling trading during Gorbachev's perestroika. Oldest daughter is very active in the business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Per Swiss law, stepped down as cochairman of Adecco at age 70. Now unloading thousands of shares of Adecco stock. In turn, former Adecco partner and current chief executive Klaus Jacobs, 68, is scooping up the shares and funneling them straight into his foundation. (In 1996 the two merged their staffing companies to create one of the largest employment companies in the world.)  It's a good time to own the stock, which reached a high of $59 last month, up 44% from October 2005. Companies are finally hiring again and Adecco has found a niche in coaching and human resources management to keep older employees in the workforce. Foriel-Destezet remains busy on the boards of holding company Akila finance and security systems provider Securitas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started chain of arts-and-crafts stores with $600 loan in 1972. Prefers retrofitting old stores to new construction; eschews bar codes, as middlemen eat profits. Today Hobby Lobby operates 360 stores, most west of the Mississippi. Devout Christian put up $30 million to finance faith-based movies produced by son, Mart. Lives to spread the Word. “We feel like we have an answer for ‘Why?’ To change lives for eternity.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of publishing legend William Randolph Hearst, who assumed control of San Francisco Examiner from his father, built what once was one of nation’s largest newspaper chains via sensational “yellow” journalism. Today the empire owns newspapers (flagship: San Francisco Chronicle), magazines (Cosmopolitan, Esquire, Good Housekeeping), cable channels (stakes in ESPN, A&E, Lifetime), TV and radio stations. Also real estate: prime parcel along California coast. William III a partner at Silicon Valley venture capital shop Kleiner Perkins.

name: Billionaires
bio: Made almost $2 billion in 2001, when Citigroup bought Banamex, which he was running at the time. He sits with Gerald Ford and Dick Parsons on the Citigroup board, and in 2004 received over $1 million worth of "office, secretarial, and related services" including airplane and helicopter usage, from the bank. Today Hernandez is active in a number of social causes, including environmental conservation, the World Monuments Fund, and the David Rockefeller Center for Latin American Studies at Harvard.

name: Billionaires
bio: With mother Ingeburg and her four brothers, Günter, Joachim, Michael and Wolfgang (see all), inherited a fortune from her father coffee magnate Max Herz.  A nasty family feud led her and her older brother Günter to sell their combined 40% stake in German consumer goods group Tchibo Holding to their three brothers and mother for an estimated $5 billion in August 2003. The brother and sister now share a private equity firm, Mayfair GmbH, which recently bought a 25% stake in German sportswear manufacturer, Puma AG.

name: Billionaires
bio: With mother Ingeburg, his three brothers, Joachim, Michael and Wolfgang, and sister Daniela (see all), inherited a fortune from his father, coffee magnate Max Herz. After a nasty family feud Günter, the eldest son, and  Daniela sold their 40% combined stake in consumer products group Tchibo Holding to their mother and three brothers for an estimated $5 billion in August 2003. Through their private equity company Mayfair GmbH, Günter and Daniela have recently bought a 25% stake in German sportswear company, Puma AG. A keen horse racing fan, he raises horses at the stud farm he owns in Schleswig-Holstein

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners and longtime friends Alexander Machkevich and Patokh Chodiev (see both) built a metals and mining empire in Kazakhstan. The trio has spent the last four years consolidating assets in the now-named Eurasian Natural Resources Corporation. Hopes to ride the crest of successful Kazakh initial offerings in London next year. Native of Kyrgyzstan, moved to Kazakhstan when the group decided to pursue business interests there. Devout Muslim with 6 sons, shuns the limelight.

name: Billionaires
bio: Traded cotton after studying economics at U. of Virginia. Started Tudor Investment 1985. Early success predicting 1987 market crash; turned prescient short positions into 201% gain. Never a down year; worst performance in 2000, when offshore Tudor BVI Global Portfolio fund delivered 11.6%. Said to charge 23% of profits and 4% of assets. Now focusing on Asia: created Australian affiliate, opened Singapore trading office in 2004. Avid pheasant hunter, bass fisherman owns property around the world, including getaways in Florida Keys and Zimbabwe. Founder New York City’s Robin Hood Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Princeton grad joined father’s auto insurance firm 1955; targeted high-risk drivers. Took Progressive public 1971. Became country’s third-largest auto insurer. Now caters to all drivers: uses tech device to monitor customers’ driving habits, sets rates accordingly. Art enthusiast, more than 6,000 works of original contemporary art in offices nationwide. Stepped down from board of Guggenheim Museum this year; supports Case Western Reserve business school, Princeton University. Democrat spent millions against Bush.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners and longtime friends Alijan Ibragimov and Patokh Chodiev (see both) built a metals and mining empire in Kazakhstan. The trio has spent the last four years consolidating assets in the now-named Eurasian Natural Resources Corporation. Hopes to ride the crest of successful Kazakh initial offerings in London next year. Native of Kyrgyzstan, studied literature and was one of the youngest deans of a university in Kyrgyzstan at the age of 26. Moved to Moscow to start a trading business with Chodiev and Ibragimov. Early on obtained Israeli citizenship and has been very active in Jewish causes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Construction manager’s son built computer program unbeatable in tic-tac-toe. Won scholarship to MIT, edited student newspaper there. Founded International Data Group 1964 to provide research for computer market. Launched Computerworld in 1967; later, PC World, Macworld. Added books (popular Dummies series), trade shows, Internet sites. Sales: $2.7 billion, still privately held. Recent growth in Asia. Publishes 41 magazines and newspapers in China, manages tech venture funds in India, Vietnam.

name: Billionaires
bio: Financial genius joined Drexel Burnham Lambert in 1969; fueled 1980s leveraged-buyout boom with high-yield junk bonds. Made borrowing easier for small firms and Forbes 400 financiers like Carl Icahn, Ronald Perelman and Henry Kravis. Salary, bonus $550 million in 1986 alone. Wharton M.B.A. ratted out by arbitrager Ivan Boesky; pleaded guilty to 6 counts of securities fraud 1990. Paid $900 million settlement to government, litigators, creditors; served 22 months in prison. Prostate cancer survivor immersed in cancer research: since 1993 raised $250 million for Prostate Cancer Foundation; speeds drugs to trial, encourages innovative research. Also created FasterCures/The Center for Accelerating Medical Solutions, Washington, D.C. think tank. Big backer of education: $25,000 checks to 100 stellar teachers and principals every year. Owns stake in Knowledge Universe: day care centers, private schools, educational toys.

name: Billionaires
bio: Star racecar driver retired from racing in 1965 at age 28. Worked for Alcoa; left, bought Chevy dealership. Started Penske Corp. 1969: truck leasing, truck parts manufacturer, diesel engine maker, auto dealerships. In addition controls more than 250 dealerships in the U.S. and Europe as chairman of United Auto Group, nation’s second-largest auto dealer. Owns 2 Indy car teams, 3 Nascar teams; part-owner of Deer Valley ski resort in Utah.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads Hong Leong Group Malaysia, a conglomerate of 14 listed companies traded on various stock exchanges. Includes Guoco Group, an Asian financial services giant and Hong Leong Industries, which makes semiconductor circuits, electronic components and lead frames. He has a Barrister-at-Law from Middle Temple school in the U.K. His cousin Kwek Leng Beng, based in Singapore, oversees the family's property and hotel businesses.

name: Billionaires
bio:
The richest man in Canada's oil patch. This Winnipeg-born geologist made it
big by finding natural gas in remote and often arctic areas. In the 1970s founded Paramount Resources, which developed huge natural gas inventories and benefited from the run up in natural gas prices. Riddell split the company into three, forming two income trusts from Paramount's assets over the last four years. Co-owner of the Calgary Flames.

name: Billionaires
bio: Met partner James Goodnight at North Carolina State; cofounded software giant SAS Institute after graduating. Developed business intelligence programs and platforms. Clients include U.S. Department of Defense, Air France, pharmaceutical and financial services companies. SAS is world’s largest privately held software manufacturer. Sales: $1.5 billion. Despite persistent rumors, no plans to go public.

name: Billionaires
bio: Palo Alto residential broker in the 1960s branched into commercial market. Now one of largest commercial landlords in rebounding Silicon Valley market, with 11 million square feet.

name: Billionaires
bio: Obtained a national commercial television license in 1993; created Polsat, now one of the nation's biggest television stations. Plans to take the group public have been postponed. Currently, Soloz-Zak is battling disgruntled bondholders of energy and telecom conglomerate Elektrim, which in turn owns contested shares in Polish mobile telecom provider PTC. Also has stakes in PTE pension fund and Invest Bank.

name: Billionaires
bio: Low-key owner of El Ad Group, a real estate development company with mostly American and Canadian properties. The crown jewel: Manhattan's Plaza Hotel, snapped up for $675 million last year. Tshuva's Cinderella story began in Netanya in a single room where his penniless family of 11 lived briefly. By the Seventies, following his compulsory service in the Israeli army, Tshuva became a contractor and later earned a tidy fortune in the construction boom that coincided with the influx of Soviet Jews to Israel during the 1980s and early 90's. But it wasn't until 1998, when he orchestrated a hostile takeover of Delek, Israel's second-largest oil and gas company, that he became a household name in Israel. Made headlines last year after he tussled with New York City labor leaders and politicos-including city's mayor, fellow billionaire Michael Bloomberg-over fate of the Plaza and its 900 employees. Through a fund he established at Delek, Tshuva underwrites scholarships for 400 Israeli university students each year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father of cable news fetches better returns in fast food and real estate than in dwindling Time Warner stake. Just as well: Time Warner still a market laggard, even with Carl Icahn (see) on the prowl. Stepped down as Time Warner vice chairman in 2003; retired from the board in February. Mouth of the South now nation’s largest individual landowner: some 2 million acres in 11 states. Restaurant chain, Ted’s Montana Grill, serves bison burgers at 41 locations. Vocal environmentalist; recently donated 3.6 million Time Warner shares to United Nations Foundation, bringing total contribution to $600 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Montreal tobacco and candy wholesaler. Wharton M.B.A.; law degrees from McGill, Harvard. Never took bar exam. Got start in real estate working at Cabot, Cabot & Forbes. Left to form Boston Properties: $10 billion REIT owns 45 million square feet of commercial space along eastern seaboard, San Francisco. Second career: publishing. Owns U.S. News & World Report; bought, turned around New York’s Daily News. Sold Atlantic Monthly magazine for measly $12 million in 1999 but hit jackpot selling Fast Company magazine at height of tech boom for $365 million. “I averaged out.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Scion of investment boutique Allen & Co. always keeps a quiet profile, but continues to rack up loud returns: more than 40% a year since mid-1980s. Forges lucrative relationships with media honchos by hosting annual retreat in Sun Valley, Idaho.

name: Billionaires
bio: Third generation to run Verlagsgruppe Bauer, the mass media company founded by his grandfather in 1875. The $2 billion (sales) group publishes everything from TV guides to special interest publications like Auto Zeitung (cars) and kochen & geniessen (cooking), to “yellow press” magazines like Neue Post and Das Neue Blatt. In the U.S. it does well with titles like Soap Opera Update, Woman’s World and Touch Weekly. Already present in 13 countries, the group is moving into Mexico, Russia and China.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of publishing legend William Randolph Hearst, who assumed control of San Francisco Examiner from his father, built what once was one of nation’s largest newspaper chains via sensational “yellow” journalism. Today the empire owns newspapers (flagship: San Francisco Chronicle), magazines (Cosmopolitan, Esquire, Good Housekeeping), cable channels (stakes in ESPN, A&E, Lifetime), TV and radio stations. Also real estate: prime parcel along California coast.

name: Billionaires
bio: Computer engineering professor at UC, San Diego founded cell phone giant Qualcomm 1985. Patented code division multiple access technology (CDMA), now second-most-used wireless protocol. Company donates small portion pretax profits to San Diego causes. Son, Paul, took over as chief executive this year; Irwin still chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Child of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), great-grandson of parquet-flooring salesman who founded wax company 1886. Sam joined 1954, chairman 1967. Expanded with household cleaning staples (Glade, Pledge, Windex), bug repellents (Off, Raid). Today S.C. Johnson employs 12,000 people worldwide, sells products in more than 110 countries. Though private about profitability, took sideline outdoor equipment company Johnson Outdoors public 1987. Also majority interest in bank holding company Johnson Financial Group. Sam handed companies over to fifth generation; remained public face through series of folksy ads. All kids sent to alma mater Cornell University before entering family business. Curtis: chairman of JohnsonDiversey, developer of business-to-business cleaning and hygiene products. Family commissioned Frank Lloyd Wright to design corporate headquarters in Racine. Big backers of Cornell, Smithsonian Institution, Nature Conservancy, Racine Art Museum, Mayo Clinic.

name: Billionaires
bio: Campbell Soup accountant joined pet food nutritionist Paul Iams in 1970 to sell premium puppy chow to high-end breeders and vets. Bought out partner 1982; expanded with upscale pet products like cat food for sensitive stomachs, hairball relief, weight-loss formulas. Sold to Procter & Gamble in 1999 for $2.3 billion. Now stays busy feeding Mathile Family Foundation; new project to build campus for needy single mothers and their children. Also bought 114 acres in Dayton as a permanent home for Center for Entrepreneurial Education.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert, created industrial conglomerate Marmon (2004 sales: $6.4 billion) and hotel chain Hyatt (211 hotels worldwide). Plan to pass control of empire to Jay’s son Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001; family agreed to carve up empire 11 ways. Family drama sparked by Robert’s 2 youngest children, Matthew and Liesel, who filed suit in Chicago and the Bahamas, where family maintains offshore trusts; each settled for $500 million. But dynastic carve-up, including sales or initial public offerings of Marmon and Hyatt to be completed before 2011, in perplexing standstill mode now. Tom: chief executive of Pritzker Organization.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of Homer Stryker (d. 1980), orthopedic surgeon who invented the mobile hospital bed. WWII Army vet turned to civilian market postwar; founded medical supply company Stryker Corp.: surgical instruments, bone implants, replacement joints. When son, Lee, died in plane crash 1976, hired John Brown (see) year later, who deployed new sales force, cost-cutting agenda. Public 1979. With sister Pat and brother Jon (see both) heirs control 30% of the company. Ronda only family member to sit on board.

name: Billionaires
bio: In late 1980s, helped foreign tourists find hotel rooms in Moscow. In 1990 worked as a consultant for Italian candy company Ferrero Rocher then began selling Italian vermouth; won an exclusive contract from Martini and Rossi. Soon after established Roust Inc., to import liquor and other spirits. In 1998 created first ever high-end brand of Russian vodka, Russian Standard.  A year later with the help of McKinsey & Co., moved into the consumer-credit market. Last year his group became  American Express' exclusive partner in Russia. A bachelor, Tariko is known for his parties on Sardinia Island and at  Moscow nightclubs as well as his lavish lifestyle: he was the first Russian to buy a Maybach and later a Mercedes SLR McLaren.

name: Billionaires
bio: The youngest man on Forbes Billionaires list. This prince inherited a fortune on his eighteenth birthday in June 2001. His assets include extensive real estate holdings, a valuable art collection and a tech company. His 30,000 hectares of woodland in Germany is considered one of the largest forestry holdings in Europe. Lives in one of the family’s castles, Schloss Emmeram, with his mother Gloria and older sisters Maria Theresia and Elisabeth.

name: Billionaires
bio: The founder of Nintendo and an icon of Japan's videogame industry, Yamauchi finally retired last June after 55 years because of bad health, although he will keep a role as an adviser. He left the company in good shape: sales reached $4.5 billion and profits almost tripled to $1.3 billion, thanks in part to the success of a new portable video game player. At his request he gave up his retirement $11 million allowance and asked that it be included in company profit instead.

name: Billionaires
bio: Slim-Fast tycoon raised in Long Beach, N.Y., then called America’s healthiest city. At 18 joined the Army: infantryman in Italy, France and Germany. Lesson: “Stay the hell out of war!” Started selling skin ointments for uncle’s medical supplies company. Stayed with firm, eventually brought out Slim-Fast nutritional supplements 1976. Sold to Unilever for $2.3 billion in 2000; gave all employees year’s salary as parting gift. Donates to Mayo Clinic, funds Center for Middle East Peace & Economic Cooperation. Octogenarian recently became a new father.

name: Billionaires
bio: Established and runs $1.3 billion (sales) Mango, makers of reasonably priced trendy women’s apparel. The first store opened in Barcelona in 1984; there are now over 800 locations in 80 countries. Little is known about the very private Andic other than the fact that his family came to Spain from Turkey in the 1960s, that he is married with children and that he apparently is an enthusiastic sailor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Family’s Bass Enterprises hit hard by Katrina: oil storage tank near New Orleans leaked 90,000 barrels into containment pond. But gains from oil boom more than make up for it. Drilling in the western states, Gulf of Mexico and internationally. Planning new deepwater oil wells off Nova Scotia. Family fortune founded by oil baron uncle Sid Richardson. Diversified into Disney, John Wiley & Sons publishing and Human Genome Sciences. Big shots of Fort Worth: Sid runs investments, Lee avid outdoorsman, Ed does real estate and backed Biosphere 2 project. Other brother Robert (see) invests on his own.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Sodexho, a catering and river-cruise company.  Sodexho supplies food to the U.S. Marine Corps. Recently won a $35 million contract to provide meals to New York City public hospitals. Endured setbacks in the last four years. Three top executives resigned. Faced a lawsuit over a California retirement community E.coli outbreak; suit was settled. Since reaching a 2004 low of $23, the company's stock has bounced back. Last year Bellon stepped down as chief executive, remains chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former bartender started Internet broadcaster Broadcast.com with Indiana University acquaintance Todd Wagner (see) in 1995. Sold to Yahoo 5 years later for $5.7 billion in stock; shrewdly collared shares before Internet bust. Used riches to buy Dallas mansion, Gulfstream jet, pro basketball’s Dallas Mavericks. With Wagner, expanded media assets: Rysher Entertainment (owns Kingpin, Dear God, Nash Bridges), film distributor Magnolia Pictures, plus big investment in high-definition television network HDNet. Famous for wild courtside antics, but major NBA fines becoming less frequent: “My new passion is my daughter.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Stock analyst for Pittsburgh National Bank after dropping out of economics Ph.D. program at U. of Michigan. Started Duquesne Capital Management 1981. Left to work for George Soros 1988; believed to have kept 30% of mentor’s incentive fee. Parted in 2000 after sustaining massive tech sector losses. Returned to Duquesne Capital to run No Margin Fund.

name: Billionaires
bio: Youngest of three children of Joyce Hall (d. 1982), preacher’s son who turned fuzzy feelings into cold cash after founding postcard manufacturer Hallmark in 1910. Now world’s largest greeting-card company. With siblings, owns two-thirds of $4.4 billion (sales) company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hartono owns the Indonesian kretek maker, Djarum, which competes with fellow billionaire Rachman Halim&#39s (see) Gudang Garam. The name kretek comes from the crackling “kretek kretek” sound of the cloves as they burn up. Like its rival, Djarum still employs hundreds of people to hand-roll many of its kreteks.

name: Billionaires
bio: A trained mathematician, Hector cofounded German software firm SAP with four former IBM colleagues. He successfully built up the North American market for SAP, then left the firm in 1997 after a falling-out with his partners. His charitable foundation supports cancer and AIDS research, art and historical preservation. Holds an honorary professorship of mathematics from the University of Karlsruhe for his support of talented students in the math, natural sciences and technology fields

name: Billionaires
bio: Born during Depression, found work as farmer, policeman, land-use lawyer. Planted vines north of San Francisco in the mid-1970s, released first Kendall-Jackson wine in 1982. Today his Jackson Wine Estates operates 24 wineries and vineyards around the world, selling an estimated 5 million cases of wine a year. Looked to retire in 2000, put K-J up for sale for $1.7 billion, changed his mind. Expanding into boutique wineries (Lokoya, Hartford Court) with his wife, Barbara Banke. Also horses: recently bought 2 Thoroughbred farms in Kentucky.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nuclear engineer turned his family's ailing Naples drug wholesaler into Alliance UniChem, second-largest drug wholesaler in Europe. In October U.K. pharmacy chain Boots announced it would acquire Alliance UniChem for $12 billion to form Alliance Boots, Europe's largest pharmacy business with 3,000 locations and a wholesale network serving 88,000 clients. Deal is awaiting regulatory approval by the Office of Fair Trading. If it goes through, Pessina would become group's executive deputy chairman.

Penny: chief of Hyatt’s senior housing division.

With sisters Pat and Ronda (see both), controls 30% of the company. Ronda only family member to sit on board. Architect Jon: founder of Arcus Foundation; focuses on gay and lesbian rights, great-ape sanctuaries, conservation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Norwegian real estate magnate bought his first building in 1951 and opened his first restaurant in 1966. Now his $590 million (sales) Olav Thon Gruppen owns 360 properties in Norway and 18 abroad. The conglomerate’s portfolio includes shopping malls, office buildings, retail stores, hotels, and several restaurants and pubs in Oslo. Even makes raw ingredients for soap and cosmetics.

name: Billionaires
bio: His key asset, Ukraine's largest steel company Kryvorizhstal, was reprivatized last year and sold to Lakshmi Mittal (see). Spent several months camped out elsewhere in Europe while criminal investigators looked into his past; postponed plans to take his company public. Recently has made an astounding comeback. He is running in Ukraine's March parliamentary elections on a libertarian, free market ticket and pundits posit he may be the country's next prime minister.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took the reins of Grupo Televisa, now Mexico's leading broadcaster, after his father passed away in 1997. The 38-year-old  owns almost 15% of the company's outstanding shares. Made news last year when it was reported that the billionaire, who has a home in South Beach, was looking to become a U.S. citizen so that he could boost his stake in U.S. Spanish language broadcaster Univision, in which Televisa already holds an 11% stake. Azcarraga says that he is in no rush; that might be in part because his relationship with Univision is fairly shaky right now. He quit the board last year, reportedly over royalty disputes. Looking beyond North America, has inked a new joint venture with music company EMI Group.

name: Billionaires
bio: This corporate raider is known for snapping up large stakes in distressed companies. His latest industry of choice: advertising. Built up a stake in French agency Havas before demanding board seats; also investing in Aegis Group, the British media and market research concern. His eclectic portfolio also includes plastics, African shipping and Asian palm-oil plantations. Started out as a bank trainee at Edmond de Rothschild. An avid comic aficionado, his collection boasts 1,000 comic-books by the likes of Pieds Nickles and Spirou. Plans to build a small house for the collection, complete with a kitchen, so his friends can enjoy a snack while reading.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fourth-generation banker and one of Spain's most influential men. Heads Santander Central Hispano, one of Spain's leading financial institutions and the world's ninth largest bank. Made news recently when he tried to acquire almost 20% of Sovereign Bancorp Inc in Philadelphia.  The deal, which was criticized by some shareholders who  apparently feared a ceding of control of Sovereign to Santander Bank and a dilution of existing shareholders' value, is now waiting for federal regulatory approval. Botin was acquitted last year of charges of criminal misappropriation of bank funds to pay off two departed bank officials. Heir apparent, daughter Ana Patricia, chairs bank's retail unit Banestos.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cable guy had humble beginnings but helped start what became Home Box Office. The old Time Inc. bought out his interest by handing him nascent cable systems with only 1,500 customers in 1973. Thus began Cablevision, which today is nation’s sixth-largest cable operator with 3 million subscribers—and with largest single contiguous system (and prime takeover bait). “Chuck” handed chief exec title to son Jimmy in 1995. Father and son clashed over dad’s pet project, digital satellite TV venture Voom, after it racked up $500 million in losses. Owner pro basketball’s New York Knicks and hockey’s New York Rangers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of John T. Dorrance, inventor of condensed soup process. Passed Campbell Soup business on to son, 3 daughters. Third generation now owns about half the company; 4 grandchildren (Dorrance, Malone, Weber and George Strawbridge) sit on board but not involved in day-to-day operations. Grandkids’ interests include horses, art (Weber), real estate and aviation (Dorrance), gardening (Hamilton) and philanthropy, notably “Dodo” Hamilton’s recent $25 million donation to Thomas Jefferson U.

name: Billionaires
bio: A count who has a lock on his wealth. Douglas holds stakes in Assa Abloy, the world’s largest producer of locks; Securitas AB, one of the largest publicly traded security companies; Fagerhult AB, a Swedish maker of light fixtures; and Attendo Senior Care, a private company that provides alarms and care communication systems for senior citizens. Received an M.B.A. from Harvard Business School in 1964.

name: Billionaires
bio: Opened his first hotel 50 years ago at the age of 21 in Palma de Majorca. The $1.1 billion (sales ) Sol Meliá group is now the world’s twelfth largest hotel company with 350 hotels and resorts in 30 countries including 20 in Cuba. Escarrer still runs the group with help from his two sons. Has received numerous awards in his career such as Tourism Personality of the Century and a place in the University of Houston’s Conrad Hilton College Hall of Honors. Avid golfer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fervent flyer got start as Air Force flight surgeon. With father founded Hospital Corp. of America 1968. Took public 1969. Merged with Richard Rainwater’s Columbia Hospital Corp. 1994; now nation’s largest hospital operator. Came out of retirement to help revive company during a lengthy Medicare-fraud investigation. ATP-certified pilot, favors amphibian C-plane and Citation jet. Original founding member Alexis de Tocqueville Society, which donates to United Way. Brother Bill is Senate majority leader.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and chief executive of Funai Electric, Wal-Mart's largest supplier of TVs, DVD players and other audiovisual equipment. Funai is better known in North America, where it generates two-thirds of sales, than at home in Japan. Sales rose 12% in the year ending March 2005, but net profits slipped by 2% as the company shifted to making digital devices and away from VCR and TV/video components. High oil prices, which bumped up material costs and squeezed margins, also hurt business. Funai  claims he has no plans to retire even at age 79. Enjoys playing golf, even when traveling overseas for business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Israeli immigrant spent his 20s learning buyout business alongside older brother Alec (see) at Gores Technology Group. Split in 1995 to form Platinum Equity: conglomerate manages 21 companies with $8 billion in sales. Recent acquisitions: General Electric’s IT Solutions; American Racing Equipment.

name: Billionaires
bio: Once drove a tow truck. Now known for astute debt-financed purchases. His Burns Philp food group recently spun off baking units in a public offering that raised about $1.6 billion. Latest target is wood and paper products company, Carter Holt Harvey; bought International Paper's 50.5% stake for $1.1 billion in 2005 and then boosted his share to 86%. As of press time, still trying to buy the rest. Enjoys boating and water sports, particularly diving.

name: Billionaires
bio: Close associate of billionaire Igor Zyuzin, Iorikh has always kept a low profile. The former commercial director of Kuznets Coal, became president of the Swiss firm Conares Holding in 1995, overseeing export sales and financing. The public learned about him for the first time in October 2004, when Mechel, the largest producer of special steel and alloys, listed on the NYSE and Iorich was named general director; the secretive Iorich turned out to have the same stake in the company as his better-known partner Zyuzin. Latest news: he recently announced plans to sell his stake to his partner by the end of 2006.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Senior statesman of Turkish industrialists, ran Koc Group until 2003.
Credited as driving force behind the expansion of Turkish economic interests
in Eastern Europe. Manages to find common ground with Greek, Israeli, Arab
and American investors in his 65,000 employee conglomerate. Avid sailor
spends months calling on ports around the world aboard his luxury yacht,
though no docking at prestigious New York Yacht Club, where he is a member.
Worked with Alexander Onassis Foundation to restore wall paintings in
historic Antalya, Turkey church. Sisters Semahat Arsel and Suna Kirac share the family fortune(see both).

name: Billionaires
bio: With wife Ann, who inherited big Wal-Mart stake from father, James (Bud) Walton (d. 1995), who cofounded retail chain with brother Sam. Stan made money as a real estate developer, including shopping centers anchored by Wal-Mart stores. Also owns more than 1 million acres of ranch land. Sports fanatic owns stakes in pro football’s St. Louis Rams, basketball’s Denver Nuggets, hockey’s Colorado Avalanche.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Flamboyant socialite owns 61% stake in Chinese Estates Holdings; stock is
soaring, thanks to hot property market. Outfit has $500 million worth of
apartments available for sale this year in Hong Kong, and plans to build
another $245 million worth in 2006. Now looking at neighboring market Macau;
recently signed a $205 million housing project in the neighboring casino
enclave. Brother Thomas owns 10% of Chinese Estates; together they also own
a stake in Lifestyle International, the outfit that owns SOGO Department
Stores.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of John T. Dorrance, inventor of condensed soup process. Passed Campbell Soup business on to son, 3 daughters. Grandkids’ interests include horses, art (Weber), real estate and aviation (Dorrance), gardening (Hamilton) and philanthropy, notably “Dodo” Hamilton’s recent $25 million donation to Thomas Jefferson U.

name: Billionaires
bio: Argentina's sole billionaire built his fortune with oil but lately has focused on food. Sold namesake energy company to Petrobras for $1 billion in 2002. Now holds a controlling stake in Molinos Rio de la Plata, Argentina's biggest packaged-food concern, which sells Luchetti's pasta and Cocinero oils. With wife, Maria Carmen, raises dairy cows and operates Munchi's, small chain of ice cream parlors. Devoted family man is father of seven. One indulgence: his $500,000 red Ferrari F50.

Family drama sparked by Robert’s 2 youngest children, Matthew and Liesel, who filed suit in Chicago and the Bahamas, where family maintains offshore trusts; each settled for $500 million. Tony: with brother, J.B., runs venture capital fund, invests in technology, manufacturing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert, created industrial conglomerate Marmon (2004 sales: $6.4 billion) and hotel chain Hyatt (211 hotels worldwide). Plan to pass control of empire to Jay’s son Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001; family agreed to carve up empire 11 ways. Family drama sparked by Robert’s 2 youngest children, Matthew and Liesel, who filed suit in Chicago and the Bahamas, where family maintains offshore trusts; each settled for $500 million. But dynastic carve-up, including sales or initial public offerings of Marmon and Hyatt to be completed before 2011, in perplexing standstill mode now. J.B.: with brother, Tony, runs venture capital fund, invests in technology, manufacturing.
