name: Billionaires
bio:
Board member of powerful Sabanci Group of Turkey serves as face of family
empire in Europe. Spends as much time in London as he does in Istanbul.
Watched as fellow billionaire Bahaa Hariri and family (see) outbid
Sabanci-led consortium for Turk Telecom privatization in late 2005. Had
library named for him at Harran University in Turkey. Past charitable
projects include an archeological site in Turkey first excavated in the
1960s and a refurbished park in Bodrum, Turkey. Brother of Erol Sabanci.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nebraska native, civil engineering degree from Colorado State. Joined Kiewit construction firm where his father worked; rose under mentor Peter Kiewit and took over after Kiewit’s death 1979. Expanded into telecom, cable, energy. Childhood friend of Warren Buffett, member of Berkshire Hathaway board, but most of wealth tied up in Mid American Energy Corp. With wife, Suzanne, funded Scott Atrium & Education Center at U. of Nebraska Medical Center.

name: Billionaires
bio: Great-granddaughter of Franz Ströher, the wigmaker who founded Wella AG, one of world’s biggest professional hair care groups. Pocketed 25% of the $4 billion  she and her family received from the sale of Wella to Procter & Gamble in March 2003. Sylvia and her husband, a former male nurse, are known for their collection of contemporary German art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Made his fortune from a variety of sources including beer, cigarettes, and airlines. Owns the country's flag carrier Philippines Airlines. His listed rum maker, Tanduay, has roots tracing back to 1854. Among his many posts, he is the Philippines' honorary consul to Romania.

name: Billionaires
bio: Member of one of China's most powerful business families, which has been prominent for decades. His father, Rong Yiren, who died in  October 2005, played a critical role in opening up China to the world through  his China International Trust & Investment Corp. after Deng Xiaoping  launched the country's reforms. Larry Rong worked in China's Ministry of  Foreign Affairs for 14 years before moving to Hong Kong to set up Citic  Pacific. He has turned the company into one of China's most successful  conglomerates with investments in steel, property and power. Citic Pacific  owns 26% of Cathay Pacific Airways and is a partner of Wal-Mart in the  Shanghai area.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 2001 Zyuzin's company Yuzhny Kuzbass bought a controlling stake in the Chelyabinsk Metallurgical Plant from Glencore. Out of these assets he created Mechel Group, which went public in 2004 on the NYSE. Mechel is the largest producer of special steel and alloys in Russia, but the company is short of raw material resources, so in 2005 Mechel paid $400 million for a 25% stake in coal mining company Yakutugol.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Brazil&#39s Bozano made headlines in 2000 when he sold Banco Bozano Simonsen,
which he cofounded, to Spain&#39s Banco Santander Central Hispano. He&#39s managed
to pretty much stay out of the headlines ever since. His 11% stake in
Brazilian jetmaker Embraer is worth some $700 million. Reportedly loves race
horses, lives in Greenwich, Conn. and has a pied-à-terre in Rio de Janeiro.

name: Billionaires
bio: New Balance Arch Co. started in 1906 to correct orthopedic foot problems. Saw opportunity with rising popularity of athletic shoes; bought company on day of Boston Marathon 1972. Turned blind eye to fashion trends, superstar endorsements; built brand on multiple width sizes, support. This year launched national advertising campaign (“For Love or Money?”) appealing to amateur athletes, running enthusiasts. Serves as New Balance CEO; wife, Anne, executive vice president. Though only number 3 in the U.S. sneaker landscape, wealthier than crosstown rival Paul Fireman (see) of Reebok.

name: Billionaires
bio:
The leader of Brazil&#39s largest retailer, Companhia Brasileira de
Distribuiçao, sold a big stake in his company last year for a reported $860
million to French supermarket chain Casino, already an existing shareholder.
Casino and Diniz now share control of CBD. Diniz stepped down as chief
executive in December 2002 but as chairman still goes to the office every
day. A fitness buff, Diniz works out and plays squash three hours a day.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Former commodity trader now runs a media empire holding the largest
newspapers and TV networks, commanding a whopping 40% of advertising market
in Turkey. Spent last year acquiring various media assets for scraps--$300
million - previously owned by nemesis and rival Uzan family, who fell off
Forbes billionaires list in 2005. Also owns a large gasoline company,
Petrol Ofisi. Charitable foundation supports literacy programs, but when it
comes to speaking English, Dogan relies on help from his four daughters, two
of whom carry M.B.A.'s from Columbia Business School, and are due to take
over the family business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Silence is golden. Engineer and physicist made fortune with audio-processing system that eliminates hiss and other background noise. Dolby sound technology now the industry standard for movies (used in more than 17,000 films), stereo equipment. Began working on noise reduction while earning Stanford engineering degree; eventually earned Ph.D. from Cambridge. Became technical adviser for Unesco in India. Founded Dolby Laboratories in London 1965, relocated to San Francisco 11 years later. Took Dolby Laboratories public last year. Owns more than 50 patents; enjoys skiing, boating, flying helicopters and airplanes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wharton grad, worked for plastic egg carton maker in 1960s. Left 1970, bought styrene plant. Went on huge acquisition spree using lots of leverage. Turned Huntsman Chemical into nation’s largest privately held chemical concern. Rising oil prices put big squeeze on profits; gave up 49% of firm settling debt with creditors. Turned around, took public last year; stake now worth $1.3 billion. Figures to be final year on The Forbes 400; says most of the proceeds will go to his cancer foundation. “I’ll keep just enough shares to live on.” Will also keep enough to finance real estate project in Driggs, Idaho.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Promise, Japan's third-largest consumer finance company. The Tokyo-based lender, which charges interest rates as high as 25%, reported record net income of $655 million for the year ending March 2005 as fewer borrowers than expected defaulted on their repayments. Jinnai funds programs for Japanese immigrants in South America, such as nursing homes and day centers for elderly settlers. Grateful recipients of his charity in Paraguay erected a statue of Jinnai in front of a center named after him.

name: Billionaires
bio: Met partner Gary Burrell (see) working as engineers at AlliedSignal; founded Garmin in 1989 to make digital navigation products and communications devices for boats, planes, hikers. Donated $17.5 million to alma mater, U. of Tennessee.

name: Billionaires
bio: The son of a pharmacist cobbled together 1,875 pharmacies to create one of the biggest pharmacy chains in North America. The Edmonton-based Katz—pronounced “Cates”—Group is also one of Canada’s largest private companies. Katz bought up distressed pharmacy chains with the help of drug distributor McKesson, then hired capable execs to turn the chains around. Katz is now using the Rexall name to rebrand all his stores.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Shanghai and raised in Hong Kong, Lam studied engineering at National Taiwan University and went on to found one of the island's largest laptop computer maker, Quanta Computer. Still not a household name, the Taiwan contract manufacturer is now the world's number one maker of notebook computers. Customers include HP and Toshiba.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads the IOI Group, one of the largest business groups in Malaysia with interests in plantations, real estate development and resource manufacturing. IOI's three listed entities have more than $5 billion in market capitalization. Started his career in the plantation industry as a field supervisor.  His specialty oils and fats are now used in soaps, detergents, cosmetics, food additives and plastics. Also a real estate developer in Malaysia - his companies have developed modern townships, malls and resorts. Gives scholarships and educational grants to needy students.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in London's East End, Lewis made his initial wealth expanding family's catering business. Gradually moved into currency trading in the late 1970s. Now based in Lyford Cay, Bahamas, he has homes all over the world including one at Isleworth, an Orlando golf community he bought out of receivership in the 1990s. He is main investor in Tavistock Group, which has interests in more than 100 companies. The Tavistock Group recently sold its currency trading firm HotSpot FX for $77 million. He is developing a new community in the Bahamas called Albany with his friends Tiger Woods and Ernie Els.

name: Billionaires
bio: Last year the longtime cable baron, ever the dealmaker, jousted with News Corp.’s Rupert Murdoch over increased voting stake. Hopes to land sweetened asset deal in exchange for Murdoch securing family control but no deal yet. Also continues to spin off cable-channel stakes owned by investment arm Liberty Media to boost lackluster stock price. Latest: Liberty’s chunk of Discovery Channel. Former engineer became right-hand man and successor to Bob Magness (d. 1996), founder of TCI cable empire. Sold TCI to AT&T in 1999, retained control of Liberty; searching for deals ever since. Major holdings include QVC, Starz, Encore; cable systems in Europe, Asia.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Richard, sons of J.W. Marriott Sr. (d. 1985), who started service empire with root beer stand Hot Shoppe in 1927; became regional chain. Added first hotel, Twin Bridges, 1957. Willard Jr. named president 1964. Built hotels and restaurants, exited latter in 1989. Since 1993 brothers split company amid bondholder protest: Richard heads hotel owner Host Marriott; Willard Jr. controls manager and franchiser Marriott International. Active Mormons fund education, help disabled people find jobs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Marcel Merieux, a former laboratory aide to Louis Pasteur. Alain is chief of biotech outfit BioMerieux, which specializes in the diagnosis of bacteria in the human body and infectious diseases like HIV and tuberculosis. Works in 130 countries. Last month the company announced its commitment to fight against emerging diseases with the launch of its Avian Flu detection test dubbed NucliSens EasyQ Influenza H5. Eldest son Rodolphe, Alain's intended successor, was tragically killed at the age of 27 when TWA Flight 800 crashed over Long Island in 1996. Second son Christophe, a doctor and BioMerieux's senior vice president of research and development, is now slated to take over in the next few years.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took control of fertilizer maker Uralkali in the mid-1990s. Last year Uralkali's market cap doubled, thanks mainly to strong global demand for potassium fertilizers. Currently accounts for 13% of global production, but wants to become the world's leader. Reinvests his capital in modernization projects.

name: Billionaires
bio: With the Labor party winning a third term, Lord Sainsbury continues to serve as Minister for Science and Innovation. His new initiative has been to bring about collaboration between business and innovation, a role he is uniquely qualified for given his business background. This politician owes his wealth to his family's iconic Sainsbury's grocery business, which has been struggling in recent years due to increased competition from rivals like Tesco and Wal-Mart. His fortune is held in a blind trust while he's in the government.

name: Billionaires
bio: Software maker endures stagnant growth. New chief executive arrived; lasted less than a year. Tried to appease angry shareholders with $13.5 million dividend; vowed to cut more costs to improve margins. What to do? Sell to former boss Larry Ellison&#39s Orcale for $5.8 billion; now dominant player in customer relationship management software. Personal foundation tackles methamphetamine addiction in Montana.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of American Pharmaceutical Partners, recently announced plans to sell his privately held drug development firm, American Bioscience, (and owner of 64% of American Pharmaceutical) to the publically traded company. Stock catapulted last year thanks to FDA approval of cancer drug Abraxane; uses particles of human protein albumin to deliver taxane directly to tumors. Development pipeline filled with other cancer-fighting drugs using biological interactive pathway to the tumor. South Africa native moved to U.S. for faculty position at UCLA’s medical school. Role at first company, VivoRx, collapsed after tangling with investors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Co-founder of Royal Caribbean Cruises; cruise behemoth remains the tent pole of the family business. While the industry came under Congressional spotlight with the mysterious disappearance of a Greenwich honeymooner, family was busy expanding its maritime empire through oil driller Awilco Offshore. Chair of the family&#39s investment company, with stakes in oil tankers, Russian hotels and shopping centers in the Baltic States. Son Alexander replaced him on Royal Caribbean’s board in 2003.

name: Billionaires
bio: Loaned family friend Fred DeLuca (see) $1,000 to open sandwich shop to help pay for college. Shop floundered, but DeLuca opened second outlet to create aura of success. Since then the partners have opened 18,864 Subway shops in the U.S., giving Subway more domestic storefronts than McDonald’s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former auto repair shop owner and Michelin engineer, John Caudwell entered the cell phone business in 1987. In his first eight months, he sold just 26 phones from his store in hardscrabble Stoke-on-Trent. Sales reached $3.6 billion in 2005. Now Caudwell is looking to sell his business. An avid sportsman, Caudwell did an 18-day, 2,300-mile bike ride from Athens to London to raise money for The Caudwell Charity, which helps sick, disabled and terminally ill children.

name: Billionaires
bio: Majority owner of electric power plants and copper, aluminum and soda ash mines in Turkey. Also smaller interests in gasoline and aviation services sectors. Building a new media center in desirable Taksim neighborhood of Istanbul. His media company Merkez has a licensing agreement with Forbes to publish Forbes Turkey. Also owns apple farms on the outskirts of Istanbul. Personally pays for much school construction throughout Turkey.

name: Billionaires
bio: Opened his first drugstore in 1969. Now the Jean Coutu Group has 2,175 stores in Canada and the U.S, which makes it North America&#39s fourth-largest pharmacy chain. Coutu reclaimed his title as chief executive last year from his son François, three years after he&#39d stepped down. Coutu took back the reins in a management shakeout following a poor showing on the stock market.

name: Billionaires
bio: Family friend Pter Buck (see) fronted DeLuca $1,000 to open sandwich shop to help pay for college. Shop floundered, but DeLuca opened second outlet to create aura of success. Since then the partners have opened 18,864 Subway shops in the U.S., giving Subway more domestic storefronts than McDonald’s.

name: Billionaires
bio: “Red” operated small lumber mill with father in 1940s. Took Sierra Pacific Public 1969; private again 5 years later. Borrowed $460 million to buy 522,000 acres in 1988. Construction boom keeps sawmills buzzing. New mill in Aberdeen, Washington is his first in the state. Two sons active in the business. Largest private landowner in California still sparring with environmentalists, despite having sold thousands of acres to appease preservationists.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a Texas farmer bought first bank in 1975 for $1.2 million, later sold for $80 million. Biggest score: with Ronald Perelman (see), sold California’s Golden State Bancorp to Citigroup for $6 billion in 2002; personal stake now worth $1 billion. Other investments include auto-finance companies AmeriCredit, Triad; oil and gas outfit McMoRan Exploration. Still searching for another windfall in banking. Downtime split between 140,000-acre cattle ranch in New Mexico, home to 15 families, and compound in the Hamptons.

name: Billionaires
bio:
With brother William (see), heads Li & Fung, the $6 billion (sales) global
outsourcing giant that supplies clothes and accessories to such retailers as
Disney and Bed, Bath & Beyond. Links American and European consumers to
factories in 40 countries. Grandfather Fung Pakliu started company a century
ago in Guangzhou with partner Li To-ming; duo sold porcelain, antiques.
Father Fung Hon-chu ran companies while brothers studied business in
America; they returned to take helm 1970s. William is managing director;
Victor is chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio:
With brother Victor (see), heads Li & Fung, the $6 billion (sales) global

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited Gerling Konzern, one of the world’s largest reinsurers, from his father. The company, in which he had a 94% stake, was sold to Germany’s Talanx Group in November for an estimated $1.6 billion. The billionaire now focuses on his Gerling Academy for Risk Research, a think tank that studies the industrial world’s impact on the environment.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started small investment portfolio from Harvard dorm room as freshman in 1986 after reading article on Home Shopping Network in FORBES; managed $1 million by senior year. Started Citadel Investment Group with $1 million investment from trader Frank Meyer 1990. Today manages at least $12 billion in assets. Stiff fees: 20% of profits, all corporate expenses paid by investors.

name: Billionaires
bio: High-risk investor husband, John Murdoch Harbert III (d. 1995), turned $6,000 winnings from craps table into large construction outfit: airports, power plants, Mideast water supply systems. Bought coal reserves in eastern Kentucky, Tennessee late 1960s. Cashed out during energy crisis for large stake in Amoco. Today son Raymond manages family fortune.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Berlin, Jarislowsky moved to Canada in 1949 after receiving his M.B.A. at Harvard. Six years later founded Jarislowsky-Fraser, which on behalf of institutional clients and high-net-worth individuals today manages $50 billion, up 20% in the last year. A champion of corporate governance in Canada, this year he cofounded the Institute for Governance of Private & Public Organizations, a research and training center in Montreal. His book Investment Zoo was a business bestseller in Canada last year, in both French and English. In addition to an eclectic art collection, which includes jade, Chinese furniture and Eskimo artifacts, owns private island in British Columbia with 16 miles of shoreline.

name: Billionaires
bio: Child of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), great-grandson of parquet-flooring salesman who founded wax company 1886. Sam joined 1954, chairman 1967. Expanded with household cleaning staples (Glade, Pledge, Windex), bug repellents (Off, Raid). Today S.C. Johnson employs 12,000 people worldwide, sells products in more than 110 countries. Though private about profitability, took sideline outdoor equipment company Johnson Outdoors public 1987. Also majority interest in bank holding company Johnson Financial Group. Sam handed companies over to fifth generation; remained public face through series of folksy ads. All kids sent to alma mater Cornell University before entering family business. Fisk: chairman and CEO of SC Johnson. Family commissioned Frank Lloyd Wright to design corporate headquarters in Racine. Big backers of Cornell, Smithsonian Institution, Nature Conservancy, Racine Art Museum, Mayo Clinic.

bio: Widow of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), great-grandson of parquet-flooring salesman who founded wax company 1886. Sam joined 1954, chairman 1967. Winnie: president of Johnson Family Foundation. Family commissioned Frank Lloyd Wright to design corporate headquarters in Racine. name: Billionaires
bio: Son of H.S. Kim, owner of Korean chipmaker Anam Semiconductor. Immigrated to U.S. 1955. Created Amkor Technologies 1968 as U.S. sales arm for father’s chip business. Took public 30 years later. Second fortune in gaming. Wife, Agnes, started Electronics Boutique retail chain 1977; sold last year to GameStop for $1.4 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited a stake in her late father’s construction group Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas, which she ran with sister Esther from 1989 to 1997. Sold out to her sister in 1997 for $800 million and has astutely invested the proceeds in companies like Enagos, Endesa, Inditex and Banco Sabadel; hotels in Spain, Italy and Portugal; and U.S. real estate. She also has a charitable foundation, Fundación Vida y Esperanza, which focuses on helping children and adolescents. The divorced Spanish beauty is rumored to be romantically involved with the Duque of Huescar, heir to the Spanish aristocratic house of Alba.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a used-car salesman quit job with Dad to sell used computers after placing $3 dollar ad in Chicago Tribune to sell old PC. Saw potential in discount computer sales, started Computer Discount Warehouse 1984. Today CDW sells $6 billion in computer gear, mostly to businesses, government. Stepped down as chief executive in 2001, spends time managing personal portfolio; invests in low-risk stocks and bonds.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wharton grad made first fortune selling contact-lens-design company to Cooper Labs for $60 million in 1971. Acquired New Jersey cable licenses; sold Vision Cable for $220 million in 1982. Later built cell phone business Metro Mobile, sold to Bell Atlantic for $2.6 billion 1992. Via natural gas distributor Southern Union, bought pipelines from Enron in bankruptcy, now nation’s third-largest pipeline owner.

name: Billionaires
bio: Rode a  wave of investor enthusiasm over Macau by cleverly injecting a casino business into his  Hong Kong-listed construction company in 2005. Chairs the new entity, Galaxy  Entertainment; also chairman of the Federation of Hong Kong Hotel Owners. Two  children sit on Galaxy’s board.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother J.W. Jr., sons of J.W. Marriott Sr. (d. 1985), who started service empire with root beer stand Hot Shoppe in 1927; became regional chain. Added first hotel, Twin Bridges, 1957. Willard Jr. named president 1964. Built hotels and restaurants, exited latter in 1989. Since 1993 brothers split company amid bondholder protest: Richard heads hotel owner Host Marriott; Willard Jr. controls manager and franchiser Marriott International. Active Mormons fund education, help disabled people find jobs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Indispensable, if overshadowed, adjunct of Warren Buffett. Berkshire Hathaway vice chairman since 1979, known for detailed analysis, oft-quoted “Mungerisms,” many of which can be found in new book Poor Charlie’s Almanac: “We have three baskets for investing: yes, no, and too tough to understand.” Donated $40 million to Stanford, wife’s alma mater, for a new dormitory. Plans to leave fortune to his 8 children.

name: Billionaires
bio: Harvard M.B.A. runs Turkey's fifth-largest private bank as measured by consolidated assets. Helps finance other firms' receivables through his Fiba Holding subsidiaries. Gave scholarships and supplied textbooks to more than 7,000 needy students in 2005. Irked Koc family (see Rahmi Koc)  when he sold his retail chain Gima to rival Sabanci Group's (see Erol Sabanci)  Carrefour SA for $132 million. Owns a shopping mall in Romania;     his Finansbank is also opening dozens of branches there.

name: Billionaires
bio: Known to her friends as Lottie, she is the second-largest shareholder of Hennes & Mauritz, the successful Swedish clothing retail chain founded by her father, Erling, in 1947 and now run by her brother Stefan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Legendary raider winning big on rising price of crude. Last year said oil would reach $60 a barrel when it was trading in the $40s; predicted oil would hit $75 by the end of the year. Graduated from Oklahoma State U. with geology degree, founded Mesa Petroleum in 1956 with $2,500. Sold to Richard Rainwater (see). Made name with hostile takeover runs on Gulf, Phillips, Unocal. These days running oil and gas investment shop BP Capital, trying to capitalize on lucrative water rights in Texas Panhandle. Septuagenarian recently married widow of Gulfstream founder Allen Paulson.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Joseph, ran pharmacy in Brooklyn. Stewart took over after dropping out of law school, turned into pharmaceuticals distributor Kinray. Highly automated fulfillment, fat operating margins. Estimated sales: $3.5 billion. Recently bought East Hampton, N.Y. estate for record $45 million, but drives to work in 10-year-old Jeep Cherokee. “I’m just a regular guy.”

name: Billionaires
bio:
Head of Turkey1s Dogus Holding conglomerate at least relinquished some
control of prized Garanti Bank, selling a quarter of the country's third
largest bank to General Electric for $1.6 billion. Dick Grasso-lookalike
also lords over media properties capturing more than 10% of country1s
advertising market. Schooled at Boston College and Harvard1s Presidential
Management Program. Bankrolled "Gallipoli" movie about seminal Turkish
military battle against the Allied offensive. Harvard Business School case
study documents challenges in taking his father1s traditionally managed
company. Recently threw a party during Davos Economic Forum attended by pal
Recep Tayyip Erdogan, prime minister of Turkey.

name: Billionaires
bio: Spend it or save it: either way, U. of Virginia law grad makes money. Founded first real estate investment trust 1964, second REIT Saul Centers in 1993. Company owns 41 strip malls, shopping centers; holds 40% stake. Founded Chevy Chase Bank 1969 out of a trailer, now Washington, D.C. area’s largest bank. Explosive growth driven by booming mortgage and home equity loan markets; net income up 68% in 2004. Trustee of Johns Hopkins School of Medicine, member of Library of Congress Trust Fund Board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Schooled in Madras, India; created shop bot Junglee. Sold to Amazon in 1998. Later backed tech outfits Yodlee, 24/7 Customer, Plaxo, Zazzle.com. Bubble era taught him to adapt: “Living in a world where everything is changing constantly, you learn to change.” Views self as “Sherpa” investor rather than angel because it makes him feel more like a guide than a checkbook. Early investor, board member of Google. Sold $400 million in Google stock at offering, still owns more than 3 million shares.

name: Billionaires
bio: Risked creation of for-profit University of Phoenix 1976 after bosses at San Jose State University turned down proposal. Today nation’s largest private university system allows working adults to complete bachelor’s, master’s degrees in classroom or online. Went public as Apollo Group in 1994. Announcement last month that enrollment is slowing triggered massive selloff; shares down 15.5% in one day, wiping out $1.6 billion in value (market cap, at $17 billion two years ago, now hovering at $8.7 billion). John resigned as chairman in 2004; son Peter serves as Apollo senior vice president.

name: Billionaires
bio: With siblings Ronda and Jon (see both) controls Stryker Corp., medical supply company founded by grandfather Homer (d. 1980). Low-profile heiress becoming more active in civic life: donated $3 million to defeat 2002 ballot initiative that would have gutted bilingual education in Colorado. Bought Sonoma’s Sommer Vineyards in 1999, rebuilt, replanted, changed name to Stryker Sonoma: 32 acres in Alexander Valley, producer of classic vinifera varietals, chardonnay and zinfandel.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Philippines' king of malls owns 23 shopping centers. This year plans to open his massive Mall of Asia on the capital Manila's waterfront. Expected to be 386,000 square meters and feature the country's first Olympic-size skating rink. Will also have an IMAX movie theater. Recently started buying stakes in local banks.

name: Billionaires
bio:
With fellow Brazilian billionaires and former investment banking partners
Jorge Paulo Lemann and Carlos Alberto Sicupira (see both), Telles invested
in and helped build AmBev into the world's third-largest brewer by volume
before it merged with Interbrew of the Netherlands in 2004 to form InBev.
Telles sits on the board of InBev, which is expanding in developing
countries like China. Telles is reportedly a keen spearfisher and likes to
spend time in Monaco.

name: Billionaires
bio: “Andy” is one of the smartest-yet least-well-known-denizens of the digital world. One recent big win: He wrote Google&#39s Sergey Brin and Larry Page (see both) a $100,000 check in 1998 before they had even incorporated the company. Six years later that investment is worth $400 million, launching him into The Forbes 400. Has been a high-tech hotshot in Silicon Valley for 2 decades. Born in Germany, came to U.S. for master&#39s in electrical engineering from Carnegie Mellon University. While working toward a Ph.D. at Stanford, he invented one of the first network workstations. With help from Vinod Khosla and Scott McNealy, turned underlying programming into Sun&#39s Solaris operating system. Left to start network switch outfit Granite Systems; sold it to Cisco in 1996 for $220 million in stock. Left Cisco last December to run Kealia, a computer system design company that he sold to Sun 4 months later for $93 million in Sun stock. Now back with buddy McNealy as Sun&#39s chief architect. Also investor in chip-designing-software maker Magma Design Automation. Once lived in a big house in Woodside, Calif. with large staff; now lives alone in small Palo Alto apartment.

name: Billionaires
bio: Career manager held posts at Hasbro, Keds, Disney, Procter & Gamble, before landing at Ebay in 1998. Harvard M.B.A. led company through Internet bust, spectacular rebound catering to loyal trading communities. Expanding: pending deal for Web-phone outfit Skype for $2.6 billion; bought comparison pricing site Shopping.com. Plans to infuse fledgling China operation, Eachnet, with $100 million. Now girding for battle against Asian auction giant Alibaba. “Meg” once rumored to be on shortlist to succeed Michael Eisner at Disney; became a board member of DreamWorks Animation instead.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took his Peel Holdings private in 2004. Last year led the group's $1.3 billion takeover of Mersey Docks & Harbour Co. in a bid to revitalize the Liverpool waterfront. Group's other holdings include Manchester's Trafford Centre, the UK's largest shopping center; investment properties, airports and ports. An environmentalist, Whittaker steered Peel to win government approval in May to set up a wind farm near Rochdale in the greater Manchester area. Owns Billown Mansion on the Isle of Man.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brothers Dirk and Robert (see both). Father, William Ziff Jr., built Ziff-Davis publishing empire (PC Magazine, Car & Driver, Boating), sold for $1.4 billion in 1994, retired to Florida. Siblings reinvest proceeds via Ziff Brothers Investments: hedge funds, corporate debt, equities, small stake in DreamWorks SKG.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brothers Daniel and Robert (see both). Father, William Ziff Jr., built Ziff-Davis publishing empire (PC Magazine, Car & Driver, Boating), sold for $1.4 billion in 1994, retired to Florida. Siblings reinvest proceeds via Ziff Brothers Investments: hedge funds, corporate debt, equities, small stake in DreamWorks SKG.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brothers Daniel and Dirk (see both). Father, William Ziff Jr., built Ziff-Davis publishing empire (PC Magazine, Car & Driver, Boating), sold for $1.4 billion in 1994, retired to Florida. Siblings reinvest proceeds via Ziff Brothers Investments: hedge funds, corporate debt, equities, small stake in DreamWorks SKG.

name: Billionaires
bio: Controls 54-year-old trading company with more than 10,000 employees. Serves as exclusive agent in the UAE for Toyota, Dodge, IBM, Volvo, Jeep, Chrysler, Fossil, Black & Decker, Seiko and Panasonic. Most lucrative operation is Toyota dealer network, Al-Futtaim Motors. It is also the largest distributor of automotive products in the Emirates. Split business ties with brother Majid Al Futtaim (see) in the early 1990s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Became president of family-run conglomerate during a Kuwaiti economic downturn in the 1980s. Under his leadership the group has expanded marketing and strategic alliances with Xerox, American Express, Minolta and others. Now employs 4,000 from 32 countries around the world.  Brother Kutuyba (see) is also a new billionaire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Splits stake in the family company with brother Bassam (see). Got feet wet in trading business founded by father Yusef, Alghanim Industries. Rode economic expansion in Kuwait during the 1970s and diversified firm into marketing and trading alliance with Hitachi, British Airways, Philips and Frigidaire, among others, as chief operating officer. These days the UC, Berkeley grad leads Gulf Bank through tremendously profitable period-the bank's 52% profit margins are twice as large as banking sector peers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Early taste of business selling popcorn outside father’s barbershop. To UCLA on hockey scholarship; Harvard M.B.A.; law degree from Loyola. After learning beverage distribution business from clients, formed Ace Beverage 1956, landed exclusive rights to distribute then-minor beer brand Budweiser in Los Angeles. Now owns 14 distributorships from Hawaii to the Virgin Islands. Also car dealerships (Silver Star Automotive), insurance, real estate (1.3 million square feet commercial space in LA).

name: Billionaires
bio: Got real estate license 1962; bought, sold corner lots at busy intersections to gas stations. Started renting apartments 1968. Today Arnel & Affiliates real estate outfit develops, manages property in southern California. Former ambassador to Spain tends to other investments via Westar Capital.

name: Billionaires
bio: Family’s Bass Enterprises hit hard by Katrina: oil storage tank near New Orleans leaked 90,000 barrels into containment pond. But gains from oil boom more than make up for it. Drilling in the western states, Gulf of Mexico and internationally. Planning new deepwater oil wells off Nova Scotia. Family fortune founded by oil baron uncle Sid Richardson. Diversified into Disney, John Wiley & Sons publishing and Human Genome Sciences. Big shots of Fort Worth: Sid runs investments, Lee avid outdoorsman, Ed does real estate and backed Biosphere 2 project. Other brother Robert (see) invests on his own.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner Judd Malkin, ran powerhouse JMB Realty during 1980s, managed $26 billion in office buildings, shopping malls, apartments, hotels. Pummeled by real estate downturn early 1990s; stuck it out, now enjoying rising values. Developing Niagara Falls casino with Pritzker family (see). Controls Four Seasons hotels in Chicago, Scottsdale, Ariz. Backed Barack Obama’s successful U.S. Senate run.

name: Billionaires
bio: With sister Denise York inherited pro football’s San Francisco 49ers franchise and shopping mall empire started by father, Edward Sr. Denise took the team, Ed got shares in Simon DeBartolo REIT. Notre Dame grad also runs DeBartolo Holdings: Ed & Eddie’s Homemade Ice Cream, food chain Famiglia DeBartolo, Web site designer I-Global Networks.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Edwards has more at stake in the Canadian oil sands than possibly any other
individual. His company, Canadian Natural Resources, has sketched out plans
to spend $25 billion to turn the gucky mud found in northern Alberta into barrels of crude. This media shy lawyer-turned financier also owns big stakes in Ensign Energy, Canada's second biggest oil services company, and Penn West, one of Canada's biggest energy trusts. Also owns Lake Louise, Canada's famous ski hill, and a chunk of the Calgary Flames hockey team.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Curtis, borrowed $55 in 1938 to produce trading stamps for grocery store promotions. Became Gold Bond Stamp Co. Diversified into hotels 1960s (Radisson Hotels & Resorts) and restaurants (T.G.I. Friday’s), travel agencies in 1970s. Renamed Carlson Cos. became travel-hospitality-marketing conglomerate: Radisson, Country Inns, Regent International Hotels, Radisson Seven Seas Cruises, Carlson Wagonlit travel agencies. With sister Marilyn Nelson, inherited business after father’s death in 1999. Marilyn now the globe-trotting chairman of $8.4 billion (sales) company. Overseeing major push into Asia: deal for 14 new properties in India, expanding T.G.I. Friday’s eateries in China, Taiwan. Barbara serves on the Carlson Cos. board of directors, runs family foundation, active with children’s charities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited retailer from Polish-immigrant parents; sold it to his brother-in-law in 1985. Built own fortune in shopping centers. Now diversifying for the future. In October announced he'd be divesting his stakes in entities that manage his properties. Bought a 50% stake in an Israeli water irrigation company earlier this year. He and his wife collect Japanese art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Also known as the Viscount Rothermere, Harmsworth assumed leadership of the Daily Mail & General Trust (DMGT) newspaper conglomerate from his late father when he was just 30 years old. Now 38, he's proven adept at guiding DMGT in a shrinking U.K. newspaper market. Under his leadership the group has been diversifying its holdings; today 44% of its business is non-newspaper, compared to 15% ten years ago.

name: Billionaires
bio: The cousin of Mexico's richest man, Carlos Slim Helu, Harp made his fortune in 2001, when Citigroup bought Banamex. Today he's an active philanthropist, serving as president of two Banamex-affiliated foundations. A baseball fanatic, Harp also owns the Red Devils, a minor league team in Mexico City.

name: Billionaires
bio: Erstwhile hippie opened first store in 1970 near U. of Pennsylvania with $4,000; sold trendy clothes to cash-strapped college kids. Expanded. Eschews advertising: lures customers with ever-changing displays, vivid color schemes, inviting floor plan. Today Urban Outfitters operates 155 stores under 3 brand lines (including Free People, Anthropologie). Sales: $800 million. Employees travel around the world to spot new trends, buy merchandise.
