name: Billionaires
bio: USC grad worked as researcher at International Rectifier; founded AMAZ Technology 1987. Then Cogent 1990: provider of automated fingerprint-identification systems, including MobileIDENT. Customers: Department of Homeland Security, Federal Bureau of Prisons, FBI.

name: Billionaires
bio: Salty-tongued tort lawyer still going strong. This year represented victims of BP refinery explosions near Houston. Company got scared, settled with his 12 clients for “very substantial” amounts. Started in DA’s office, formed own firm 1955. Built business on personal injury cases. Big score handling Texaco-Pennzoil merger 1987: received estimated $345 million in fees. Big donor to alma mater U. of Texas. Enjoys the finer things: shrimp and beer.

name: Billionaires
bio: MIT engineer runs the $1.5 billion (sales) Kalyani group. Flagship Bharat Forge is the world's second-largest forgings manufacturer, with customers including Ford, General Motors, Toyota, Honda and DaimlerChrysler. Group is building capacity overseas with acquisitions in the U.S. and Europe.

name: Billionaires
bio: Accordion-playing fire-breather turned circus icon, Laliberté founded Cirque du Soleil in 1984 with a gang of street performing friends. Initially funded by the Canadian government, the Montreal-based circus, which has no animals, no speaking and no star performers, became a for-profit group in 1985. Laliberté eventually bought out his majority partner in 2000. Hit the jackpot in 1991 when Steve Wynn brought Cirque to Las Vegas. Today the $550 million (revenues) group has four permanent shows in Sin City, including the $165 million “Ka,” which opened in February 2005 at MGM Grand. Produces a total of ten shows, with another three on the way. Next show in Vegas: Beatles-themed production at the Mirage; show will replace Siegfried & Roy. Known for lavish parties, Laliberté, who dreams of one day traveling into space, owns 95% of the company.

name: Billionaires
bio:
With fellow Brazilian billionaire Luiz Seabra (see), Leal helped build
Natura Cosméticos into the largest direct-sales cosmetics company in Brazil.
Leal, now cochairman, joined Natura in 1979. Spurred by his belief in
sustainable development, he helped spearhead a Natura product line that uses
renewable ingredients from the Brazilian rainforest. Leal is active on the
boards of several nonprofit groups including the World Wildlife Fund in
Brazil.

name: Billionaires
bio: Younger sister of Korea&#39s richest man, Samsung head Kun Hee-Lee (see). Mrs. Lee heads Shinsegae, which means “a new world,” South Korea&#39s leading discount retailer, with 81 E-Mart stores. It also operates seven high-end department stores that cater to South Korea&#39s affluent shoppers. Shinsegae is now expanding aggressively in China, with plans to open 50 discount stores there by 2020.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of Al Lerner (d. 2002), founder of credit card giant MBNA and savior of Cleveland Browns pro football franchise. Family sold 40% of stake in MBNA to pay taxman; will convert the rest to shares and cash pending $35 billion sale to Bank of America; merger will create country’s largest credit card lender. Struggling Browns still a keeper. Former prosecuting attorney Nancy keeps low profile, but known for Cleveland-area philanthropy, especially medical causes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of Al Lerner (d. 2002), founder of credit card giant MBNA and savior of Cleveland Browns pro football franchise. Family sold 40% of stake in MBNA to pay taxman; will convert the rest to shares and cash pending $35 billion sale to Bank of America; merger will create country’s largest credit card lender. Struggling Browns still a keeper. Norma keeps low profile, but known for Cleveland-area philanthropy, especially medical causes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Al Lerner (d. 2002), founder of credit card giant MBNA and savior of Cleveland Browns pro football franchise. Family sold 40% of stake in MBNA to pay taxman; will convert the rest to shares and cash pending $35 billion sale to Bank of America; merger will create country’s largest credit card lender. Struggling Browns still a keeper. Randy shook up management after recent losing seasons, hired new coach Romeo Crennel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Real estate tycoon had a busy year. Sales have been brisk at his red-hot Xintiandi   development in downtown Shanghai.  Lo backed China's version of Donald Trump's The Apprentice. Ironically, Trump sued Lo and other Hong Kong real estate partners for allegedly selling prime New York property for allededly selling prime New York property for too paltry sum of  $1.8 billion. Case was dismissed. Lo and the other investors took the proceeds and bought a prominent building in San Francisco, California.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cogen Technologies founder opted for mostly cash when he sold the nation’s largest privately held power company to Enron for $1.5 billion in 1999. Became hometown hero bringing Texans pro football expansion team to Houston. Avid horseman controls Stonerside Stables, winner of 59 Graded Stake horse races. Civic-minded: taking leading role in project to revitalize downtown Houston with pedestrian-friendly streets and gardens.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Curtis, borrowed $55 in 1938 to produce trading stamps for grocery store promotions. Became Gold Bond Stamp Co. Diversified into hotels 1960s (Radisson Hotels & Resorts) and restaurants (T.G.I. Friday’s), travel agencies in 1970s. Renamed Carlson Cos. became travel-hospitality-marketing conglomerate: Radisson, Country Inns, Regent International Hotels, Radisson Seven Seas Cruises, Carlson Wagonlit travel agencies. With sister Barbara Gage, inherited business after father’s death in 1999. Marilyn now the globe-trotting chairman of $8.4 billion (sales) company. Overseeing major push into Asia: deal for 14 new properties in India, expanding T.G.I. Friday’s eateries in China, Taiwan. Barbara serves on the Carlson Cos. board of directors, runs family foundation, active with children’s charities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Prickly money manager sold Heine Securities to Franklin Resources for $670 million and 5-year employment contract in 1996. Now manages private firm, MFP Investors: at least $1.6 billion under management, much of it his own money. Reputation for painstaking analysis, shaking up management. Disputes Forbes net worth estimate: “You guys make things up about people every year, so you can keep making things up about me.”

name: Billionaires
bio: At 83, Riegel still runs $1.7 billion (sales) confectioner Haribo with his brother Paul. He is often the one to concoct new products and is credited with inventing more than 200 confections including the popular Gummi Bears, Vademecum sugar-free gum and Maoam fruit chewies. Apparently gets his inspiration from reading comic books and watching movies for children. A bachelor with no children, has reportedly had a falling out with his heir apparent, nephew Hans-Jürgen Riegel, who has left the company.

name: Billionaires
bio:
The father of Brazil&#39s homegrown Avon. Seabra founded Natura Cosméticos in
1969 with a single shop in Sao Paulo. In the 1970s he adopted the
door-to-door sales model pioneered by Avon. Today the company has 519,000
“consultants” peddling creams and makeup in Brazil, Argentina, Chile, Mexico and Peru. Seabra serves as cochairman with fellow billionaire Guilherme Leal (see). The company went public in Brazil in May 2004.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stock car racing front man watched first auto race as an 8-year-old. Began promoting events on a dirt track in Midland, N.C. as a teenager. Launched Charlotte Motor Speedway in 1960, went bankrupt just 2 years later. Rebounded with Speedway Motorsports: 6 tracks that host 11 Nascar Cup series. Took public 1995; expanding ever since with better tracks, additional seating. Set to enter drag race market with recent offer to purchase National Hot Rod Association. Owns stakes in car dealerships, supports child-related causes via Speedway Children’s Charities. Pledged $50 million for monorail project near original Charlotte speedway.

name: Billionaires
bio: After bosses at San Jose State University turned down his father&#39s proposal, father and son team risked creation of for-profit University of Phoenix 1976. Today nation’s largest private university system allows working adults to complete bachelor’s, master’s degrees in classroom or online. Went public as Apollo Group in 1994. Announcement last month that enrollment is slowing triggered massive selloff; shares down 15.5% in one day, wiping out $1.6 billion in value (market cap, at $17 billion two years ago, now hovering at $8.7 billion). John resigned as chairman in 2004; son Peter serves as Apollo senior vice president.

name: Billionaires
bio: Radio reports of Charles Lindbergh’s transatlantic flight inspired this Kentucky farm boy to open hamburger stand near his school to pay for flying lessons. Dropped out of U. of Kentucky to pursue flying; spent 10 years flying with PanAm. Launched pilot training school FlightSafety International in 1951. Went public 1968. Sold to Warren Buffett 1996; received 16,000 shares of Berkshire Hathaway stock. Main diversion: Orbis International, nonprofit dedicated to reducing blindness in Third World countries using airplanes as mobile ophthalmological labs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Queen of all media wrapping up her second decade ruling the airwaves. Born in rural Mississippi. Moved to Milwaukee, then Tennessee. Became TV newscaster in Nashville and Baltimore; emotional, ad-lib delivery prompted shift to talk format. Joined Chicago TV station; turned third-rated morning show into number 1. Launched The Oprah Winfrey Show nationally in 1986. Owns property in Chicago, Hawaii, Santa Barbara. Gives to needy women, children and families via Oprah’s Angel Network and her personal charity, the Oprah Winfrey Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: This metals magnate is experiencing a re-birth of sorts. In the 1990s was one of the best-known Russian businessmen, co-owner of aluminum plants and the bank Rossiyskiy Kredit. In 2000 sold all his holdings in Russia and was quiet for four years. Then in 2004 he made a triumphant comeback as co-owner, with Alisher Usmanov, of the Metalloinvest holding company, one of Russia&#39s largest ore-mining and processing firms. Anisimov&#39s wholly-owned Coalco  has recently acquired a large livestock farm in Moscow region and is accumulating commercial property in Moscow and New York; his socialite daughter Anna who lives in Manhattan was dubbed a “Russian Paris Hilton” by New York magazine.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Philanthropist shares Koc Group fortune with brother Rahmi and sister Suna
(see both). Holds board seat at conglomerate but does not manage any
business unit. Delivered speech to graduating class of Robert College in
Istanbul, saying "life is full of surprises." Due to parasite in her blood,
spent years fighting illness in hospitals around the world, and moved her to
build nursing education and research center in Turkey, and marry a doctor.
Fluent in English and German.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fired from now-defunct Handy Dan Improvement Center, founded Home Depot with Bernard Marcus (see) in 1978, pioneered big-box do-it-yourself stores. Hardware giant now 1,800 locations; youngest retailer to surpass $70 billion sales milestone. Owner of NFL’s Atlanta Falcons made quarterback Michael Vick pro football’s highest-paid player with 10-year, $130 million contract in December 2004. Also owns Georgia Force arena football team.

name: Billionaires
bio: William Morris graduate made his name in Hollywood, then turned to the Internet. “I’m not finished, because I’m still curious.” Controls stakes in dozens of Web sites together worth more than $10 billion. In August split InterActiveCorp into 2 companies: travel-based Expedia (Hotels.com, Expedia.com); other businesses under IAC (including Ask Jeeves). “IAC focuses on the myriad ways people are moving aspects of their daily lives to the Net.” Married to fashion’s Diane von Furstenberg.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brothers Roberts and William (see both). Parents sold records and jeans to San Francisco teens in generation “gap” 1969. Opened 6 stores within first year, took Gap public 1976. Expanded with Banana Republic (1983), Gap Kids (1986), low-price chain Old Navy (1994). Now 3,000 stores worldwide. Profits slipped late 1990s when clothing became too trendy; sales rose with return to classic cuts. New chain, Forth & Towne, tailored for women over 35. Last August parents, Doris and Donald, distributed control of company, nearly half of stock holdings, to children. John co-owns pro baseball’s Oakland A’s, donates to KIPP schools for underprivileged.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brothers Robert and John (see both). Parents sold records and jeans to San Francisco teens in generation “gap” 1969. Opened 6 stores within first year, took Gap public 1976. Expanded with Banana Republic (1983), Gap Kids (1986), low-price chain Old Navy (1994). Now 3,000 stores worldwide. Profits slipped late 1990s when clothing became too trendy; sales rose with return to classic cuts. New chain, Forth & Towne, tailored for women over 35. Last August parents, Doris and Donald, distributed control of company, nearly half of stock holdings, to children. William ran company’s international stores, resigned 1998.
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: Upstate New York native dropped out of high school to join Marines. Started cable TV empire in 1956 with $1,500, running wire from antennas. Purchased cable franchises; sold to Time Warner in 1996 for $2.8 billion. Parked most of the proceeds in private investment company Granite Associates. New focus on reviving the Catskills, farming. Developing arts center at Bethel Woods, site of original Woodstock festival in 1969.

name: Billionaires
bio: Low-key billionaire thrust into the limelight with $1.5 billion purchase of pro soccer’s Manchester United. Raised the ire of team’s rabid fans, raised hundreds of millions of dollars in preferred stock to help with the financing. Also owns Tampa Bay Buccaneers, pro football franchise worth $877 million. Real source of wealth less glitzy: holding company Zapata, its best-known big investment in fish-oil outfit Omega.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hot-sauce owner married Linda Marie Pace, daughter of Pace salsa founder David Pace. Began cutting vegetables in production line; became president 1977. With wife, bought company from family; then bought her half for $95 million during 1991 divorce. Sold whole enchilada 4 years later to Campbell Soup for $1.1 billion. Now back in salsa business through private equity firm Silver Ventures. Big stake in tomato company Desert Glory, salsa manufacturer San Antonio Farms. “Kit” cooking up something new: plans to retrofit San Antonio Pearl Brewery as a culinary school.

name: Billionaires
bio: Payroll rep saw niche providing small businesses with payroll services. Launched Paychex in 1971 with $3,000 and a credit card; expanded through franchise agreements, joint ventures. Took public in 1983. Today more than 100 offices nationwide. Stepped down in 2004 after 33 years at the helm; remains chairman. Cofounder of the New York State Independence Party, spent $90 million of his own money on three failed gubernatorial campaigns. Contemplating run on the GOP ticket for 2006. Charitable spending geared to education, hospitals. Donated $9 million to Rochester General. Owner of pro hockey’s Buffalo Sabres.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Gores Technology Group buyout firm 1987 after selling computers out of his father’s basement. Prefers to buy divisions of technology firms, merge them to create new companies. Conglomerate now has 30 companies, including Real Software, Adventa, Voicecom Telecommunications. Brother, Tom (see), runs Platinum Equity.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Mormon apartment caretakers got start managing hotel/gas station complex after college in Little America, Wyo. Bought 10% stake in operation, added stations in Utah, Arizona. Moved into refining as business grew; bought Sinclair Oil 1976. “Earl” diversified into hotels, including Sun Valley Ranch ski resort, home to Herb Allen’s (see) annual media mogul conference. Bought for $12 million, now worth over $300 million. Other resorts: Utah’s Snowbasin ski area and 395-suite Grand America Hotel, venues for the 2002 Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City. Modest: “Doing the best I know how with what I’ve got to do it with.”

name: Billionaires
bio:
Thank Brazilians' thirst for swank homes and apartments for Horn's debut
among the world's wealthiest this year. Cyrela Brazil Realty, which he
founded in 1978, is now the largest developer of luxury residential
buildings in Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo. Since the company went public in
September 2005, the stock price has doubled. Horn is known for giving 20% of
his earnings to charity.

name: Billionaires
bio: Studied to be pharmacist at Oklahoma University, opted to join father’s real estate brokerage instead. Founded home builder D.R. Horton 1978. Took public 1992. Sales: $11 billion. Prides himself on lavishing workers with perks. Employees’ kids use 86,000-acre corporate ranch in southwest Texas for summer camp. Special policy for reserves called up to fight; hold job, continue pay.

name: Billionaires
bio: Secretive sunglassmaker got start selling flashy motorcycle grips out of trunk of his car in 1975. Added goggles, sunglasses. Typically eschewed star-endorsement deals favored by Nike; instead, relied on knack for style, new lens technology (its polycarbonate material withstands shotgun blasts). Expanded into clothes (shoes, fire-resistant shirts and pants), accessories (wristwatches, backpacks), personal electronics (Thump sunglasses equipped with MP3 players; RazrWire shades armed with wireless Bluetooth technology). Shades account for only 50% of Oakley’s business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Kentucky native founded Commonwealth Brands tobacco company 1990, manufactured discounted cigarettes USA Gold, Bull Durham, Malibu. Undersold top names with low advertising costs. Sold for $1 billion in 2001. Owns 71% of Kentucky Downs racetrack; also holds minor stake in Churchill Downs, venue of Kentucky Derby. Also real estate: 1.2 million acres in Texas, Florida, New Mexico. Wildlife conservationist runs program to help zoos breed “hoofstock.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Good-natured buyout titan had a rough fall. After taking Warner Music public last May with Edgar Bronfman Jr., flipped commodities outfit Refco in August. Refco quickly fell apart after chief executive Peter Bennett accused of securities of fraud; company's assets bought up by London-based hedge fund Man Group. Harvard grad started investing with $150,000 inheritance 1974. Greatest hit: Snapple, bought for $135 million 1992, sold to Quaker Oats for $1.7 billion in 1994.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father made ricotta and mozzarella for local customers in the 1950s. Jim joined company at 18, turned Leprino Foods into world’s largest producer of mozzarella. Biggest customers: Pizza Hut, Domino’s, Papa John’s. Sales: at least $1.7 billion. Nine manufacturing plants process 1 million to 6 million pounds of milk per day—5% of U.S. milk supply. Loves the leftovers: excess whey sold as protein concentrate and lactose for baby formula, baked goods, animal feeds. Big GOP contributor. Expanding into Europe; joint venture with Glanbia, Continent’s largest maker of pizza cheese.

name: Billionaires
bio: Part of the Liu family, four brothers who made their  initial fortune in the feed industry starting in the 1980s, when Deng Xiaoping's economic reforms were taking route in the countryside. Liu Yongxing's East Hope is still one of the country's largest feed suppliers but has diversified into aluminum and invested in financial  institutions.

name: Billionaires
bio: Surgeon, inveterate tinkerer made small fortune patenting spinal cages and implants. Became billionaire after settling protracted patent suit with Medtronic for $1.4 billion. Bone of contention: implant that stabilizes, helps fuse vertebrae. Critics snipe that the patents were overly broad, but the devices now fueling big growth in the orthopedics business. Says he’ll give away bulk of his fortune in his lifetime.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Honeywell exec became Cisco chief in 1988. Took it public in 1990, stepped down in 1995 as stock turned into Internet bellwether; briefly was world’s most valuable company. Recently made $30 million gift to renovate a U. of Wisconsin education building.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nephew of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who, with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert, created industrial conglomerate Marmon (2004 sales: $6.4 billion) and hotel chain Hyatt (211 hotels worldwide). Plan to pass control of empire to Jay’s son Tom, cousin Nick and niece Penny collapsed in 2001; family agreed to carve up empire 11 ways. Family drama sparked by Robert’s 2 youngest children, Matthew and Liesel, who filed suit in Chicago and the Bahamas, where family maintains offshore trusts; each settled for $500 million. But dynastic carve-up, including sales or initial public offerings of Marmon and Hyatt to be completed before 2011, in perplexing standstill mode now. Nicholas runs Hyatt Development.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former chemical engineer has been hailed as the staid chemical industry's answer to steel magnate Lakshmi Mittal (see) due to his recent dealmaking. Ineos, the chemical company he founded and now chairs, paid $8.7 billion bid for BP Group's Innovene business last year, creating Britain's largest chemical company. Ratcliffe, who owns more than half of the $33 billion (2005 sales) combined entity, now must focus on generating enough cash flow to cover the deal's $10.7 billion debt load.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dropped out of college to flip burgers. Saved money, invested in oil, real estate. Now owns 41 acres on Las Vegas Strip, home to New Frontier hotel/casino. Land alone worth about $1 billion. Recently unveiled plans to knock down the New Frontier and build new $1.5 billion resort in its place. Side bet: partnering with Donald Trump. Pair broke ground on 64-story Trump International Hotel & Tower; plans for second tower in the works. Other holdings: convenience stores, hand-truck manufacturer.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Fashionista sister of Ferit Sahenk (see) and heir to Dogus Holding fortune,
built by father Ayhan, has handled retail partnerships with luxury brands
Tods and Armani. Advocate of women1s leadership and one of Turkey1s top 100
taxpayers also holds title of president at family1s active charitable
foundation, sponsor of well-known three-day annual international mountain
bike festival in the Cappadoccia region. Also active in the International
Myeloma Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio:
One of the trio of Brazilian investment bankers who turned a poorly managed
Brazilian beermaker into AmBev, one of the world's largest brewers, and then
merged it with Interbrew of the Netherlands in 2004 to form InBev. The
merger has paid off handsomely, with the stock up 40% in the last year. With
his investing partners and fellow billionaires Jorge Paulo Lemann and Marcel
Telles (see both), Sicupira also increased his investment in Brazilian
retailer Lojas Americanas last year. For fun, Sicupira enjoys underwater
spearfishing, for which he holds multiple world records.

name: Billionaires
bio: Left family’s bakery to break into construction, property management. Has built more than 80,000 units in 18 states. Just finished fancy 6-story office building in California’s San Joaquin County. Son Dean heads most valuable asset: pro football’s San Diego Chargers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief of Meriton Apartments, made his fortune building low-cost second-rate housing. Demand for his apartments has softened. To stay afloat, he is renting out more, rather than trying to sell the units. But believes the market is starting to turn in his favor. Also invests in stocks and bonds. Born in China to Russian parents who fled the country during the Bolshevik Revolution. Learned about real estate development as a child visiting his father, a builder, at work sites in Tientsin, China; immigrated to Australia at age 14. Owns three Bentleys; on alternate days his license plates read HOT1 and HOT2 (for his initials) and OSCAR1 (his middle name).

name: Billionaires
bio: His former Dutch TV production company Endemol launched the reality show craze with the creation of programs like Big Brother and Fear Factor. Made his fortune when he later sold Endemol to Spanish telecom giant Telefonica in 2000 for $5.3 billion. After that he turned his full attention to theater, a passion he’s had since childhood. (At age 6, van den Ende put on a puppet theater for neighborhood kids in his hometown.) Van den Ende is currently chairman at Stage Entertainment, a musical theater company and Endemol spin-off that is behind blockbuster musicals like The Lion King and Mamma Mia. Its U.S. division has won 46 TONY Awards. Last year, van den Ende partnered with Dutch real estate developers Trimp & van Tartwijk to build living and working districts that will all include a theater. Humble beginnings; started his career as a party-supply salesman.

name: Billionaires
bio: It can’t get too cold for Viessmann, the owner of a large manufacturer of boilers and heating equipment. The $1.4 billion (sales) Viessmann Werke GMBH was founded by his grandfather nearly 90 years ago. The company set up the Viessman Academy to provide training for heating architects and engineers; it also sponsors cold weather sports like skiing and sledding as well as Formula 1 racing. Outside of work Viessman is president of the Kassel Chamber of Commerce, treasurer of Marburg University and holds a professional pilot’s license.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father started sign company in 1935; Dean sold signs as 13-year-old. Dropped out of U. of Nebraska to attend U.S. Merchant Marine Academy. Took over business 1946, renamed Whiteco Industries; millionaire by age 40. Sold to Chancellor Media for $960 million in 1998. “At that price, I mean, what the heck?” Cheerful workaholic still thrives on billboards, real estate. Whiteco Qingyu the biggest billboard company in Shanghai, branching out into other Chinese cities. With wife, Barbara, gives to local universities, hospitals via Dean & Barbara White Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs Ayala Corp., the oldest and largest conglomerate in the Philippines, founded in 1834. Has interests in real estate, water and telecom, among other industries. For 2005 posted record profits of $150 million. Big environmentalist, chairs the Philippines branch of the World Wildlife Fund.

name: Billionaires
bio: Michigan State grad stepped down last year as chair of Janus, mutual fund outfit he started in 1969. No wonder: company still trying to shake off stigma of 2003 market-timing scandal. Fund managers accused of ripping off investors; firm settled with regulators in August 2004 for $100 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Family’s Bass Enterprises hit hard by Katrina: oil storage tank near New Orleans leaked 90,000 barrels into containment pond. But gains from oil boom more than make up for it. Drilling in the western states, Gulf of Mexico and internationally. Planning new deepwater oil wells off Nova Scotia. Family fortune founded by oil baron uncle Sid Richardson. Diversified into Disney, John Wiley & Sons publishing and Human Genome Sciences. Big shots of Fort Worth: Sid runs investments, Lee avid outdoorsman, Ed does real estate and backed Biosphere 2 project. Other brother Robert (see) invests on his own.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former loan processor, vending machine repairman invested in Silicon Valley commercial real estate with John Sobrato (see) in the 1960s. Struck out on own, formed Mission West Properties. Owns 8 million square feet in Silicon Valley; 100 tech investments.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fulbright scholar earned Ph.D. in electrical engineering from MIT, founded Bose Corp. 1964. First contracts with NASA, U.S. military, improving audio communications, but brand built on groundbreaking loudspeaker design. Introduced first factory-installed car stereo system 1982; today a major supplier for high-end automobiles (Porsche, Mercedes). Sales: $1.7 billion. Expanding product line: high-end headphones, wireless home entertainment centers, car-suspension systems.

name: Billionaires
bio: Housing boom boosts this accountant-turned-developer back into the billionaire rankings. LA-based builder of high-density inner-city real estate always up for a good fight: shouldered past community group protests to develop prime 4.5-acre plot in Westwood; squashed lawsuit brought by older brother who alleged he shirked bonus payments; never charged in political scandal involving employees who exceeded campaign contribution limits to LA candidates. Loyal backer of Jewish and Israeli causes, including Simon Wiesenthal Center’s Museum of Tolerance.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, William (d. 2002), recognized Asian market potential after serving in WWII, founded sourcing and logistics company in Tokyo 1949. “Chip” started working for Dad at age 12, took control of William E. Connor & Assoc. early 1980s, moved company to Hong Kong. Focused on apparel, home products. Today 35 offices in 20 countries around world. Estimated sales: $1.6 billion. Client list includes top retailers like Nordstrom, Dillard’s, Saks Fifth Avenue, Neiman Marcus.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former P&G product manager created Quicken checkbook-balancing software early in PC era. Founded Intuit with partner Tom Proulx; public 1993. Followed with TurboTax, Standard Payroll, QuickBooks. Since 1998 Intuit Tax Freedom Project donated free tax preparation to 11 million low-income people. Avid cyclist dreams of developing automated, instantaneous tax programs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Graduated from the University of Electronic Science &  Technology in China. Then in 1997 at age 26 founded Internet portal NetEase.  Company withstood a rocky period several years ago during which it delayed  issuing financial reports and trading of its Nasdaq shares was suspended. Ding  stepped into the role of chief executive in late November 2005 after the  untimely death of the greatly respected Ted Sun, who focused on online gaming  and calmly led the company out of turmoil.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Dodged a bullet when Mongolian government decided not to grab a stake in the
copper and gold deposit his NYSE-listed Ivanhoe Mines discovered in Mongolia. This Chicago-born mining promoter has been touting the discovery. He made his first fortune in 1994 after stumbling onto one of the world's biggest nickel deposits while searching for diamonds in Voisey's Bay, Nfld. Sold Diamond Fields Resources in 1996 for $3.1 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: French literature major at U. of Pennsylvania, premed at Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Invented disposable biopsy device 1971. Took over Key Pharmaceuticals, developed new delivery systems for old drugs. Sold to Schering-Plough in 1986. Founded Ivax year later, now one of largest generic drug companies. Miami’s Frost Art Museum currently under construction.

name: Billionaires
bio: President of Benesse Corp., which his father founded. The company is best known for its distance learning and test prep schools that train children to pass entrance exams to get them into prestigious schools and universities. Some 4 million Japanese children between the ages of 3 and 18 are enrolled at Benesse. Despite graying trend of Japanese population, sales hit a record high of $2.5 billion and net profit jumped 52% to $124 million for the year ending March 2005. A modern art lover, Fukutake is also the head of a contemporary art museum on a southern island facing inland Sea of Japan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of coffee magnate Max Herz. With her five children, Günter, Joachim, Michael, Wolfgang, and Daniela (see all), inherited a fortune from her late husband Max Herz. She personally controls 15% of her late husband&#39s legacy, Tchibo Holding, the German consumer goods group. Sons Michael, Wolfgang and Joachim hold the rest. Daughter Daniela and son Günter cashed out in 2003 after a nasty family feud.

name: Billionaires
bio: Digital-dish-loving, cable-hating TV watchers owe something to “Stub” (pronounced “stoob”). Father, Stanley Eugene Hubbard (d. 1992), started what may have been country’s first commercial airline (went bankrupt). Eugene built radio station 1923; added TV 1948. Stanley took over 1981, redirected into satellite TV. Took public as U.S. Satellite Broadcasting 1996; sold to Hughes/DirecTV 3 years later for $1.3 billion. Latest venture: Moviewatch, satellite and cable channel dedicated to movie information and trivia. “People love movies.” Brainchild of son Stanley E. set to debut in 26 million homes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Descendant of William W. Cargill, who started with one grain elevator in post-Civil War Iowa. Son-in-law John MacMillan rescued company from debt crisis after founder’s death. Agribusiness and trading giant now largest private company in America, with annual sales exceeding $60 billion. Family owns about 90%, employees the rest. Whitney last family CEO, but several family members remain on board. All keep relatively low profile.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Elegant and well-dressed vice chair of Koc Group conglomerate graduated from
Turkish prep school and college. Youngest sister of magnate Rahmi Koc, fluent in French and English, is former recipient of Woman of the Year
contest sponsored by university women's group in Turkey. Honorary Fellow of
London Business School also named a library for herself at university
founded by family.

name: Billionaires
bio: Descendant of William W. Cargill, who started with one grain elevator in post-Civil War Iowa. Son-in-law John MacMillan rescued company from debt crisis after founder’s death. Agribusiness and trading giant now largest private company in America, with annual sales exceeding $60 billion. Family owns about 90%, employees the rest. Whitney last family CEO, but several family members remain on board. All keep relatively low profile.

name: Billionaires
bio: Descendant of William W. Cargill, who started with one grain elevator in post-Civil War Iowa. Son-in-law John MacMillan rescued company from debt crisis after founder’s death. Agribusiness and trading giant now largest private company in America, with annual sales exceeding $60 billion. Family owns about 90%, employees the rest. Whitney last family CEO, but several family members remain on board. All keep relatively low profile.

name: Billionaires
bio: Game over for Red. This summer sold pro football’s Minnesota Vikings to investment group led by real estate developer Zygi Wilf for $600 million, pocketed $354 million profit. Now investing in oil, real estate. Law school dropout got start selling cars, joined Lowry Mays (see) to found radio station giant Clear Channel Communications in 1972. Owns undeveloped land throughout Texas; apartment projects, industrial parks, office buildings in Houston, Austin. Still holds 4.8 million Clear Channel shares worth $160 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather created wholesale grocery business in 1920s. McLane joined 1959, worked night shift loading trucks after earning M.B.A. from Michigan State. Rose to president 1965. Sold family business to tennis partner Sam Walton for cash and Wal-Mart shares in 1990. Invested windfall in pro baseball’s Houston Astros. Also chairman of privately held McLane Group; logistics ventures focus on exporting U.S. goods, revamping transportation for military. Sits on board of Boy Scouts of America.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vietnam vet joined advertising guru William Levine, who started Outdoor Systems in 1980 with billboards, ads in bus stations. Duo took company public 1996, later sold to Infinity Broadcasting 1999 for $8.7 billion in stock (now Viacom shares). Phoenix native also big real estate investor: bought 1,800 acres near Mesa, Ariz. for commercial development. Bought Anaheim Angels (now of Los Angeles) in 2003 for $184 million; baseball franchise now worth $294 million. Donates to youth education and athletics projects through Moreno Family Foundation in Arizona, Angels Foundation in southern California. Also provides scholarships to athletes at alma mater U. of Arizona.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded and chairs software services firm Infosys Technologies. Was chief executive until 2002 when he handed over reins to cofounder Nandan Nilekani. Sits on the boards of the country's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India, and Singapore's DBS Bank. He is also an IT advisor to several Asian countries. Wife Sudha chairs the Infosys Foundation, the firm's philanthrophic arm.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Aruze, which makes pachinko slot machines. Company has been slipping: a defective new machine was one of the reasons sales dropped 30% to $722 million last year; profits were almost halved to $47 million. One bright spot has been Okada's 25% stake in Wynn Resorts, the casino business run by U.S. billionaire Steve Wynn. The two gaming tycoons plan to collaborate on future projects, including one in Macau.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brewmaster of Turkey created one of country's most popular brands, Efes Pilsen beer. He and fellow billionaire Yazici together Anadolu group. Second-generation partnership with Yazici family continues during 37-year-old Anadolu Group's rapid expansion to Russia and former Soviet republics. Also a car guy: makes Isuzus in Turkish plants and imports to Turkey Lada and Kia cars made in Russia and Korea to then be distributed in Ukraine and Central Asia countries. Built hospital affiliated with Johns Hopkins Medical School; it opened in 2005.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Argentina to Cuban parents. Flirted with academic career before becoming urban planner, then consultant to developers in Miami. Chance meeting with New York developer Steven Ross led to lifelong partnership; two cofounded Related Group of Florida 1979. Committed bon vivant and urbanist, obsessive about stylish developments in inner-city Miami years before city’s revival. Sold $2 billion of apartments in 2004, $11 billion more in the pipeline. Big donor to Miami Art Museum plans to build $3 billion Vegas casino Las Ramblas with partners Randy Gerber and George Clooney despite recent property slump in Sin City.

name: Billionaires
bio: Descendant of William W. Cargill, who started with one grain elevator in post-Civil War Iowa. Son-in-law John MacMillan rescued company from debt crisis after founder’s death. Agribusiness and trading giant now largest private company in America, with annual sales exceeding $60 billion. Family owns about 90%, employees the rest. Whitney last family CEO, but several family members remain on board. All keep relatively low profile.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son-in-law of ex-president Leonid Kuchma and founder of steel pipe conglomerate Interpipe, Pinchuk hobnobs with glitterati: he hosted the biggest private lunch at this year's Davos forum to promote Ukraine; also funded an exhibit at the Venice Biennale. Otherwise on a losing streak: his co-owned Kryvorizhstal, Ukraine's largest steel company, was reprivatized and sold to Mittal last year, and another steel mill Nikolpol seems to be heading towards a similar fate this year. Pinchuk says he will continue to fight for his assets. In the meantime, signed a deal in February to sell his Ukrotsbank to Italy's Banca Intesa for more than $1 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: With David Mandelbaum and others, created Interstate Properties in 1968. Self-described “greedy guy” took control of Vornado, owner of moneylosing discount retailer Two Guys, in 1980. Boosted $100 million market cap to $11 billion via shrewd buyouts of Manhattan skyscrapers, purchase of Kennedy clan’s Merchandise Mart in Chicago. Codeveloping new train station and office building to replace tired Pennsylvania Station under Madison Square Garden.

name: Billionaires
bio: Great-grandson of Richard Beatty Mellon, founder of T. Mellon & Sons, predecessor of Mellon Bank. Read newspapers as a child; now owns Pittsburgh Tribune-Review, radio stations in western Pennsylvania. Staunch conservative, big supporter of Heritage Foundation. With wife, Ritchie, donated $1 million to Baltimore-based Catholic Relief Services for East Asian tsunami rescue and relief efforts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father sold family car in 1935 to start trucking and storage business. Donald graduated Wharton, joined firm in 1961, drove acquisition spree. Schneider National now 15,500 drivers, 48,000 trailers, operations in 38 countries. Early adopter of satellite tracking technology; abandoned plan to spin off transportation logistics division after stock market downturn. Ceded day-to-day operations to Schneider veteran Christopher Lofgren; still chairs board.

name: Billionaires
bio:
This widowed mother of three can thank a sweet deal to raise her family&#39s
stake in Brazil&#39s largest flat-steel company, Companhia Siderúrgica Nacional
(CSN), for the increase in her fortune. The Steinbruch and Rabinovitch
families, through their Vicunha Textile, paid a reported $800 million in
1993 for control of CSN, a formerly state-owned steel company. Last year
Dorothéa Steinbruch bought out the Rabinovitch stake, now worth perhaps $900
million, for a reported $588 million. She isn&#39t involved in running CSN
leaving that task to her son Benjamin, who serves as its chairman and chief
executive.

name: Billionaires
bio: Two years after finishing nine-month prison sentence for price-fixing with competitor Christie’s, sold controlling stake in Sotheby’s back to company. Deal ends 2-decade affair with the auction house, setting up likely sale or merger. U. of Michigan dropout built shopping center empire, took public via REIT 1992. Taubman Centers now owns 800,000 square feet of retail space in 10 states.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ran junk bond desk at Goldman Sachs after master’s from Carnegie Mellon University 1982. Founded Appaloosa Management 1993; 30% average annual returns, including 150% in 2003. With wife, Marlene, gave $55 million for Carnegie Mellon’s Tepper School of Business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Surviving widow of famed investor Laurence Tisch (d. 2003). With brother Preston (d. 2005), brooklyn-born siblings started in real estate: bought New Jersey hotel in 1946, started leasing hotels in Atlantic City. Later owned NYC’s Drake, Belmont Plaza, Regency. Took control of Loews Theatres 1959; diversified interests now include insurance (CNA Financial), watches (Bulova), oil drilling (Diamond Offshore Drilling), tobacco (Lorillard). Larry long known for bearish pessimism, informal but tightfisted management style. Still a family business: Wilma’s son James now commands Loews Corp.; Preston’s son Jonathan heads Loews Hotels. Family donations to NYU exceed $100 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded an auto parts/repair company in 1985. Sold 80% of the company, Auto-Teile-Unger, to a British investor group in 2002 for an estimated $800 million. Received another estimated $360 million for the remaining 19%, when the group was sold to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts in July 2004. Now retired and living in Weide, Bavaria.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Sydney, ran family’s shoemaking business, started buying Florida real estate. With Ed, bought Miami TV station for $3.4 million in 1962. Ed took over 1971. Dropped NBC affiliation, revamped as tabloid news station. Applied same formula to Boston station. Son Andrew runs Sunbeam real estate division: more than 4 million square feet of commercial, industrial space, much of it in Broward County, Fla. Ed big donor to United Way, Habitat for Humanity.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners Richard Peery (see), Became 2 of Silicon Valley’s biggest commercial landlords converting farmland bought in the 1960s into pricey office space. Lifelong partners shun debt, the media. Arrillaga a big donor to alma mater Stanford University.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner Min Kao (see) founded Garmin in 1989 to make digital navigation products and communications devices for boats, planes, hikers. Retired as cochairman 2004, now chairman emeritus. New ad campaign features basketball star Yao Ming. Duo met while working as engineers at AlliedSignal; struck out on own in 1989. First customers: U.S. Army during first Gulf war.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of China's most successful property barons. His assets  are mostly in Guangdong Province, an area that missed out on much of China's  property boom but is starting to attract interest. International investors  have shown increasing interest in Hopson. The U.S.? Tiger Fund and Singapore's  government-owned Aranda Investments each paid $63 million for 8.3% stakes in  2005.

name: Billionaires
bio: Last January software firm he founded finally succumbed to takeover by Larry Ellison’s Oracle in $10 billion deal. Cornell graduate hints at possible return to enterprise software market. Set up $10 million fund for ex-PeopleSoft employees unable to find jobs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Unofficial czar of Turkey's medical and pharmaceutical sector got his last name from the honorary title given to his grandfather, Turkey's head pharmacist, 95 years ago. Overseeing expansion of ceramic tile manufacturing unit into Russia and Ireland. His company gave employees a 9.6% pay raise and a 9% bump is social security payments. Along with wife, Oya, Bulent was a major benefactor of Istanbul's new Modern Art Gallery, a renovated 86,000-square-foot former customs warehouse on the waters of the Sea of Marmara. Oya serves as museum's director.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Philip (d. 2004), ran own investment firm, built reputation with buy-and-hold philosophy, early tech investments. Ken worked at dad’s shop after college, struck out on own 1973. Father of the price/sales ratio, author (Super Stocks), long-running FORBES columnist. Today Fisher Investments manages $27 billion. History buff; currently studying interaction between finance and behavioral psychology.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ford Motor—once synonymous with American industrial might—now struggling. Blame intense foreign competition, lack of creativity for declining market share. When grandfather Henry Ford began business in 1903, there were scores of car manufacturers in the U.S. His vision: produce affordable cars for the masses. A century later only Ford and General Motors remain independent, and both are ailing. Henry’s grandson “Bill Sr.” remains largest shareholder. Son and chief exec, Bill Jr., forgoing salary until company recovers. Announced plans to cut 30,000 jobs and shut down 14 plants in January in hopes of bringing company back to profitability by 2008. Spends retirement watching his Detroit Lions pro football team compete in $350 million Ford Field, home of this year&#39s Super Bowl.

name: Billionaires
bio: Read market reports for fun, bought first stock at 13. Founded Gabelli Asset Management 1977; launched first mutual fund 1986. Today company provides advisory services to more than 30 mutual funds, invests most of $29 billion assets under management in equities. Public offering 1999; owns 50% stake, Bill Gates owns 13%. Columbia business school grad skips salary, bonuses, stock options; prefers management-fee-based compensation instead. Lucrative tradeoff: earned $55 million in 2004.

name: Billionaires
bio: Early investor in Berkshire Hathaway lay low until joining Warren Buffett on board in 2003. Harvard M.B.A. founded investment advisory firm First Manhattan Co. 1964, remains a partner. Also sits on board of American Museum of Natural History in New York City. Donated millions to help create Gottesman Hall of Planet Earth exhibit.

name: Billionaires
bio: Navy stint in Vietnam. After M.B.A. from UCLA, became securities analyst at Pacific Life. Discovered how to make money with bonds: trade, don’t buy and hold. Handed $10 million portfolio to manage 1973. Stellar returns justified $20 million bonuses in the 1980s. Bond division spun off to create Pimco. Public 1994. Sold to German insurance giant Allianz AG for $4.7 billion in 2000; personally made more than $400 million. As Pimco chief investment officer earns $40 million annual salary. Obsessively secretive: Kept second wife-to-be in the dark about wealth until they were engaged.

name: Billionaires
bio: Leads the diversified Fosun Group, whose interests include  pharmaceuticals, steel, retailing, finance, real estate and media. Shares in  Fosun's Hong Kong-listed property development arm, Shanghai Forte, have been  flying high, largely due to its strong brand and its national expansion  plans.

name: Billionaires
bio: Self-made chairman of Maruhan Corp., Japans largest chain of pachinko parlors, one of the few legal gambling venues in Japan. Sales of the group have tripled in the past five years to $11 billion, generating $90 million in profit for the year ending March 2005. When the company reached its longtime sales goal of 1 trillion yen ($9.5 billion) last year, Han celebrated in style by inviting 7,000 guests, including 5,100 employees, to a daylong party with music and expensive French cuisine. That shindig cost Han $13 million. The next milestone he has set his company is sales of 5 trillion yen by 2010, though he hasn't said what he will do to celebrate then.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Fujian Province, Hui is one of China's largest  property barons. Owns properties in Beijing, on Nanjing Road and in Fujian  Province. His Shanghai Shimao International Plaza, set along Shanghai's famed  Nanjing Road, will be completed later this year. Also plans to list Shimao's  China real estate holding company in Hong Kong in 2006. The company is  branching out into other cities, with new projects in Wuhan and  Beijing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Captain of the 1964 Cotton Bowl-winning U. of Arkansas Razorbacks football team. Joined father’s insurance business after earning M.B.A. Wildcatter hit gas with first 13 wells drilled in early 1970s. Struck gold again with purchase of Dallas Cowboys football team in 1989. Original $140 million now worth $1.1 billion. Building new $770 million stadium, most expensive sports venue in history. “We’re going to have the highest revenue in the NFL.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Numbers guru earned Harvard math and physics degrees in 3 years. Began as actuarial trainee at Occidental Life for $225 a month, quit after realizing salesmen made more. Created own property and casualty insurance company. Then Mercury General 1962: targeted customers having trouble getting auto insurance; aggressively investigated suspicious claims. Took public 1985.

name: Billionaires
bio: Business school grad derives fortune from a 55% stake in Kotak Mahindra Bank, which he founded and runs; also has partnerships with Goldman Sachs for investment banking and brokering and with Old Mutual for life insurance. Kotak recently sold his personal investment in cellular operator Hutchison Essar for $140 million. Plays the sitar and is a cricket fan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Observant Jewish father was dressmaker in Boston’s Chinatown district, wanted Robert to be a rabbi. Went to Harvard Business School instead. Married Myra Hiatt, whose father ran packaging company Rand-Whitney. Joined, eventually bought company in 1972. Same year started International Forest Products: owns mills, manufactures and distributes paper and packaging products in 80 countries. Fulfilled lifelong desire to own pro football’s New England Patriots in 1994, paying then-record $172 million. Sports franchise now a $1 billion dynasty: Super Bowl champs 2001, 2003, 2004. Likes team players: “If you keep the turkeys out of your life, then good things can happen.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Investment banker provided seed money for Home Depot; owns shares worth $677 million. Also big stake in Eli Lilly. Contentious Queens native sued by N.Y. Attorney General Eliot Spitzer in 2004 over $187.5 million pay package awarded to former New York Stock Exchange chairman Richard Grasso. Intends to fight case in court.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Youngest son of legendary Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-shing borrowed $250 million
from his father in 1991 to launch satellite outfit StarTV. Later sold to
Rupert Murdoch for $950 millionCK; used proceeds to start Pacific Century
Group, invested in technology, real estate, financial services. Also runs
Hong Kong's largest fixed-line telephone operator, PCCW; now the world's
largest provider of Internet Protocol TV with 500,000 subscribers. Owns 55%
stake in Tokyo's Marunouchi building worth at least $400 million. Also a
Canadian citizen.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner John Arrillaga (see), became 2 of Silicon Valley’s biggest commercial landlords converting farmland bought in the 1960s into pricey office space. Lifelong partners shun debt, the media.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner Peter May runs publicly traded buyout firm Triarc. Wharton dropout made first fortune with acquisition, merger of Triangle Industries and National Can 1985. Sold company 5 years later for $830 million profit. Bought Snapple in 1997 from Quaker Oats for $300 million, sold 3 years later for $1.5 billion. Arby’s owner outbid for Burger King by Texas Pacific Group in 2002.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vietnam vet’s Los Angeles Majestic Realty one of country’s largest commercial builders, with 55 million square feet of space. Developing 400-acre business park off Las Vegas’ new beltway with Thomas & Mack. Built Staples Center with Philip Anschutz (see); duo failed in attempt to bring pro football back to Los Angeles. USC grad loves sports: minority owner of pro basketball’s LA Lakers, hockey’s LA Kings. Other vice: antique sports cars.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Sammy, Japan's largest slot-machine maker. Bought out ailing videogame maker Sega Corporation in 2004 for $394 million. Heads the newly combined $4.5 billion (sales) group, now called Sega Sammy. An avid golf player, Satomi has an 8 handicap.

name: Billionaires
bio: Made fortune with older brother Mel covering the U.S. with shopping malls, including Minnesota’s infamous Mall of America. Cochair Simon Property Group, nation’s largest publicly traded retail REIT; owns or operates nearly 350 properties in North America, Japan, Europe. Brothers also own pro basketball’s Indiana Pacers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a bartender, raised in Illinois projects. Paid way through Southern Illinois U. selling life insurance, working construction jobs. Founded Excel Communications 1988; multilevel marketer sold telecommunication products. Sales reached $1 billion after 8 years. Sold to Teleglobe for $3.5 billion in 1998 (later sold to VarTec, which went bankrupt last year and was auctioned). Co-owns WinStar Farm in Kentucky, home to 2003 Kentucky Derby and Preakness winner Funny Cide. Devout Christian attends Bible studies weekly; also coaches children’s basketball team in Dallas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of John T. Dorrance, inventor of condensed soup process. Passed Campbell Soup business on to son, 3 daughters. Third generation now owns about half the company; 4 grandchildren (Dorrance, Malone, Weber and George Strawbridge) sit on board but not involved in day-to-day operations. Grandkids’ interests include horses, art (Weber), real estate and aviation (Dorrance), gardening (Hamilton) and philanthropy, notably “Dodo” Hamilton’s recent $25 million donation to Thomas Jefferson University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Kamil Yazici, founder of Anadolu Group, brewer and distributor of beer and soft drinks, and holder of a 40% stake in all seven of Coca-Cola's Turkish bottling and distributing companies. Got to watch his Efes Pilsen basketball club win the European championship in 1996 and 2000. Has helped open thousands of summer sports camps throughout Turkey to generate interest in basketball. Longtime business partner of fellow billionaire Tuncay Ozilhan (see).

name: Billionaires
bio: Patriarch of the Yeoh family heads YTL Corp., one of Malaysia’s largest conglomerates with interests in construction, utilities, hotels, property development and technology. He and his family not only steered clear of the late 90s financial downturn in Asia, but profited from it. Started buying up land and companies that were selling at cut-rate prices. In 2002, took this shrewd strategy abroad, buying English utility company Wessex Water for US$1.7 billion from the then collapsing Enron. Celebrated YTL Corp.’s 50th anniversary last year at a five-day celebration at Sentul Park in Kuala Lumpur. Top British tenor Russell Watson was the featured performer, 5,000 people won tickets and illustrious guests included Malaysia’s Prime Minister Datuk Seri Abdullah Ahmad Badawi. In September 2005, Yeoh became pro-chancellor of University Malaysia Sabah.

name: Billionaires
bio: Morphed a bed-linen manufacturer into Turkey's largest exporter. His Zorlu holding company encompasses 65 businesses concentrated in consumer electronics, financial services and energy. Once bankrupt private-label TV-maker and distributor Vestel now commands 20% of the European market. Former high school dropout now shuttles around Europe in custom-designed helicopter. Owns Vestel Manisaspor soccer club, which plays in Turkey's Premier Super League.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mall developer introduced snow skiing to Dubai tourists and residents in 2005 with opening of five indoor ski trails in his Mall of the Emirates. Partnered with fellow billionaire Naguib Sawiris of Egypt to form Oasis Capital, a private equity fund for early stage companies in Egypt. His eponymous holding company was founded in 1992 and employs 6,500. Group operates malls, supermarkets, hotels and other properties throughout Middle East and North Africa, including the UAE, Egypt, Bahrain, Lebanon, Oman, Saudi Arabia and Qatar. Brother of Abdulla Al Futtaim (see).

name: Billionaires
bio: Secretive hedge fund manager raised in Raleigh, N.C., studied literature at Middlebury College. Met Wall Street tycoon Walter Frank while working summer job on fishing boat, started trading a year later. Launched Moore Capital 1989; up 86% in first year after correctly guessing Gulf war’s effect on oil prices. Global macro trader now runs 4 funds from London and New York. Signature Moore Global Investments fund returned an average 24% a year since 1990. Charges steep fee for performance: 25% of profits, 3% of assets. Avid hunter owns 435-acre Robin’s Island in Long Island Sound, where he throws traditional English hunting parties.

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime rice trader turned media baron, launched India’s satellite television revolution. His pioneering Zee TV competes with, among others, Sony and Star. Other interests include packaging, theme parks, lotteries and cinema multiplexes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stanford professor set up students Sergey Brin and Larry Page of Google with money men at Kleiner Perkins. Founded Granite Systems with Andreas von Bechtolsheim (see). Backed VMWare. As tenured professor, leads research on fun stuff like distributed interactive simulation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started Poland&#39s largest leasing business, Europejski Fundusz Leasingowy, in 1991, and sold his stake ten years later to French bank Crédit Agricole for $280 million. Since then has concentrated on building a banking, insurance and leasing conglomerate. His publicly listed Getin Holding is buying assets to build a nationwide retail bank. Also holds a significant stake in insurance company TU Europa. Plans to list his LC Corp., a promising property developer. Likes extreme sports like cave diving; was one of the first to sign up to fly into space with Russia (though never came through).

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded NCB stockbrokers in Dublin in 1981. Sold the company in 1994 for $39 million and started his own private-equity firm, International Investment & Underwriting. Owns London City Airport as well as stakes in a variety of companies from Scotland's Celtic Football Club to Ireland's Greencore Group, one of Europe's leading convenience-food manufacturers. This year bought one-third of Latvia's Rietumu Banka, said to be one of the most significant transactions in the Baltic banking sector in recent years. Also owns a stake in Barbados' swank Sandy Lane Hotel. Passionate golfer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns Northern & Shell group, which includes a popular U.K. newspaper, the Daily Express, celeb magazine OK!, and broadcast programs. Got his start as a cloakroom attendant, then sold advertising space at Thompson newspapers; launched his first magazine, International Musician, in 1974. At one time owned over 30 adult entertainment titles; sold them in 2001 to focus on more upscale media. Plays the drums in his band RD Crusaders. Other band members include former musicians from The Who and Led Zeppelin; so far has had three concerts to raise money for charities, with another planned for May 2006.

name: Billionaires
bio: Alpha male at top-dog venture firm Kleiner Perkins has logged 25 years investing in Silicon Valley. Hits: Intuit, Netscape, Amazon, Sun Microsystems. Misses: AtHome, Handspring and Segue, electric scooter touted to change modern transportation. Latest score: Google. KP’s original $12.5 million investment now worth $6.5 billion. On deck: social networking outfit Friendster, and voice-recognition software maker Tellme. Holds an electrical engineering degree from Rice U. and an M.B.A. from Harvard (not to mention plenty of cell phones and other computerized gizmos). Perennial contender for the top spot on FORBES’ annual Midas List of venture capitalists; net worth estimate probably low.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mastermind behind the superfashionable and functional Dyson vacuum. Supported in part by his art-teacher wife's salary, the former art student ran through 5,127 prototypes until he perfected the G-Force, a bagless upright that uses a spinning technology to better keep its suction constant. In 1985 licensed it to a Japanese company; then holed up for another seven years to work on next. Introduced in U.K. in 1993 and was immediate hit. U.S. sales quadrupled in 2004 and boosted group's total revenues by 54% to $747 million. Now available in 39 countries. The San Francisco Museum of Modern Art and eight other museums display his vacuum cleaner. Dyson still spends much of his time in his workshop tinkering with new designs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Marine lover built boats in garage before founding Bayliner Marine Corp. 1955. Doubled revenue every 3 years; sold to Brunswick for $425 million in 1986. Invested proceeds in stocks, bonds, Arizona real estate. Also partner in Westport Shipyard; set to unveil first 164-foot motor yacht later this year. Donated $5.4 million to Arizona State University for Edson Student Entrepreneurial Initiative; funds Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research and the Mayo Clinic.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of hotel impresario Conrad Hilton, joined company after stint as WWII Navy photographer. Rose from elevator operator to president 1966; chairman 1979. Hotel chain now one of the largest in the U.S.: 2,300 hotels, 70,000 employees. Sold stake in pro football San Diego Chargers, invested proceeds in casinos. Now owns big stake in Harrah’s Entertainment; company owns most casinos on Vegas Strip. As celebrity granddaughter Paris would say, “That’s hot.”

name: Billionaires
bio:
Father opened popcorn stand in 1915, grew into major sports concessions 
business. Jeremy took over company after father’s death, transformed Delaware North into global player in food and hospitality. Operates concessions at major ballparks, airports, visitor centers at national parks. Owns Tenaya Lodge, destination resort near Yosemite National Park; Harrison Hot Springs & Spa in British Columbia. Also Boston’s Fleet Center, pro hockey’s Boston Bruins. Avid horseman created equestrian sanctuary on 400 acres near Wellington, Fla.

name: Billionaires
bio: Korean War vet became sales rep for Miles Laboratories; law degree at night school from DePaul U. Partnered with Phillip Frost (see) early 1970s, acquired Key Pharmaceuticals. Turned company around with revamped asthma drug; sold to Schering-Plough for $836 million in 1986. Launched Kos Pharmaceuticals 1988. Introduced cholesterol-control drug Niaspan 1997. Went public same year. Carroll College grad holds more than 50% stake, chairman emeritus position. Donates to New York’s Metropolitan Museum of Art, son’s alma mater Tufts University’s medical school.

name: Billionaires
bio: An original investor in $1.6 billion (sales) Amdocs, a customer-relationship management and billing software firm for large telecom outfits. (One out of every two phone calls made in North America relies on Amdocs software.) Has cashed out nearly $1 billion worth of shares since Amdocs went public in 1998. He's also a part owner of Aurec Group, an Israeli-based private equity firm with cable and telecom investments. The press-shy former diver founded Coral World International, a string of aquariums in Eilat, Israel; Maui, Hawaii; and Perth, Australia. Son Benjamin is a marine biologist.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Turkcell mobile phone company. Fell off the billionaires list in 2003, due to enormous debt load at two of his banks, Pamukbank and Yapi Kredi. He returns to the list having paid off more than $3 billion of the debt.  Sold his Yapi Kredi Bank to Koc Group (see Rahmi Koc). Got a $1.7 billion advance from Russia's Alfa Telecom in exchange for a chunk of Turkcell shares formerly seized by the Turkish government. The agreement was protested by Turkcell's other shareholder, Sweden's TeliaSonera, which claims it had an agreement with Karamehmet to buy those same shares. The dispute is headed for international arbitration.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners John Herma and Jay Baker, took control of Kohl’s department store chain following their 1986 management buyout. Expanded family-operated 40-store chain into 674-branch empire. Kellogg climbed from store manager to chief executive. Retired from day-to-day operations 2001. Surplus inventories, stiff competition drained stock in recent years. Also investor in used-car chain CarMax.

name: Billionaires
bio: Iran's foreign minister has reportedly called him the ambassador of Islam. The former art dealer holds what is likely the largest private collection of Islamic art, including more than 20,000 objects spanning 1,400 years. An Iranian-born Jew, also collects Japanese art of the Meiji period, Indian and Swedish textiles, Spanish damascened metalwork and Russian enamels. A dual U.S.-British citizen, he owns real estate worth tens of millions in the U.K. and resides in the upscale Mayfair section of London. Borrows Arsenal Football Club's soccer field to host matches for Muslim and Jewish children, between the ages of 9 and 12, on Sunday mornings.

name: Billionaires
bio: After tumultuous parliamentary hearings about his role in the sale of Poland's oil giant Orlen, which included allegations of meeting a Russian spy, Kulczyk's reputation and business suffered. Kulczyk denied the allegations and decided to make holdings more transparent to avoid further accusations of shady dealings. Sold off stakes in telecom, insurance and oil interests. Still owns auto importer, Kulczyk Tradex, which sells Volkswagen, Audi and Porsche. Also has stakes in real estate and transportation companies. Pulled back from Polish investing to focus on eastern Europe, specifically Ukraine.

name: Billionaires
bio: The youngest of the four Liu brothers who formed the Hope  Group before going their own ways, Liu is the largest shareholder of Minsheng  Bank, China's largest private bank. He is also looking to expand his  agribusiness investments.

name: Billionaires
bio: Flamboyant liquor tycoon acquired archrival Shaw Wallace last June to make his UB group the world's third-largest spirits producer by volume. His top brands include Kingfisher beer and Bagpiper whiskey. Scottish & Newcastle is his partner in beer. His Kingfisher Airline, named after his bestselling beer and modeled after JetBlue, launched last year and plans to list soon. Has anointed his 18-year old son Sidhartha as successor. Personal toys include fleet of vintage cars and stud farm with 200 horses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Financier completed $4.5 billion sale of International Steel Group to Indian mogul Lakshmi Mittal in October 2004. Cash and stock deal created world’s largest steel company. Lawyer’s son got start parking cars at racetrack in Monmouth, N.J. Dreamed of being a writer; worked on literary magazine at Yale. Summer job on Wall Street, then position at Rothschild 1976. Began running private equity fund 1997, founded WL Ross & Co. three years later. Buys up companies in tired industries like coal, steel, textiles; cleans up balance sheet, improves management, sells for profit. Today manages about $3 billion in 7 private equity funds, 2 hedge funds. Taking heat for safety record of his International Coal Group: company owned West Virginia Sago mine, where 12 miners died in January.

name: Billionaires
bio: Author had a banner year last year. Last July, Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince, the sixth book in her widely successful Potter series, was a huge hit. Rowling sold 60 million books worldwide last year, bringing the tally to 310 million copies of Harry Potter books sold. In November, Warner Bros. released Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, the fourth Potter film and reversed a creeping Harry box-office slide. The movie pulled in $287 million in the U.S., the highest grossing film in the series after the debut film. A source in the Rowling camp says that last book in the series will be out in 2007.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of billionaire banker Edmond Safra is a philanthropist and socialite in New York and London, with homes in Geneva and Monaco as well. Last year Safra took offense at what she deemed a thinly veiled, defamatory portrayal of her in the novel "Empress Bianca" by Lady Colin Campbell. In the novel, the main character kills two of her four husbands. In reality, Edmond died in 1999 in an arson attack at his apartment in Monaco. Safra complained and had Campbell's book removed from shelves and pulped; Campbell is suing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns a third of German publishing house, Verlagsgruppe Holtzbrinck. Brothers Dieter and Stefan von Holtzbrinck own the rest. She heads its S. Fischer Verlag unit, which dates back to 1886, original publishers of Thamas Mann, Kafka and Hermann Hesse.

name: Billionaires
bio: Small-time builder risked everything on one Manhattan high-rise in 1972. “We’re in barracuda land. You can only get away with this once.” Once is enough when it’s 9 West 57th Street, still one of Manhattan’s premier office buildings.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Seven Network, the TV and publishing conglomerate that competes with James Packer's(see) PBL. Going up against the big guys, Stokes is suing several companies including Murdoch's News Corp. and Packer's PBL for $820 million. He alleges they ruined his pay-television sports channel C7 by colluding to prevent him from getting the rights to broadcast Australian football. Also owns WesTrac, one of the largest Caterpillar equipment dealers, with operations in Australia and northern China.

name: Billionaires
bio: His Rimbunan Hijau Group got its start in 1975 as a timber contractor in Sarawak, Malaysia. Operations now span New Zealand, central Africa, Papua New Guinea and Vanuatu. Maintains that his logging operations benefit local communities and are conducted with sustainable forest management practices. Now trying to build a global Chinese media group.  In recent years, his publishing house Ming Pao Enterprises introduced local editions of the Chinese-language daily Ming Pao in cities like San Francisco, New York, Vancouver and Toronto.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of John T. Dorrance, inventor of condensed soup process. Passed Campbell Soup business on to son, 3 daughters. Third generation now owns about half the company; 4 grandchildren (Dorrance, Malone, Weber and George Strawbridge) sit on board but not involved in day-to-day operations. Grandkids’ interests include horses, art (Weber), real estate and aviation (Dorrance), gardening (Hamilton) and philanthropy, notably “Dodo” Hamilton’s recent $25 million donation to Thomas Jefferson U.

name: Billionaires
bio: Considered the brains behind Turkcell. His idea for mobile phone company was eventually funded by billionaire Mehmet Karamehmet. Sat on Turkcell board from 1993 until May 2005. Still owns nearly a billion-dollar stake in the NYSE-listed telecom stock. Rents out his 120-foot yacht, Jasmin, docked at Antibes, France, for $70,000 per week in the low season.

name: Billionaires
bio: With half-brother Dieter and half-sister Monika Schoeller, inherited publishing house, Verlagsgruppe Holtzbrinck, from their father George who founded it in 1948. Each owns one-third. Stefan took over the management of the company from Dieter who retired in May 2001. The $2.4 billion (sales) company owns renowned German newspaper Die Zeit and publishing houses including Henry Holt in New York and Macmillan in London. A lawyer, Stefan apprenticed at Bloomsbury Publishing in London before joining Holtzbrinck in 1994.

name: Billionaires
bio: With fellow Indiana U. alum Mark Cuban (see) created Internet outfit Broadcast.com 1995; sold to Yahoo for $5.7 billion. Branched into Hollywood: owns stakes in 2929 Entertainment, Lions Gate, Magnolia Pictures, Rysher Entertainment, Landmark Theaters and high-definition network HDNet. Former lawyer supports afterschool programs for inner-city children.

name: Billionaires
bio: Parents ran newspaper in Delhi, La. Sam cleaned presses, sold ads. Followed brother to Louisiana Tech. Worked at IBM, Honeywell. Founded supercomputer operator University Computing with $1,000 in 1963; $57 million (sales) by 1968. Added investments in insurance, oil, restaurants. Bought controlling interest in arts and crafts chain Michaels Stores 1982. Sold Sterling Software to Computer Associates in 2000 for $4 billion; launched failed proxy battle to oust chairman, 4 board members. Former refinery investor turning green: family owns 7 Toyota Priuses; insulated Colorado ranch with old blue jeans. Also director, largest stockholder, of clean-energy producer Green Mountain Energy.
